cts:urn:0032-006:1.1.1
glaux1.0-sentence	1
perseus-grc2	Δαρείου καὶ Παρυσάτιδος γίγνονται παῖδες δύο , πρεσβύτερος μὲν Ἀρταξέρξης , νεώτερος δὲ Κῦρος ·
perseus-eng2	Darius and Parysatis had two sons born to them, of whom the elder was Artaxerxes and the younger  Cyrus .

cts:urn:0032-006:1.1.1
glaux1.0-sentence	2
perseus-grc2	ἐπεὶ δὲ ἠσθένει Δαρεῖος καὶ ὑπώπτευε τελευτὴν τοῦ βίου , ἐβούλετο τὼ παῖδε ἀμφοτέρω παρεῖναι .
perseus-eng2	Now when Darius lay sick and suspected that the end of his life was near, he wished to have both his sons with him.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.1.2
glaux1.0-sentence	3
perseus-grc2	ὁ μὲν οὖν πρεσβύτερος παρὼν ἐτύγχανε ·
perseus-eng2	The elder, as it chanced, was with him already;

cts:urn:0032-006:1.1.2
glaux1.0-sentence	4
perseus-grc2	Κῦρον δὲ μεταπέμπεται ἀπὸ τῆς ἀρχῆς ἧς αὐτὸν σατράπην ἐποίησε , καὶ στρατηγὸν δὲ αὐτὸν ἀπέδειξε πάντων ὅσοι ἐς Καστωλοῦ πεδίον ἁθροίζονται .
perseus-eng2	but  Cyrus  he summoned from the province over which he had made him satrap, and he had also appointed him commander of all the forces that muster in the plain of Castolus.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.1.2
glaux1.0-sentence	5
perseus-grc2	ἀναβαίνει οὖν ὁ Κῦρος λαβὼν Τισσαφέρνην ὡς φίλον , καὶ τῶν Ἑλλήνων ἔχων ὁπλίτας ἀνέβη τριακοσίους , ἄρχοντα δὲ αὐτῶν Ξενίαν Παρράσιον .
perseus-eng2	 Cyrus  accordingly went up under the command of Xenias of  Parrhasia .

cts:urn:0032-006:1.1.3
glaux1.0-sentence	6
perseus-grc2	ἐπεὶ δὲ ἐτελεύτησε Δαρεῖος καὶ κατέστη εἰς τὴν βασιλείαν Ἀρταξέρξης , Τισσαφέρνης διαβάλλει τὸν Κῦρον πρὸς τὸν ἀδελφὸν ὡς ἐπιβουλεύοι αὐτῷ .
perseus-eng2	When Darius had died and Artaxerxes had become established as king, Tissaphernes falsely accused  Cyrus  to his brother of plotting against him.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.1.3
glaux1.0-sentence	7
perseus-grc2	ὁ δὲ πείθεται καὶ συλλαμβάνει Κῦρον ὡς ἀποκτενῶν ·
perseus-eng2	And Artaxerxes, believing the accusation, arrested  Cyrus , with the intention of putting him to death;

cts:urn:0032-006:1.1.3
glaux1.0-sentence	8
perseus-grc2	ἡ δὲ μήτηρ ἐξαιτησαμένη αὐτὸν ἀποπέμπει πάλιν ἐπὶ τὴν ἀρχήν .
perseus-eng2	his mother, however, made intercession for him, and sent him back again to his province.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.1.4
glaux1.0-sentence	9
perseus-grc2	ὁ δ’ ὡς ἀπῆλθε κινδυνεύσας καὶ ἀτιμασθείς , βουλεύεται ὅπως μήποτε ἔτι ἔσται ἐπὶ τῷ ἀδελφῷ , ἀλλά , ἢν δύνηται , βασιλεύσει ἀντ’ ἐκείνου .
perseus-eng2	Now when  Cyrus  had thus returned, after his danger and disgrace, he set about planning that he might never again be in the power of his brother, but, if possible, might be king in his stead.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.1.4
glaux1.0-sentence	10
perseus-grc2	Παρύσατις μὲν δὴ ἡ μήτηρ ὑπῆρχε τῷ Κύρῳ , φιλοῦσα αὐτὸν μᾶλλον ἢ τὸν βασιλεύοντα Ἀρταξέρξην .
perseus-eng2	He had, in the first place, the support of Parysatis, his mother, for she loved him better than the son who was king, Artaxerxes.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.1.5
glaux1.0-sentence	11
perseus-grc2	ὅστις δ’ ἀφικνεῖτο τῶν παρὰ βασιλέως πρὸς αὐτὸν πάντας οὕτω διατιθεὶς ἀπεπέμπετο ὥστε αὐτῷ μᾶλλον φίλους εἶναι ἢ βασιλεῖ .
perseus-eng2	Again, when any of the King’s court came to visit him, he treated them all in such a way that when he sent them back they were more devoted to him than to the King.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.1.5
glaux1.0-sentence	12
perseus-grc2	καὶ τῶν παρ’ ἑαυτῷ δὲ βαρβάρων ἐπεμελεῖτο ὡς πολεμεῖν τε ἱκανοὶ εἴησαν καὶ εὐνοϊκῶς ἔχοιεν αὐτῷ .
perseus-eng2	He also took care that the barbarians of his own province should be capable soldiers and should feel kindly toward him.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.1.6
glaux1.0-sentence	13
perseus-grc2	τὴν δὲ Ἑλληνικὴν δύναμιν ἥθροιζεν ὡς μάλιστα ἐδύνατο ἐπικρυπτόμενος , ὅπως ὅτι ἀπαρασκευότατον λάβοι βασιλέα .
perseus-eng2	Lastly, as regards his Greek force, he proceeded to collect it with the utmost secrecy, so that he might take the King as completely unprepared as possible.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.1.6
glaux1.0-sentence	14
perseus-grc2	ὧδε οὖν ἐποιεῖτο τὴν συλλογήν .
perseus-eng2	It was in the following way, then, that he gathered this force:

cts:urn:0032-006:1.1.6
glaux1.0-sentence	15
perseus-grc2	ὁπόσας εἶχε φυλακὰς ἐν ταῖς πόλεσι παρήγγειλε τοῖς φρουράρχοις ἑκάστοις λαμβάνειν ἄνδρας Πελοποννησίους ὅτι πλείστους καὶ βελτίστους , ὡς ἐπιβουλεύοντος Τισσαφέρνους ταῖς πόλεσι .
perseus-eng2	In the first place, he sent orders to the commanders of all the garrisons he had in the cities to enlist as many Peloponnesian soldiers of the best sort as they severally could, on the plea that Tissaphernes had designs upon their cities.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.1.6
glaux1.0-sentence	16
perseus-grc2	καὶ γὰρ ἦσαν αἱ Ἰωνικαὶ πόλεις Τισσαφέρνους τὸ ἀρχαῖον ἐκ βασιλέως δεδομέναι , τότε δὲ ἀφειστήκεσαν πρὸς Κῦρον πᾶσαι πλὴν Μιλήτου ·
perseus-eng2	For, in fact, the Ionian cities had originally belonged to Tissaphernes, by gift of the King, but at that time all of them except  Miletus  had revolted and gone over to  Cyrus .

cts:urn:0032-006:1.1.7
glaux1.0-sentence	17
perseus-grc2	ἐν Μιλήτῳ δὲ Τισσαφέρνης προαισθόμενος τὰ αὐτὰ ταῦτα βουλευομένους ἀποστῆναι πρὸς Κῦρον , τοὺς μὲν αὐτῶν ἀπέκτεινε τοὺς δ’ ἐξέβαλεν .
perseus-eng2	The people of  Miletus  also were planning to do the very same thing, namely, to go over to  Cyrus , but Tissaphernes, finding out about it in time, put some of them to death and banished others.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.1.7
glaux1.0-sentence	18
perseus-grc2	ὁ δὲ Κῦρος ὑπολαβὼν τοὺς φεύγοντας συλλέξας στράτευμα ἐπολιόρκει Μίλητον καὶ κατὰ γῆν καὶ κατὰ θάλατταν καὶ ἐπειρᾶτο κατάγειν τοὺς ἐκπεπτωκότας .
perseus-eng2	 Cyrus  thereupon took the exiles under his protection, collected an army, and laid siege to  Miletus  both by land and by sea, and endeavoured to restore the exiles to their city;

cts:urn:0032-006:1.1.7
glaux1.0-sentence	19
perseus-grc2	καὶ αὕτη αὖ ἄλλη πρόφασις ἦν αὐτῷ τοῦ ἁθροίζειν στράτευμα .
perseus-eng2	and this, again, made him another pretext for gathering an army.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.1.8
glaux1.0-sentence	20
perseus-grc2	πρὸς δὲ βασιλέα πέμπων ἠξίου ἀδελφὸς ὢν αὐτοῦ δοθῆναι οἷ ταύτας τὰς πόλεις μᾶλλον ἢ Τισσαφέρνην ἄρχειν αὐτῶν , καὶ ἡ μήτηρ συνέπραττεν αὐτῷ ταῦτα ·
perseus-eng2	Meanwhile he sent to the King and urged, on the ground that he was his brother, that these Ionian cities should be given to him instead of remaining under the rule of Tissaphernes, and his mother co-operated with him in this.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.1.8
glaux1.0-sentence	21
perseus-grc2	ὥστε βασιλεὺς τὴν μὲν πρὸς ἑαυτὸν ἐπιβουλὴν οὐκ ᾐσθάνετο , Τισσαφέρνει δ’ ἐνόμιζε πολεμοῦντα αὐτὸν ἀμφὶ τὰ στρατεύματα δαπανᾶν ·
perseus-eng2	The result was that the King failed to perceive the plot against himself, but believed that  Cyrus  was spending money on his troops because he was at war with Tissaphernes.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.1.8
glaux1.0-sentence	22
perseus-grc2	ὥστε οὐδὲν ἤχθετο αὐτῶν πολεμούντων .
perseus-eng2	Consequently he was not at all displeased at their being at war.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.1.8
glaux1.0-sentence	23
perseus-grc2	καὶ γὰρ ὁ Κῦρος ἀπέπεμπε τοὺς γιγνομένους δασμοὺς βασιλεῖ ἐκ τῶν πόλεων ὧν Τισσαφέρνους ἐτύγχανεν ἔχων .
perseus-eng2	For  Cyrus  regularly remitted to the King the tribute which came in from the cities he chanced to have that belonged to Tissaphernes.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.1.9
glaux1.0-sentence	24
perseus-grc2	ἄλλο δὲ στράτευμα αὐτῷ συνελέγετο ἐν Χερρονήσῳ τῇ κατ’ ἀντιπέρας Ἀβύδου τόνδε τὸν τρόπον .
perseus-eng2	Still another army was being collected for him in the  Chersonese  which is opposite  Abydus , in the following manner:

cts:urn:0032-006:1.1.9
glaux1.0-sentence	25
perseus-grc2	Κλέαρχος Λακεδαιμόνιος φυγὰς ἦν ·
perseus-eng2	Clearchus was a Lacedaemonian exile;

cts:urn:0032-006:1.1.9
glaux1.0-sentence	26
perseus-grc2	τούτῳ συγγενόμενος ὁ Κῦρος ἠγάσθη τε αὐτὸν καὶ δίδωσιν αὐτῷ μυρίους δαρεικούς .
perseus-eng2	 Cyrus , making his acquaintance, came to admire him, and gave him ten thousand darics.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.1.9
glaux1.0-sentence	27
perseus-grc2	ὁ δὲ λαβὼν τὸ χρυσίον στράτευμα συνέλεξεν ἀπὸ τούτων τῶν χρημάτων καὶ ἐπολέμει ἐκ Χερρονήσου ὁρμώμενος τοῖς Θρᾳξὶ τοῖς ὑπὲρ Ἑλλήσποντον οἰκοῦσι καὶ ὠφέλει τοὺς Ἕλληνας ·
perseus-eng2	And Clearchus, taking the gold, collected an army by means of this money, and using the  Chersonese  as a base of operations, proceeded to make war upon the Thracians who dwell beyond the  Hellespont , thereby aiding the Greeks.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.1.9
glaux1.0-sentence	28
perseus-grc2	ὥστε καὶ χρήματα συνεβάλλοντο αὐτῷ εἰς τὴν τροφὴν τῶν στρατιωτῶν αἱ Ἑλλησποντιακαὶ πόλεις ἑκοῦσαι .
perseus-eng2	Consequently, the Hellespontine cities of their own free will sent Clearchus contributions of money for the support of his troops.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.1.9
glaux1.0-sentence	29
perseus-grc2	τοῦτο δ’ αὖ οὕτω τρεφόμενον ἐλάνθανεν αὐτῷ τὸ στράτευμα .
perseus-eng2	So it was that this army also was being secretly maintained for  Cyrus .

cts:urn:0032-006:1.1.10
glaux1.0-sentence	30
perseus-grc2	Ἀρίστιππος δὲ ὁ Θετταλὸς ξένος ὢν ἐτύγχανεν αὐτῷ , καὶ πιεζόμενος ὑπὸ τῶν οἴκοι ἀντιστασιωτῶν ἔρχεται πρὸς τὸν Κῦρον καὶ αἰτεῖ αὐτὸν εἰς δισχιλίους ξένους καὶ τριῶν μηνῶν μισθόν , ὡς οὕτως περιγενόμενος ἂν τῶν ἀντιστασιωτῶν .
perseus-eng2	Again, Aristippus the Thessalian chanced to be a friend of  Cyrus , and since he was hard pressed by his political opponents at home, he came to  Cyrus  and asked him for three months’ pay for two thousand mercenaries, urging that in this way he should get the better of his opponents.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.1.10
glaux1.0-sentence	31
perseus-grc2	ὁ δὲ Κῦρος δίδωσιν αὐτῷ εἰς τετρακισχιλίους καὶ ἓξ μηνῶν μισθόν , καὶ δεῖται αὐτοῦ μὴ πρόσθεν καταλῦσαι πρὸς τοὺς ἀντιστασιώτας πρὶν ἂν αὐτῷ συμβουλεύσηται .
perseus-eng2	And  Cyrus  gave him six months’ pay for four thousand, and requested him not to come to terms with his opponents until he had consulted with him.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.1.10
glaux1.0-sentence	32
perseus-grc2	οὕτω δὲ αὖ τὸ ἐν Θετταλίᾳ ἐλάνθανεν αὐτῷ τρεφόμενον στράτευμα .
perseus-eng2	Thus the army in  Thessaly , again, was being secretly maintained for him.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.1.11
glaux1.0-sentence	33
perseus-grc2	Πρόξενον δὲ τὸν Βοιώτιον ξένον ὄντα ἐκέλευσε λαβόντα ἄνδρας ὅτι πλείστους παραγενέσθαι , ὡς ἐς Πισίδας βουλόμενος στρατεύεσθαι , ὡς πράγματα παρεχόντων τῶν Πισιδῶν τῇ ἑαυτοῦ χώρᾳ .
perseus-eng2	Furthermore,  Cyrus  directed Proxenus the Boeotian, who was a friend of his, to come to him with as many men as he could get, saying that he wished to undertake a campaign against the Pisidians, because, as he said, they were causing trouble to his province.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.1.11
glaux1.0-sentence	34
perseus-grc2	Σοφαίνετον δὲ τὸν Στυμφάλιον καὶ Σωκράτην τὸν Ἀχαιόν , ξένους ὄντας καὶ τούτους , ἐκέλευσεν ἄνδρας λαβόντας ἐλθεῖν ὅτι πλείστους , ὡς πολεμήσων Τισσαφέρνει σὺν τοῖς φυγάσι τοῖς Μιλησίων .
perseus-eng2	He also directed Sophaenetus the Stymphalian and Socrates the Achaean, who were likewise friends of his, to come with as many men as they could get, saying that he intended to make war upon Tissaphernes with the aid of the Milesian exiles;

cts:urn:0032-006:1.1.11
glaux1.0-sentence	35
perseus-grc2	καὶ ἐποίουν οὕτως οὗτοι .
perseus-eng2	and they proceeded to carry out his directions.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.2.1
glaux1.0-sentence	36
perseus-grc2	ἐπεὶ δ’ ἐδόκει ἤδη πορεύεσθαι αὐτῷ ἄνω , τὴν μὲν πρόφασιν ἐποιεῖτο ὡς Πισίδας βουλόμενος ἐκβαλεῖν παντάπασιν ἐκ τῆς χώρας ·
perseus-eng2	When he thought the time had come to begin his upward march, the pretext he offered was that he wished to drive the Pisidians out of his land entirely.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.2.1
glaux1.0-sentence	37
perseus-grc2	καὶ ἁθροίζει ὡς ἐπὶ τούτους τό τε βαρβαρικὸν καὶ τὸ Ἑλληνικόν .
perseus-eng2	It was avowedly against them that he set about collecting both his barbarian and his Greek troops.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.2.1
glaux1.0-sentence	38
perseus-grc2	ἐνταῦθα καὶ παραγγέλλει τῷ τε Κλεάρχῳ λαβόντι ἥκειν ὅσον ἦν αὐτῷ στράτευμα καὶ τῷ Ἀριστίππῳ συναλλαγέντι πρὸς τοὺς οἴκοι ἀποπέμψαι πρὸς ἑαυτὸν ὃ εἶχε στράτευμα ·
perseus-eng2	At that time he also sent word to Clearchus to come to him with the entire army which he had, and to Aristippus to effect a reconciliation with his adversaries at home and send him the army which he had;

cts:urn:0032-006:1.2.1
glaux1.0-sentence	39
perseus-grc2	καὶ Ξενίᾳ τῷ Ἀρκάδι , ὃς αὐτῷ προειστήκει τοῦ ἐν ταῖς πόλεσι ξενικοῦ , ἥκειν παραγγέλλει λαβόντα τοὺς ἄλλους πλὴν ὁπόσοι ἱκανοὶ ἦσαν τὰς ἀκροπόλεις φυλάττειν .
perseus-eng2	and he sent word to Xenias the Arcadian, who commanded for him the mercenary force in the cities, to come with his troops, leaving behind only so many as were necessary to garrison the citadels.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.2.2
glaux1.0-sentence	40
perseus-grc2	ἐκάλεσε δὲ καὶ τοὺς Μίλητον πολιορκοῦντας , καὶ τοὺς φυγάδας ἐκέλευσε σὺν αὐτῷ στρατεύεσθαι , ὑποσχόμενος αὐτοῖς , εἰ καλῶς καταπράξειεν ἐφ’ ἃ ἐστρατεύετο , μὴ πρόσθεν παύσεσθαι πρὶν αὐτοὺς καταγάγοι οἴκαδε .
perseus-eng2	He likewise summoned the troops which were besieging  Miletus , and urged the Milesian exiles to take the field with him, promising them that, if he should successfully accomplish the object for which he was taking the field, he would not stop until he had restored them to their homes.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.2.2
glaux1.0-sentence	41
perseus-grc2	οἱ δὲ ἡδέως ἐπείθοντο ·
perseus-eng2	And they gladly obeyed.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.2.2
glaux1.0-sentence	42
perseus-grc2	ἐπίστευον γὰρ αὐτῷ ·
perseus-eng2	For they trusted him.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.2.2
glaux1.0-sentence	43
perseus-grc2	καὶ λαβόντες τὰ ὅπλα παρῆσαν εἰς Σάρδεις .
perseus-eng2	They presented themselves, under arms, at  Sardis .

cts:urn:0032-006:1.2.3
glaux1.0-sentence	44
perseus-grc2	Ξενίας μὲν δὴ τοὺς ἐκ τῶν πόλεων λαβὼν παρεγένετο εἰς Σάρδεις ὁπλίτας εἰς τετρακισχιλίους , Πρόξενος δὲ παρῆν ἔχων ὁπλίτας μὲν εἰς πεντακοσίους καὶ χιλίους , γυμνῆτας δὲ πεντακοσίους , Σοφαίνετος δὲ ὁ Στυμφάλιος ὁπλίτας ἔχων χιλίους , Σωκράτης δὲ ὁ Ἀχαιὸς ὁπλίτας ἔχων ὡς πεντακοσίους , Πασίων δὲ ὁ Μεγαρεὺς τριακοσίους μὲν ὁπλίτας , τριακοσίους δὲ πελταστὰς ἔχων παρεγένετο ·
perseus-eng2	Xenias, then, arrived at  Sardis  with the troops from the cities, who were hoplites to the number of four thousand._Proxenus was there with hoplites to the number of fifteen hundred, and five hundred light-armed troops, Sophaenetus the Stymphalian with a thousand hoplites, Socrates the Achaean with about five hundred hoplites, and Pasion the Megarian arrived with three hundred hoplites and three hundred peltasts.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.2.3
glaux1.0-sentence	45
perseus-grc2	ἦν δὲ καὶ οὗτος καὶ ὁ Σωκράτης τῶν ἀμφὶ Μίλητον στρατευομένων .
perseus-eng2	The last-named, and Socrates also, belonged to the force that had been engaged in besieging  Miletus .

cts:urn:0032-006:1.2.4
glaux1.0-sentence	46
perseus-grc2	οὗτοι μὲν εἰς Σάρδεις αὐτῷ ἀφίκοντο .
perseus-eng2	All these came to  Cyrus  at  Sardis .

cts:urn:0032-006:1.2.4
glaux1.0-sentence	47
perseus-grc2	Τισσαφέρνης δὲ κατανοήσας ταῦτα , καὶ μείζονα ἡγησάμενος εἶναι ἢ ὡς ἐπὶ Πισίδας τὴν παρασκευήν , πορεύεται ὡς βασιλέα ᾗ ἐδύνατο τάχιστα ἱππέας ἔχων ὡς πεντακοσίους .
perseus-eng2	Meanwhile Tissaphernes had taken note of these proceedings and come to the conclusion that  Cyrus ’ preparations were too extensive to be against the Pisidians;_he accordingly made his way to the King as quickly as he could, with about five hundred horsemen.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.2.5
glaux1.0-sentence	48
perseus-grc2	καὶ βασιλεὺς μὲν δὴ ἐπεὶ ἤκουσε Τισσαφέρνους τὸν Κύρου στόλον , ἀντιπαρεσκευάζετο .
perseus-eng2	And when the King heard from Tissaphernes about  Cyrus ’ array, he set about making counter-preparations.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.2.5
glaux1.0-sentence	49
perseus-grc2	Κῦρος δὲ ἔχων οὓς εἴρηκα ὡρμᾶτο ἀπὸ Σάρδεων ·
perseus-eng2	  Cyrus  was now setting forth from  Sardis  with the troops I have mentioned;

cts:urn:0032-006:1.2.5
glaux1.0-sentence	50
perseus-grc2	καὶ ἐξελαύνει διὰ τῆς Λυδίας σταθμοὺς τρεῖς παρασάγγας εἴκοσι καὶ δύο ἐπὶ τὸν Μαίανδρον ποταμόν .
perseus-eng2	and he marched through  Lydia  three stages, to the  Maeander  river.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.2.5
glaux1.0-sentence	51
perseus-grc2	τούτου τὸ εὖρος δύο πλέθρα ·
perseus-eng2	The width of this river was two plethra.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.2.5
glaux1.0-sentence	52
perseus-grc2	γέφυρα δὲ ἐπῆν ἐζευγμένη πλοίοις .
perseus-eng2	There was a bridge over it made of seven boats.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.2.6
glaux1.0-sentence	53
perseus-grc2	τοῦτον διαβὰς ἐξελαύνει διὰ Φρυγίας σταθμὸν ἕνα παρασάγγας ὀκτὼ εἰς Κολοσσάς , πόλιν οἰκουμένην καὶ εὐδαίμονα καὶ μεγάλην .
perseus-eng2	After crossing the Maeander he marched through  Phrygia  one stage, a distance of eight parasangs, to  Colossae , an inhabited city, prosperous and large.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.2.6
glaux1.0-sentence	54
perseus-grc2	ἐνταῦθα ἔμεινεν ἡμέρας ἑπτά ·
perseus-eng2	There he remained seven days;

cts:urn:0032-006:1.2.6
glaux1.0-sentence	55
perseus-grc2	καὶ ἧκε Μένων ὁ Θετταλὸς ὁπλίτας ἔχων χιλίους καὶ πελταστὰς πεντακοσίους , Δόλοπας καὶ Αἰνιᾶνας καὶ Ὀλυνθίους .
perseus-eng2	and Menon the Thessalian arrived, with a thousand hoplites and five hundred peltasts, consisting of Dolopians, Aenianians, and Olynthians.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.2.7
glaux1.0-sentence	56
perseus-grc2	ἐντεῦθεν ἐξελαύνει σταθμοὺς τρεῖς παρασάγγας εἴκοσιν εἰς Κελαινάς , τῆς Φρυγίας πόλιν οἰκουμένην , μεγάλην καὶ εὐδαίμονα .

cts:urn:0032-006:1.2.7
glaux1.0-sentence	57
perseus-grc2	ἐνταῦθα Κύρῳ βασίλεια ἦν καὶ παράδεισος μέγας ἀγρίων θηρίων πλήρης , ἃ ἐκεῖνος ἐθήρευεν ἀπὸ ἵππου , ὁπότε γυμνάσαι βούλοιτο ἑαυτόν τε καὶ τοὺς ἵππους .
perseus-eng2	There  Cyrus  had a palace and a large park full of wild animals, which he used to hunt on horseback whenever he wished to give himself and his horses exercise.

glaux1.0-sentence	58

perseus-eng2	There is likewise a palace of the Great King in Celaenae, strongly fortified and situated at the foot of the Acropolis over the sources of the Marsyas river;

cts:urn:0032-006:1.2.8
glaux1.0-sentence	64

perseus-eng2	It was here, according to the story, that Apollo flayed Marsyas, after having defeated him in a contest of musical skill; he hung up his skin in the cave from which the sources issue,

cts:urn:0032-006:1.2.8
glaux1.0-sentence	65

perseus-eng2	It was here also, report has it, that Xerxes, when he was on his retreat from  Greece  after losing the famous battle, built the palace just mentioned and likewise the citadel of Celaenae.

perseus-eng2	When he had driven past them all, he halted his chariot in front of the centre of the phalanx, and sending his interpreter Pigres to the generals of the Greeks, gave orders that the troops should advance arms and the phalanx move forward in a body.

perseus-eng2	And then, as they went on faster and faster, at length with a shout the troops broke into a run of their own accord, in the direction of the camp. As for the barbarians, they were terribly frightened; the Cilician queen took to flight in her carriage, and the people in the market left their wares behind and took to their heels.

perseus-eng2	Therefore  Cyrus  remained for a day in the plain.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.2.21
glaux1.0-sentence	120
perseus-grc2	τῇ δ’ ὑστεραίᾳ ἧκεν ἄγγελος λέγων ὅτι λελοιπὼς εἴη Συέννεσις τὰ ἄκρα , ἐπεὶ ᾔσθετο ὅτι τὸ Μένωνος στράτευμα ἤδη ἐν Κιλικίᾳ ἦν εἴσω τῶν ὀρέων , καὶ ὅτι τριήρεις ἤκουε περιπλεούσας ἀπ’ Ἰωνίας εἰς Κιλικίαν Ταμὼν ἔχοντα τὰς Λακεδαιμονίων καὶ αὐτοῦ Κύρου .
perseus-eng2	On the following day, however, a messenger came with word that Syennesis had abandoned the heights, because he had learned that Menon’s army was already in  Cilicia , on his own side of the mountains, and because, further, he was getting reports that triremes belonging to the Lacedaemonians and to  Cyrus  himself were sailing around from  Ionia  to  Cilicia  under the command of Tamos.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.2.22
glaux1.0-sentence	121
perseus-grc2	Κῦρος δ’ οὖν ἀνέβη ἐπὶ τὰ ὄρη οὐδενὸς κωλύοντος , καὶ εἶδε τὰς σκηνὰς οὗ οἱ Κίλικες ἐφύλαττον .
perseus-eng2	At any rate Cyrus  climbed the mountains without meeting any opposition, and saw the camp where the Cilicians had been keeping guard.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.2.22
glaux1.0-sentence	122
perseus-grc2	ἐντεῦθεν δὲ κατέβαινεν εἰς πεδίον μέγα καὶ καλόν , ἐπίρρυτον , καὶ δένδρων παντοδαπῶν σύμπλεων καὶ ἀμπέλων ·
perseus-eng2	Thence he descended to a large and beautiful plain, well-watered and full of trees of all sorts and vines.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.2.22
glaux1.0-sentence	123

perseus-eng2	It produces an abundance of sesame, millet, panic, wheat, and barley.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.2.22
glaux1.0-sentence	124
perseus-grc2	ὄρος δ’ αὐτὸ περιεῖχεν ὀχυρὸν καὶ ὑψηλὸν πάντῃ ἐκ θαλάττης εἰς θάλατταν .
perseus-eng2	A lofty and formidable range of mountains surrounds it on every side, from sea to sea.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.2.23
glaux1.0-sentence	125
perseus-grc2	καταβὰς δὲ διὰ τούτου τοῦ πεδίου ἤλασε σταθμοὺς τέτταρας παρασάγγας πέντε καὶ εἴκοσιν εἰς Ταρσούς , τῆς Κιλικίας πόλιν μεγάλην καὶ εὐδαίμονα , οὗ ἦν τὰ Συεννέσιος βασίλεια τοῦ Κιλίκων βασιλέως ·
perseus-eng2	After descending he marched through this plain four stages, twenty-five parasangs, to  Tarsus , a large and prosperous city of  Cilicia , where the palace of Syennesis, the king of the Cilicians, was situated.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.2.23
glaux1.0-sentence	126

perseus-eng2	Through the middle of the city flows a river named the Cydnus, two plethra in width.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.2.24
glaux1.0-sentence	127

perseus-eng2	The inhabitants of this city had abandoned it and fled, with Syennesis, to a stronghold upon the mountains—all of them, at least, except the tavern-keepers.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.2.24

cts:urn:0032-006:1.2.25

perseus-eng2	Now Epyaxa, the wife of Syennesis, had reached  Tarsus  five days ahead of  Cyrus .

cts:urn:0032-006:1.2.25

perseus-eng2	But in the course of her passage over the mountains to the plain two companies of Menon’s army had been lost.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.2.25

perseus-grc2	οἱ μὲν ἔφασαν ἁρπάζοντάς τι κατακοπῆναι ὑπὸ τῶν Κιλίκων , οἱ δὲ ὑπολειφθέντας καὶ οὐ δυναμένους εὑρεῖν τὸ ἄλλο στράτευμα οὐδὲ τὰς ὁδοὺς εἶτα πλανωμένους ἀπολέσθαι ·
perseus-eng2	Some said that they had been cut to pieces by the Cilicians while engaged in a bit of plundering; others that that they had been left behind, and, unable to find the rest of the army or the roads, had thus wandered about and perished;

perseus-grc2	ἦσαν δ’ οὖν οὗτοι ἑκατὸν ὁπλῖται .

glaux1.0-sentence	133

perseus-eng2	And when the rest of Menon’s troops reached  Tarsus , in their anger over the loss of their comrades they plundered thoroughly, not only the city, but also the palace that was in it.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.2.26

perseus-eng2	As for  Cyrus , after he had marched into the city he more than once summoned Syennesis to his presence;

cts:urn:0032-006:1.2.26
glaux1.0-sentence	135
perseus-grc2	ὁ δ’ οὔτε πρότερον οὐδενί πω κρείττονι ἑαυτοῦ εἰς χεῖρας ἐλθεῖν ἔφη οὔτε τότε Κύρῳ ἰέναι ἤθελε , πρὶν ἡ γυνὴ αὐτὸν ἔπεισε καὶ πίστεις ἔλαβε .
perseus-eng2	but Syennesis said that he had never yet put himself in the hands of anyone who was more powerful than he was, and he would not now put himself in the hands of  Cyrus  until his wife had won him over and he had received pledges.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.2.27
glaux1.0-sentence	136
perseus-grc2	μετὰ δὲ ταῦτα ἐπεὶ συνεγένοντο ἀλλήλοις , Συέννεσις μὲν ἔδωκε Κύρῳ χρήματα πολλὰ εἰς τὴν στρατιάν , Κῦρος δὲ ἐκείνῳ δῶρα ἃ νομίζεται παρὰ βασιλεῖ τίμια , ἵππον χρυσοχάλινον καὶ στρεπτὸν χρυσοῦν καὶ ψέλια καὶ ἀκινάκην χρυσοῦν καὶ στολὴν Περσικήν , καὶ τὴν χώραν μηκέτι διαρπάζεσθαι ·
perseus-eng2	And afterwards, when the two men finally met one another, Syennesis gave  Cyrus  a large sum of money for his army, while  Cyrus  gave him gifts which are regarded at court as tokens of honour—a horse with a gold-mounted bridle, a gold necklace and bracelets, a gold dagger and a Persian robe—promising him, further, that his land should not be plundered any more

cts:urn:0032-006:1.2.27
glaux1.0-sentence	137

perseus-eng2	and that they might take back the slaves that had been seized in case they should chance upon them anywhere.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.3.1

cts:urn:0032-006:1.3.2

perseus-eng2	At that time Clearchus narrowly escaped being stoned to death; but afterwards, when he realized that he could not accomplish anything by force, he called a meeting of his own troops.

perseus-eng2	then he spoke as follows:

glaux1.0-sentence	148
perseus-grc2	ἄνδρες στρατιῶται , μὴ θαυμάζετε ὅτι χαλεπῶς φέρω τοῖς παροῦσι πράγμασιν .
perseus-eng2	Fellow-soldiers, do not wonder that I am distressed at the present situation.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.3.3
glaux1.0-sentence	149
perseus-grc2	ἐμοὶ γὰρ ξένος Κῦρος ἐγένετο καί με φεύγοντα ἐκ τῆς πατρίδος τά τε ἄλλα ἐτίμησε καὶ μυρίους ἔδωκε δαρεικούς ·
perseus-eng2	For  Cyrus  became my friend and not only honoured me, an exile from my fatherland, in various ways, but gave me ten thousand darics.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.3.3
glaux1.0-sentence	150
perseus-grc2	οὓς ἐγὼ λαβὼν οὐκ εἰς τὸ ἴδιον κατεθέμην ἐμοὶ οὐδὲ καθηδυπάθησα , ἀλλ’ εἰς ὑμᾶς ἐδαπάνων .
perseus-eng2	And I, receiving this money, did not lay it up for my own personal use or squander it in pleasure, but I proceeded to expend it on you.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.3.4
glaux1.0-sentence	151
perseus-grc2	καὶ πρῶτον μὲν πρὸς τοὺς Θρᾷκας ἐπολέμησα , καὶ ὑπὲρ τῆς Ἑλλάδος ἐτιμωρούμην μεθ’ ὑμῶν , ἐκ τῆς Χερρονήσου αὐτοὺς ἐξελαύνων βουλομένους ἀφαιρεῖσθαι τοὺς ἐνοικοῦντας Ἕλληνας τὴν γῆν .
perseus-eng2	First I went to war with the Thracians, and for the sake of  Greece  I inflicted punishment upon them with your aid, driving them out of the  Chersonese  when they wanted to deprive the Greeks who dwelt there of their land.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.3.4
glaux1.0-sentence	152
perseus-grc2	ἐπειδὴ δὲ Κῦρος ἐκάλει , λαβὼν ὑμᾶς ἐπορευόμην , ἵνα εἴ τι δέοιτο ὠφελοίην αὐτὸν ἀνθ’ ὧν εὖ ἔπαθον ὑπ’ ἐκείνου .
perseus-eng2	Then when  Cyrus  called, I took you with me and set out, in order that, if he had need of me, I might give him aid in return for the benefits I had received from him.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.3.5
glaux1.0-sentence	153
perseus-grc2	ἐπεὶ δὲ ὑμεῖς οὐ βούλεσθε συμπορεύεσθαι , ἀνάγκη δή μοι ἢ ὑμᾶς προδόντα τῇ Κύρου φιλίᾳ χρῆσθαι ἢ πρὸς ἐκεῖνον ψευσάμενον μεθ’ ὑμῶν εἶναι .
perseus-eng2	But you now do not wish to continue the march with me, it seems that I must either desert you and continue to enjoy  Cyrus ’ friendship, or prove false to him and remain with you.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.3.5
glaux1.0-sentence	154
perseus-grc2	εἰ μὲν δὴ δίκαια ποιήσω οὐκ οἶδα , αἱρήσομαι δ’ οὖν ὑμᾶς καὶ σὺν ὑμῖν ὅ τι ἂν δέῃ πείσομαι .
perseus-eng2	Whether I shall be doing what is right, I know not, but at any rate I shall choose you and with you shall suffer whatever I must.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.3.5
glaux1.0-sentence	155
perseus-grc2	καὶ οὔποτε ἐρεῖ οὐδεὶς ὡς ἐγὼ Ἕλληνας ἀγαγὼν εἰς τοὺς βαρβάρους , προδοὺς τοὺς Ἕλληνας τὴν τῶν βαρβάρων φιλίαν εἱλόμην , ἀλλ’ ἐπεὶ ὑμεῖς ἐμοὶ οὐ θέλετε πείθεσθαι , ἐγὼ σὺν ὑμῖν ἕψομαι καὶ ὅ τι ἂν δέῃ πείσομαι .
perseus-eng2	And never shall any man say that I, after leading Greeks into the land of the barbarians, betrayed the Greeks and chose the friendship of the barbarians. Rather, since you do not care to obey me, I shall follow with you and suffer whatever I must.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.3.6
glaux1.0-sentence	156
perseus-grc2	νομίζω γὰρ ὑμᾶς ἐμοὶ εἶναι καὶ πατρίδα καὶ φίλους καὶ συμμάχους , καὶ σὺν ὑμῖν μὲν ἂν οἶμαι εἶναι τίμιος ὅπου ἂν ὦ , ὑμῶν δὲ ἔρημος ὢν οὐκ ἂν ἱκανὸς οἶμαι εἶναι οὔτ’ ἂν φίλον ὠφελῆσαι οὔτ’ ἂν ἐχθρὸν ἀλέξασθαι .
perseus-eng2	For I consider that you are to me both fatherland and friends and allies. With you I think I shall be honoured wherever I may be, bereft of you I do not think I shall be able either to aid a friend or to ward off a foe.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.3.6
glaux1.0-sentence	157
perseus-grc2	ὡς ἐμοῦ οὖν ἰόντος ὅπῃ ἂν καὶ ὑμεῖς οὕτω τὴν γνώμην ἔχετε .
perseus-eng2	Be sure, therefore, that wherever you go, I shall go also.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.3.7
glaux1.0-sentence	158

perseus-eng2	Such were his words.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.3.7
glaux1.0-sentence	159
perseus-grc2	οἱ δὲ στρατιῶται οἵ τε αὐτοῦ ἐκείνου καὶ οἱ ἄλλοι ταῦτα ἀκούσαντες ὅτι οὐ φαίη παρὰ βασιλέα πορεύεσθαι ἐπῄνεσαν ·
perseus-eng2	And the soldiers—not only his own men, but the rest also—when they heard that he said he would not go on to the King’s capital, commended him.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.3.7
glaux1.0-sentence	160
perseus-grc2	παρὰ δὲ Ξενίου καὶ Πασίωνος πλείους ἢ δισχίλιοι λαβόντες τὰ ὅπλα καὶ τὰ σκευοφόρα ἐστρατοπεδεύσαντο παρὰ Κλεάρχῳ .
perseus-eng2	More than two thousand of the troops under Xenias and Pasion took their arms and their baggage train and encamped with Clearchus.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.3.8

perseus-eng2	But  Cyrus , perplexed and distressed by this situation, sent repeatedly for Clearchus.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.3.8
glaux1.0-sentence	162
perseus-grc2	ὁ δὲ ἰέναι μὲν οὐκ ἤθελε , λάθρᾳ δὲ τῶν στρατιωτῶν πέμπων αὐτῷ ἄγγελον ἔλεγε θαρρεῖν ὡς καταστησομένων τούτων εἰς τὸ δέον .
perseus-eng2	Clearchus refused to go to him, but without the knowledge of the soldiers he sent a messenger and told him not to be discouraged, because, he said, this matter would be settled in the right way.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.3.8
glaux1.0-sentence	163
perseus-grc2	μεταπέμπεσθαι δ’ ἐκέλευεν αὐτόν ·
perseus-eng2	He directed  Cyrus , however, to keep on sending for him.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.3.8
glaux1.0-sentence	164
perseus-grc2	αὐτὸς δ’ οὐκ ἔφη ἰέναι .
perseus-eng2	He himself, he said, would refuse to go.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.3.9
glaux1.0-sentence	165
perseus-grc2	μετὰ δὲ ταῦτα συναγαγὼν τούς θ’ ἑαυτοῦ στρατιώτας καὶ τοὺς προσελθόντας αὐτῷ καὶ τῶν ἄλλων τὸν βουλόμενον , ἔλεξε τοιάδε .
perseus-eng2	After this Clearchus gathered together his own soldiers, those who had come over to him, and any others who wanted to be present, and spoke as follows:

cts:urn:0032-006:1.3.9
glaux1.0-sentence	166
perseus-grc2	ἄνδρες στρατιῶται , τὰ μὲν δὴ Κύρου δῆλον ὅτι οὕτως ἔχει πρὸς ἡμᾶς ὥσπερ τὰ ἡμέτερα πρὸς ἐκεῖνον ·
perseus-eng2	Fellow-soldiers, it is clear that the relation of  Cyrus  to us is precisely the same as ours to him;

cts:urn:0032-006:1.3.9
glaux1.0-sentence	167
perseus-grc2	οὔτε γὰρ ἡμεῖς ἐκείνου ἔτι στρατιῶται , ἐπεί γε οὐ συνεπόμεθα αὐτῷ , οὔτε ἐκεῖνος ἔτι ἡμῖν μισθοδότης .
perseus-eng2	that is, we are no longer his soldiers, since we decline to follow him, and likewise he is no longer our paymaster.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.3.10
glaux1.0-sentence	168
perseus-grc2	ὅτι μέντοι ἀδικεῖσθαι νομίζει ὑφ’ ἡμῶν οἶδα ·
perseus-eng2	I know, however, that he considers himself wronged by us.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.3.10
glaux1.0-sentence	169
perseus-grc2	ὥστε καὶ μεταπεμπομένου αὐτοῦ οὐκ ἐθέλω ἐλθεῖν , τὸ μὲν μέγιστον αἰσχυνόμενος ὅτι σύνοιδα ἐμαυτῷ πάντα ἐψευσμένος αὐτόν , ἔπειτα καὶ δεδιὼς μὴ λαβών με δίκην ἐπιθῇ ὧν νομίζει ὑπ’ ἐμοῦ ἠδικῆσθαι .
perseus-eng2	Therefore, although he keeps sending for me, I decline to go, chiefly, it is true, from a feeling of shame, because I am conscious that I have proved utterly false to him, but, besides that, from fear that he may seize me and inflict punishment upon me for the wrongs he thinks he has suffered at my hands.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.3.11
glaux1.0-sentence	170
perseus-grc2	ἐμοὶ οὖν δοκεῖ οὐχ ὥρα εἶναι ἡμῖν καθεύδειν οὐδ’ ἀμελεῖν ἡμῶν αὐτῶν , ἀλλὰ βουλεύεσθαι ὅ τι χρὴ ποιεῖν ἐκ τούτων .
perseus-eng2	In my opinion, therefore, it is no time for us to be sleeping or unconcerned about ourselves, but we should rather be considering what course we ought to follow under the present circumstances.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.3.11
glaux1.0-sentence	171
perseus-grc2	καὶ ἕως γε μένομεν αὐτοῦ σκεπτέον μοι δοκεῖ εἶναι ὅπως ἀσφαλέστατα μενοῦμεν , εἴ τε ἤδη δοκεῖ ἀπιέναι , ὅπως ἀσφαλέστατα ἄπιμεν , καὶ ὅπως τὰ ἐπιτήδεια ἕξομεν ·
perseus-eng2	And so long as we remain here we must consider, I think, how we can remain most safely; or, again, if we count it best to depart at once, how we are to depart most safely and how we shall secure provisions.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.3.11
glaux1.0-sentence	172
perseus-grc2	ἄνευ γὰρ τούτων οὔτε στρατηγοῦ οὔτε ἰδιώτου ὄφελος οὐδέν .
perseus-eng2	For without provisions neither general nor private is of any use.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.3.12
glaux1.0-sentence	173
perseus-grc2	ὁ δ’ ἀνὴρ πολλοῦ μὲν ἄξιος ᾧ ἂν φίλος ᾖ , χαλεπώτατος δ’ ἐχθρὸς ᾧ ἂν πολέμιος ᾖ , ἔχει δὲ δύναμιν καὶ πεζὴν καὶ ἱππικὴν καὶ ναυτικὴν ἣν πάντες ὁμοίως ὁρῶμέν τε καὶ ἐπιστάμεθα ·
perseus-eng2	And remember that while this  Cyrus  is a valuable friend when he is your friend, he is a most dangerous foe when he is your enemy; urthermore, he has an armament—infantry and cavalry and fleet—which we all alike see and know about;

cts:urn:0032-006:1.3.12
glaux1.0-sentence	174
perseus-grc2	καὶ γὰρ οὐδὲ πόρρω δοκοῦμέν μοι αὐτοῦ καθῆσθαι .
perseus-eng2	for I take it that our camp is not very far away from him.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.3.12
glaux1.0-sentence	175
perseus-grc2	ὥστε ὥρα λέγειν ὅ τι τις γιγνώσκει ἄριστον εἶναι .
perseus-eng2	It is time, then, to propose whatever plan any one of you deems best.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.3.12
glaux1.0-sentence	176
perseus-grc2	ταῦτα εἰπὼν ἐπαύσατο .
perseus-eng2	With these words he ceased speaking.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.3.13
glaux1.0-sentence	177
perseus-grc2	ἐκ δὲ τούτου ἀνίσταντο οἱ μὲν ἐκ τοῦ αὐτομάτου , λέξοντες ἃ ἐγίγνωσκον , οἱ δὲ καὶ ὑπ’ ἐκείνου ἐγκέλευστοι , ἐπιδεικνύντες οἵα εἴη ἡ ἀπορία ἄνευ τῆς Κύρου γνώμης καὶ μένειν καὶ ἀπιέναι .
perseus-eng2	Thereupon various speakers arose, some of their own accord to express the opinions they held, but others at the instigation of Clearchus to make clear the difficulty of either remaining or departing without the consent of  Cyrus .

cts:urn:0032-006:1.3.14
glaux1.0-sentence	178
perseus-grc2	εἷς δὲ δὴ εἶπε προσποιούμενος σπεύδειν ὡς τάχιστα πορεύεσθαι εἰς τὴν Ἑλλάδα στρατηγοὺς μὲν ἑλέσθαι ἄλλους ὡς τάχιστα , εἰ μὴ βούλεται Κλέαρχος ἀπάγειν ·
perseus-eng2	One man in particular, pretending to be in a hurry to proceed back to  Greece  with all speed, proposed that they should choose other generals as quickly as possible, in case Clearchus did not wish to lead them back;

cts:urn:0032-006:1.3.14
glaux1.0-sentence	179
perseus-grc2	τὰ δ’ ἐπιτήδει’ ἀγοράζεσθαι ( ἡ δ’ ἀγορὰ ἦν ἐν τῷ βαρβαρικῷ στρατεύματι ) καὶ συσκευάζεσθαι ·
perseus-eng2	secondly, that they should buy provisions—the market was in the barbarian army!—and pack up their baggage;

cts:urn:0032-006:1.3.14
glaux1.0-sentence	180
perseus-grc2	ἐλθόντας δὲ Κῦρον αἰτεῖν πλοῖα , ὡς ἀποπλέοιεν ·
perseus-eng2	then, to go to  Cyrus  and ask for vessels to sail away in;

cts:urn:0032-006:1.3.14
glaux1.0-sentence	181
perseus-grc2	ἐὰν δὲ μὴ διδῷ ταῦτα , ἡγεμόνα αἰτεῖν Κῦρον ὅστις διὰ φιλίας τῆς χώρας ἀπάξει .
perseus-eng2	and if he would not give them vessels, to ask him for a guide to lead them homeward through a country that was friendly;

cts:urn:0032-006:1.3.14
glaux1.0-sentence	182
perseus-grc2	ἐὰν δὲ μηδὲ ἡγεμόνα διδῷ , συντάττεσθαι τὴν ταχίστην , πέμψαι δὲ καὶ προκαταληψομένους τὰ ἄκρα , ὅπως μὴ φθάσωσι μήτε Κῦρος μήτε οἱ Κίλικες καταλαβόντες , ὧν πολλοὺς καὶ πολλὰ χρήματα ἔχομεν ἀνηρπακότες .
perseus-eng2	and if he would not give them a guide, either, to form in line of battle with all speed and likewise to send a force to occupy the mountain heights in advance, in order that neither  Cyrus  nor the Cilicians should forestall them, many of whom Cilicians and much of their property we have seized as plunder.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.3.14
glaux1.0-sentence	183
perseus-grc2	οὗτος μὲν τοιαῦτα εἶπε ·
perseus-eng2	Such were the words of this speaker.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.3.14
glaux1.0-sentence	184
perseus-grc2	μετὰ δὲ τοῦτον Κλέαρχος εἶπε τοσοῦτον .
perseus-eng2	After him Clearchus said merely this:

cts:urn:0032-006:1.3.15
glaux1.0-sentence	185
perseus-grc2	ὡς μὲν στρατηγήσοντα ἐμὲ ταύτην τὴν στρατηγίαν μηδεὶς ὑμῶν λεγέτω ·
perseus-eng2	Let no one among you speak of me as the man who is to hold this command.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.3.15
glaux1.0-sentence	186
perseus-grc2	πολλὰ γὰρ ἐνορῶ δι’ ἃ ἐμοὶ τοῦτο οὐ ποιητέον ·
perseus-eng2	For I see many reasons why I should not do so;

cts:urn:0032-006:1.3.15
glaux1.0-sentence	187
perseus-grc2	ὡς δὲ τῷ ἀνδρὶ ὃν ἂν ἕλησθε πείσομαι ᾗ δυνατὸν μάλιστα , ἵνα εἰδῆτε ὅτι καὶ ἄρχεσθαι ἐπίσταμαι ὥς τις καὶ ἄλλος μάλιστα ἀνθρώπων .
perseus-eng2	say rather that I shall obey to the best of my ability the man whom you choose, in order that you may know that I understand as well as any other person in the world how to be a subordinate also.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.3.16
glaux1.0-sentence	188
perseus-grc2	μετὰ τοῦτον ἄλλος ἀνέστη , ἐπιδεικνὺς μὲν τὴν εὐήθειαν τοῦ τὰ πλοῖα αἰτεῖν κελεύοντος , ὥσπερ πάλιν τὸν στόλον Κύρου ποιουμένου , ἐπιδεικνὺς δὲ ὡς εὔηθες εἴη ἡγεμόνα αἰτεῖν παρὰ τούτου ᾧ λυμαινόμεθα τὴν πρᾶξιν .
perseus-eng2	After he had spoken another man arose to point out the foolishness of the speaker who had urged them to ask for vessels, just as if  Cyrus  were going home again, and to point out also how foolish it was to ask for a guide from this man whose enterprise we are ruining.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.3.16
glaux1.0-sentence	189
perseus-grc2	εἰ δὲ καὶ τῷ ἡγεμόνι πιστεύσομεν ὃν ἂν Κῦρος διδῷ , τί κωλύει καὶ τὰ ἄκρα ἡμῖν κελεύειν Κῦρον προκαταλαβεῖν ;
perseus-eng2	Indeed, if we propose to trust the guide that  Cyrus  gives us, what is to hinder us from directing  Cyrus  also to occupy the heights for us in advance?

cts:urn:0032-006:1.3.17
glaux1.0-sentence	190
perseus-grc2	ἐγὼ γὰρ ὀκνοίην μὲν ἂν εἰς τὰ πλοῖα ἐμβαίνειν ἃ ἡμῖν δοίη , μὴ ἡμᾶς ταῖς τριήρεσι καταδύσῃ , φοβοίμην δ’ ἂν τῷ ἡγεμόνι ὃν δοίη ἕπεσθαι , μὴ ἡμᾶς ἀγάγῃ ὅθεν οὐκ ἔσται ἐξελθεῖν ·
perseus-eng2	For my part, I should hesitate to embark on the vessels that he might give us, for fear of his sinking us with his war-ships, and I should be afraid to follow the guide that he might give, for fear of his leading us to a place from which it will not be possible to escape;

cts:urn:0032-006:1.3.17
glaux1.0-sentence	191
perseus-grc2	βουλοίμην δ’ ἂν ἄκοντος ἀπιὼν Κύρου λαθεῖν αὐτὸν ἀπελθών ·
perseus-eng2	my choice would be, in going off without  Cyrus ’ consent, to go off without his knowledge.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.3.17
glaux1.0-sentence	192
perseus-grc2	ὃ οὐ δυνατόν ἐστιν .
perseus-eng2	And that is not possible.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.3.18
glaux1.0-sentence	193
perseus-grc2	ἀλλ’ ἐγώ φημι ταῦτα μὲν φλυαρίας εἶναι ·
perseus-eng2	Now in my own opinion the plans just proposed are nonsense;

cts:urn:0032-006:1.3.18
glaux1.0-sentence	194
perseus-grc2	δοκεῖ δέ μοι ἄνδρας ἐλθόντας πρὸς Κῦρον οἵτινες ἐπιτήδειοι σὺν Κλεάρχῳ ἐρωτᾶν ἐκεῖνον τί βούλεται ἡμῖν χρῆσθαι ·
perseus-eng2	rather, I think we should send to  Cyrus  men of the proper sort, along with Clearchus, to ask him what use he wishes to make of us;

cts:urn:0032-006:1.3.18
glaux1.0-sentence	195
perseus-grc2	καὶ ἐὰν μὲν ἡ πρᾶξις ᾖ παραπλησία οἵᾳπερ καὶ πρόσθεν ἐχρῆτο τοῖς ξένοις , ἕπεσθαι καὶ ἡμᾶς καὶ μὴ κακίους εἶναι τῶν πρόσθεν τούτῳ συναναβάντων ·
perseus-eng2	and if his enterprise is like the sort of one in which he employed mercenaries before, I think that we also should follow him and not be more cowardly than those who went up with him on the former occasion.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.3.19
glaux1.0-sentence	196
perseus-grc2	ἐὰν δὲ μείζων ἡ πρᾶξις τῆς πρόσθεν φαίνηται καὶ ἐπιπονωτέρα καὶ ἐπικινδυνοτέρα , ἀξιοῦν ἢ πείσαντα ἡμᾶς ἄγειν ἢ πεισθέντα πρὸς φιλίαν ἀφιέναι ·
perseus-eng2	If, however, his enterprise is found to be greater and more laborious and more dangerous than the former one, we ought to demand that he should either offer sufficient persuasion and lead us on with him, or yield to our persuasion and let us go home in friendship;

cts:urn:0032-006:1.3.19
glaux1.0-sentence	197
perseus-grc2	οὕτω γὰρ καὶ ἑπόμενοι ἂν φίλοι αὐτῷ καὶ πρόθυμοι ἑποίμεθα καὶ ἀπιόντες ἀσφαλῶς ἂν ἀπίοιμεν ·
perseus-eng2	for in this way, if we should follow him, we should follow as friends and zealous supporters, and if we should go back, we should go back in safety.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.3.19
glaux1.0-sentence	198
perseus-grc2	ὅ τι δ’ ἂν πρὸς ταῦτα λέγῃ ἀπαγγεῖλαι δεῦρο ·

cts:urn:0032-006:1.3.19

cts:urn:0032-006:1.3.20
glaux1.0-sentence	200

perseus-eng2	This plan was adopted, and they chose representatives and sent them with Clearchus; and they proceeded to put to  Cyrus  the questions resolved upon by the army.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.3.20
glaux1.0-sentence	201
perseus-grc2	ὁ δ’ ἀπεκρίνατο ὅτι ἀκούει Ἀβροκόμαν ἐχθρὸν ἄνδρα ἐπὶ τῷ Εὐφράτῃ ποταμῷ εἶναι , ἀπέχοντα δώδεκα σταθμούς ·
perseus-eng2	He replied that he had heard that Abrocomas, a foe of his, was at the Euphrates river, twelve stages distant.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.3.20

cts:urn:0032-006:1.3.20

perseus-eng2	And if he were there, he wished to inflict due punishment upon him; but if he has fled, "we will deliberate about the matter then and there."

cts:urn:0032-006:1.3.21

perseus-eng2	They, while suspecting that  Cyrus  was leading them against the King, nevertheless thought it best to follow him.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.3.21

cts:urn:0032-006:1.3.21

cts:urn:0032-006:1.4.1

perseus-grc2	ἐντεῦθεν ἐξελαύνει σταθμοὺς δύο παρασάγγας δέκα ἐπὶ τὸν Ψάρον ποταμόν , οὗ ἦν τὸ εὖρος τρία πλέθρα .

perseus-eng2	From there he marched one stage, five parasangs, to the Pyramus river, the width of which was a stadium.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.4.1
glaux1.0-sentence	211
perseus-grc2	ἐντεῦθεν ἐξελαύνει σταθμοὺς δύο παρασάγγας πεντεκαίδεκα εἰς Ἰσσούς , τῆς Κιλικίας ἐσχάτην πόλιν ἐπὶ τῇ θαλάττῃ οἰκουμένην , μεγάλην καὶ εὐδαίμονα .
perseus-eng2	From there he marched two stages, fifteen parasangs, to  Issus , the last city in  Cilicia , a place situated on the sea, and large and prosperous.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.4.2
glaux1.0-sentence	212
perseus-grc2	ἐνταῦθα ἔμειναν ἡμέρας τρεῖς ·
perseus-eng2	There they remained three days;

cts:urn:0032-006:1.4.2
glaux1.0-sentence	213
perseus-grc2	καὶ Κύρῳ παρῆσαν αἱ ἐκ Πελοποννήσου νῆες τριάκοντα καὶ πέντε καὶ ἐπ’ αὐταῖς ναύαρχος Πυθαγόρας Λακεδαιμόνιος .
perseus-eng2	and the ships from  Peloponnesus arrived to meet  Cyrus , thirty-five in number, with Pythagoras the Lacedaemonian as admiral in command of them.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.4.2
glaux1.0-sentence	214
perseus-grc2	ἡγεῖτο δ’ αὐταῖς Ταμὼς Αἰγύπτιος ἐξ Ἐφέσου , ἔχων ναῦς ἑτέρας Κύρου πέντε καὶ εἴκοσιν , αἷς ἐπολιόρκει Μίλητον , ὅτε Τισσαφέρνει φίλη ἦν , καὶ συνεπολέμει Κύρῳ πρὸς αὐτόν .
perseus-eng2	They had been guided from  Ephesus  to  Issus  by Tamos the Egyptian, who was at the head of another fleet of twenty-five ships belonging to  Cyrus —these latter being the ships with which Tamos had besieged  Miletus , at the time when it was friendly to Tissaphernes, and had supported  Cyrus  in his war upon Tissaphernes.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.4.3
glaux1.0-sentence	215
perseus-grc2	παρῆν δὲ καὶ Χειρίσοφος Λακεδαιμόνιος ἐπὶ τῶν νεῶν , μετάπεμπτος ὑπὸ Κύρου , ἑπτακοσίους ἔχων ὁπλίτας , ὧν ἐστρατήγει παρὰ Κύρῳ .
perseus-eng2	Cheirisophus the Lacedaemonian also arrived with this fleet, coming in response to  Cyrus ’ summons, together with seven hundred hoplites, over whom he continued to hold command in the army of  Cyrus .

cts:urn:0032-006:1.4.3
glaux1.0-sentence	216
perseus-grc2	αἱ δὲ νῆες ὥρμουν παρὰ τὴν Κύρου σκηνήν .
perseus-eng2	And the ships lay at anchor alongside  Cyrus ’ tent.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.4.3
glaux1.0-sentence	217
perseus-grc2	ἐνταῦθα καὶ οἱ παρὰ Ἀβροκόμα μισθοφόροι Ἕλληνες ἀποστάντες ἦλθον παρὰ Κῦρον τετρακόσιοι ὁπλῖται καὶ συνεστρατεύοντο ἐπὶ βασιλέα .
perseus-eng2	It was at  Issus  also that the Greek mercenaries who had been in the service of Abrocomas—four hundred hoplites—joined  Cyrus , after deserting Abrocomas, and so bore a share in his expedition against the King.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.4.4
glaux1.0-sentence	218
perseus-grc2	ἐντεῦθεν ἐξελαύνει σταθμὸν ἕνα παρασάγγας πέντε ἐπὶ πύλας τῆς Κιλικίας καὶ τῆς Συρίας .
perseus-eng2	Thence he marched one stage, five parasangs, to the Gates between  Cilicia  and  Syria .

cts:urn:0032-006:1.4.4
glaux1.0-sentence	219
perseus-grc2	ἦσαν δὲ ταῦτα δύο τείχη , καὶ τὸ μὲν ἔσωθεν τὸ πρὸ τῆς Κιλικίας Συέννεσις εἶχε καὶ Κιλίκων φυλακή , τὸ δὲ ἔξω τὸ πρὸ τῆς Συρίας βασιλέως ἐλέγετο φυλακὴ φυλάττειν .
perseus-eng2	These Gates consisted of two walls; the one on the hither, or Cilician, side was held by Syennesis and a garrison of Cilicians, while the one on the farther, the Syrian, side was reported to be guarded by a garrison of the King’s troops.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.4.4
glaux1.0-sentence	220
perseus-grc2	διὰ μέσου δὲ ῥεῖ τούτων ποταμὸς Κάρσος ὄνομα , εὖρος πλέθρου .
perseus-eng2	And in the space between these walls flows a river named the Carsus, a plethrum in width.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.4.4
glaux1.0-sentence	221
perseus-grc2	ἅπαν δὲ τὸ μέσον τῶν τειχῶν ἦσαν στάδιοι τρεῖς ·
perseus-eng2	The entire distance from one wall to the other was three stadia;

cts:urn:0032-006:1.4.4
glaux1.0-sentence	222
perseus-grc2	καὶ παρελθεῖν οὐκ ἦν βίᾳ ·
perseus-eng2	and it was not possible to effect a passage by force.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.4.4
glaux1.0-sentence	223
perseus-grc2	ἦν γὰρ ἡ πάροδος στενὴ καὶ τὰ τείχη εἰς τὴν θάλατταν καθήκοντα , ὕπερθεν δ’ ἦσαν πέτραι ἠλίβατοι ·
perseus-eng2	or the pass was narrow, the walls reached down to the sea, and above the pass were precipitous rocks.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.4.4
glaux1.0-sentence	224
perseus-grc2	ἐπὶ δὲ τοῖς τείχεσιν ἀμφοτέροις ἐφειστήκεσαν πύλαι .
perseus-eng2	Besides, there were towers upon both the walls.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.4.5
glaux1.0-sentence	225
perseus-grc2	ταύτης ἕνεκα τῆς παρόδου Κῦρος τὰς ναῦς μετεπέμψατο , ὅπως ὁπλίτας ἀποβιβάσειεν εἴσω καὶ ἔξω τῶν πυλῶν , καὶ βιασόμενος τοὺς πολεμίους εἰ φυλάττοιεν ἐπὶ ταῖς Συρίαις πύλαις , ὅπερ ᾤετο ποιήσειν ὁ Κῦρος τὸν Ἀβροκόμαν , ἔχοντα πολὺ στράτευμα .
perseus-eng2	It was because of this pass that  Cyrus  had sent for the fleet, in order that he might disembark hoplites between and beyond the walls and thus overpower the enemy if they should be keeping guard at the Syrian Gates—and that was precisely what  Cyrus  supposed Abrocomas would do, for he had a large army.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.4.5
glaux1.0-sentence	226
perseus-grc2	Ἀβροκόμας δὲ οὐ τοῦτ’ ἐποίησεν , ἀλλ’ ἐπεὶ ἤκουσε Κῦρον ἐν Κιλικίᾳ ὄντα , ἀναστρέψας ἐκ Φοινίκης παρὰ βασιλέα ἀπήλαυνεν , ἔχων , ὡς ἐλέγετο , τριάκοντα μυριάδας στρατιᾶς .
perseus-eng2	Abrocomas, however, did not do so, but as soon as he heard that  Cyrus  was in  Cilicia , he turned about in his journey from  Phoenicia and marched off to join the King, with an army, so the report ran, of three hundred thousand men.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.4.6
glaux1.0-sentence	227
perseus-grc2	ἐντεῦθεν ἐξελαύνει διὰ Συρίας σταθμὸν ἕνα παρασάγγας πέντε εἰς Μυρίανδον , πόλιν οἰκουμένην ὑπὸ Φοινίκων ἐπὶ τῇ θαλάττῃ ·
perseus-eng2	Thence  Cyrus  marched one stage, five parasangs, to Myriandus, a city on the sea coast, inhabited by Phoenicians;

cts:urn:0032-006:1.4.6
glaux1.0-sentence	228
perseus-grc2	ἐμπόριον δ’ ἦν τὸ χωρίον καὶ ὥρμουν αὐτόθι ὁλκάδες πολλαί .
perseus-eng2	it was a trading place, and many merchant ships were lying at anchor there.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.4.6
glaux1.0-sentence	229
perseus-grc2	ἐνταῦθ’ ἔμεινεν ἡμέρας ἑπτά ·
perseus-eng2	There he remained seven days;

cts:urn:0032-006:1.4.7
glaux1.0-sentence	230
perseus-grc2	καὶ Ξενίας ὁ Ἀρκὰς στρατηγὸς καὶ Πασίων ὁ Μεγαρεὺς ἐμβάντες εἰς πλοῖον καὶ τὰ πλείστου ἄξια ἐνθέμενοι ἀπέπλευσαν , ὡς μὲν τοῖς πλείστοις ἐδόκουν φιλοτιμηθέντες ὅτι τοὺς στρατιώτας αὐτῶν τοὺς παρὰ Κλέαρχον ἀπελθόντας ὡς ἀπιόντας εἰς τὴν Ἑλλάδα πάλιν καὶ οὐ πρὸς βασιλέα εἴα Κῦρος τὸν Κλέαρχον ἔχειν .
perseus-eng2	and Xenias the Arcadian and Pasion the Megarian embarked upon a ship, put on board their most valuable effects, and sailed away; they were moved to do this, as most people thought, by a feeling of jealous pride, because their soldiers had gone over to Clearchus with the intention of going back to  Greece  again instead of proceeding against the King, and  Cyrus  had allowed Clearchus to keep them.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.4.7
glaux1.0-sentence	231

perseus-eng2	After they had disappeared, a report went round that  Cyrus  was pursuing them with warships;

cts:urn:0032-006:1.4.7
glaux1.0-sentence	232
perseus-grc2	καὶ οἱ μὲν ηὔχοντο ὡς δειλοὺς ὄντας αὐτοὺς ληφθῆναι , οἱ δ’ ᾤκτιρον εἰ ἁλώσοιντο .
perseus-eng2	and while some people prayed that they might be captured, because, as they said, they were cowards, yet others felt pity for them if they should be caught.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.4.8
glaux1.0-sentence	239

perseus-eng2	But for my part, I swear by the gods that I shall not pursue them, nor shall anyone say about me that I use a man so long as he is with me and then, when he wants to leave me, seize him and maltreat him and despoil him of his possessions.

perseus-eng2	No, let them go, with the knowledge that their behaviour toward us is worse than ours toward them.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.4.8

perseus-eng2	After this  Cyrus  marched four stages, twenty parasangs, to the Chalus river, which is a plethrum in width and full of large, tame fish; these fish the Syrians regarded as gods, and they would not allow anyone to harm them, or the doves, either.

perseus-eng2	and the soldiers were angry with the generals, and said that they had known about this for a long time, but had been keeping it from the troops; furthermore, they refused to go on unless they were given money, when he went to visit his father; they had received the donation, even though they marched, not to battle, but merely because  Cyrus ’ father summoned him.

perseus-eng2	For if they vote to follow him, it is you who will get the credit for that decision because you began the crossing, and  Cyrus  will not only feel grateful to you, regarding you as the most zealous in his cause, but he will return the favour—-

cts:urn:0032-006:1.5.3

cts:urn:0032-006:1.5.3
glaux1.0-sentence	294

perseus-eng2	for it would distance him at once in its flight, not merely plying its feet, but hoisting its wings and using them like a sail.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.5.3

cts:urn:0032-006:1.5.5
glaux1.0-sentence	302

cts:urn:0032-006:1.5.5

cts:urn:0032-006:1.5.5

cts:urn:0032-006:1.5.5

perseus-eng2	and the people who dwelt here made a living by quarrying mill-stones along the river banks, then fashioning them and taking them to  Babylon , where they sold them and bought grain in exchange.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.5.6
glaux1.0-sentence	306
perseus-grc2	τὸ δὲ στράτευμα ὁ σῖτος ἐπέλιπε , καὶ πρίασθαι οὐκ ἦν εἰ μὴ ἐν τῇ Λυδίᾳ ἀγορᾷ ἐν τῷ Κύρου βαρβαρικῷ , τὴν καπίθην ἀλεύρων ἢ ἀλφίτων τεττάρων σίγλων .
perseus-eng2	As for the troops, their supply of grain gave out, and it was not possible to buy any except in the Lydian at the price of four sigli for a capith of wheat flour or barley meal.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.5.6

cts:urn:0032-006:1.5.6

perseus-eng2	The soldiers therefore managed to subsist by eating meat.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.5.7

cts:urn:0032-006:1.5.7

perseus-grc2	καὶ δή ποτε στενοχωρίας καὶ πηλοῦ φανέντος ταῖς ἁμάξαις δυσπορεύτου ἐπέστη ὁ Κῦρος σὺν τοῖς περὶ αὐτὸν ἀρίστοις καὶ εὐδαιμονεστάτοις καὶ ἔταξε Γλοῦν καὶ Πίγρητα λαβόντας τοῦ βαρβαρικοῦ στρατοῦ συνεκβιβάζειν τὰς ἁμάξας .
perseus-eng2	Once in particular, when they came upon a narrow, muddy place which was hard for the wagons to get through,  Cyrus  halted with his train of nobles and dignitaries and ordered Glus and Pigres to take some of the barbarian troops and help to pull the wagons out.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.5.8
glaux1.0-sentence	312
perseus-grc2	ἐπεὶ δ’ ἐδόκουν αὐτῷ σχολαίως ποιεῖν , ὥσπερ ὀργῇ ἐκέλευσε τοὺς περὶ αὐτὸν Πέρσας τοὺς κρατίστους συνεπισπεῦσαι τὰς ἁμάξας .
perseus-eng2	But it seemed to him that they took their time with the work; accordingly, as if in anger, he directed the Persian nobles who accompanied him to take a hand in hurrying on the wagons.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.5.8

perseus-eng2	And then one might have beheld a sample of good discipline:

cts:urn:0032-006:1.5.8
glaux1.0-sentence	314
perseus-grc2	ῥίψαντες γὰρ τοὺς πορφυροῦς κάνδυς ὅπου ἔτυχεν ἕκαστος ἑστηκώς , ἵεντο ὥσπερ ἂν δράμοι τις ἐπὶ νίκῃ καὶ μάλα κατὰ πρανοῦς γηλόφου , ἔχοντες τούτους τε τοὺς πολυτελεῖς χιτῶνας καὶ τὰς ποικίλας ἀναξυρίδας , ἔνιοι δὲ καὶ στρεπτοὺς περὶ τοῖς τραχήλοις καὶ ψέλια περὶ ταῖς χερσίν ·
perseus-eng2	they each threw off their purple cloaks where they chanced to be standing, and rushed, as a man would run to win a victory, down a most exceedingly steep hill, wearing their costly tunics and coloured trousers, some of them, indeed, with necklaces around their necks and bracelets on their arms;

cts:urn:0032-006:1.5.8
glaux1.0-sentence	315
perseus-grc2	εὐθὺς δὲ σὺν τούτοις εἰσπηδήσαντες εἰς τὸν πηλὸν θᾶττον ἢ ὥς τις ἂν ᾤετο μετεώρους ἐξεκόμισαν τὰς ἁμάξας .
perseus-eng2	and leaping at once, with all this finery, into the mud, they lifted the wagons high and dry and brought them out more quickly than one would have thought possible.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.5.9
glaux1.0-sentence	316
perseus-grc2	τὸ δὲ σύμπαν δῆλος ἦν Κῦρος ὡς σπεύδων πᾶσαν τὴν ὁδὸν καὶ οὐ διατρίβων ὅπου μὴ ἐπισιτισμοῦ ἕνεκα ἤ τινος ἄλλου ἀναγκαίου ἐκαθέζετο , νομίζων , ὅσῳ θᾶττον ἔλθοι , τοσούτῳ ἀπαρασκευαστοτέρῳ βασιλεῖ μαχεῖσθαι , ὅσῳ δὲ σχολαίτερον , τοσούτῳ πλέον συναγείρεσθαι βασιλεῖ στράτευμα .
perseus-eng2	In general, it was clear that  Cyrus  was in haste throughout the whole journey and was making no delays, except where he halted to procure provisions or for some other necessary purpose; his thought was that the faster he went, the more unprepared the King would be to fight with him, while, on the other hand, the slower he went, the greater would be the army that was gathering for the King.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.5.9
glaux1.0-sentence	317
perseus-grc2	καὶ συνιδεῖν δ’ ἦν τῷ προσέχοντι τὸν νοῦν τῇ βασιλέως ἀρχῇ πλήθει μὲν χώρας καὶ ἀνθρώπων ἰσχυρὰ οὖσα , τοῖς δὲ μήκεσι τῶν ὁδῶν καὶ τῷ διεσπάσθαι τὰς δυνάμεις ἀσθενής , εἴ τις διὰ ταχέων τὸν πόλεμον ποιοῖτο .
perseus-eng2	Furthermore, one who observed closely could see at a glance that while the King’s empire was strong in its extent of territory and number of inhabitants, it was weak by reason of the greatness of the distances and the scattered condition of its forces, in case one should be swift in making his attack upon it.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.5.10

cts:urn:0032-006:1.5.14

perseus-eng2	But Proxenus–for he chanced to be now coming up, later than the others, with a battalion of hoplites following him–straightway led his troops into the space between the two parties, halted them under arms, and began to beg Clearchus not to proceed with his attack.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.5.14
glaux1.0-sentence	335
perseus-grc2	ὁ δ’ ἐχαλέπαινεν ὅτι αὐτοῦ ὀλίγου δεήσαντος καταλευσθῆναι πράως λέγοι τὸ αὑτοῦ πάθος , ἐκέλευσέ τε αὐτὸν ἐκ τοῦ μέσου ἐξίστασθαι .
perseus-eng2	Clearchus, however, was angry, because, when he had barely escaped being stoned to death, Proxenus was talking lightly of his grievance, and he ordered him to remove himself from between them.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.5.15

perseus-eng2	He immediately took his spears in his hands and, attended by such of his counsellors as were present, came riding into the intervening space and spoke as follows:

cts:urn:0032-006:1.5.16

perseus-eng2	Clearchus, and Proxenus, and all you other Greeks who are here, you know not what you are doing.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.5.16

perseus-eng2	For as certainly as you come to fighting with one another, you may be sure that on this very day I shall be instantly cut to pieces and yourselves not long after me;

cts:urn:0032-006:1.5.16

perseus-eng2	for once let ill fortune overtake us, and all these barbarians whom you see will be more hostile to us than are those who stand with the King.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.5.17

perseus-eng2	As they went on from there, they kept seeing tracks of horses and horses’ dung.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.6.1

cts:urn:0032-006:1.6.1

perseus-eng2	The horsemen as they proceeded were burning up fodder and everything else that was of any use.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.6.1
glaux1.0-sentence	346
perseus-grc2	Ὀρόντας δέ , Πέρσης ἀνήρ , γένει τε προσήκων βασιλεῖ καὶ τὰ πολέμια λεγόμενος ἐν τοῖς ἀρίστοις Περσῶν ἐπιβουλεύει Κύρῳ καὶ πρόσθεν πολεμήσας , καταλλαγεὶς δέ .
perseus-eng2	At this time Orontas, a Persian, who was related to the King by birth and was reckoned among the best of the Persians in matters of war, devised a plot against  Cyrus —in fact, he had made war upon him before this, but had become his friend again.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.6.2
glaux1.0-sentence	347
perseus-grc2	οὗτος Κύρῳ εἶπεν , εἰ αὐτῷ δοίη ἱππέας χιλίους , ὅτι τοὺς προκατακαίοντας ἱππέας ἢ κατακαίνοι ἂν ἐνεδρεύσας ἢ ζῶντας πολλοὺς αὐτῶν ἂν ἕλοι καὶ κωλύσειε τοῦ καίειν ἐπιόντας , καὶ ποιήσειεν ὥστε μήποτε δύνασθαι αὐτοὺς ἰδόντας τὸ Κύρου στράτευμα βασιλεῖ διαγγεῖλαι .
perseus-eng2	He now said to  Cyrus  that if he would give him a thousand horsemen, he would either ambush and kill these horsemen who were burning ahead of him, or he would capture many of them alive and put a stop to their burning as they advanced; and he would see to it that they should never be able to behold  Cyrus ’ army and get to the King with their report.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.6.2
glaux1.0-sentence	348
perseus-grc2	τῷ δὲ Κύρῳ ἀκούσαντι ταῦτα ἐδόκει ὠφέλιμα εἶναι , καὶ ἐκέλευεν αὐτὸν λαμβάνειν μέρος παρ’ ἑκάστου τῶν ἡγεμόνων .
perseus-eng2	When  Cyrus  heard this plan, it seemed to him to be an expedient one, and he directed Orontas to get a detachment from each one of the cavalry commanders.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.6.3

perseus-eng2	Then Orontas, thinking that his horsemen were assured him, wrote a letter to the King saying that he would come to him with as many horsemen as he could get.

perseus-eng2	My friends, I have invited you here in order that I may consult with you and then take such action in the case of Orontas here as is right in the sight of gods and men.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.6.6

cts:urn:0032-006:1.6.6
glaux1.0-sentence	362

perseus-eng2	then, at the bidding, as he himself said, of my brother, this man levied war upon me, holding the citadel of  Sardis , and I, by the war I waged against him, made him count it best to cease from warring upon me, and I received and gave the hand-clasp of friendship. Since that," he said, "Orontas, have I done you any wrong?

cts:urn:0032-006:1.6.7

perseus-grc2	ἀπεκρίνατο ὅτι οὔ .

cts:urn:0032-006:1.6.7

perseus-eng2	Did you not,"  Cyrus  said, "when once more you had learned the slightness of your own power, go to the altar of Artemis and say you were sorry, and did you not, after prevailing upon me to pardon you, again give me pledges and receive pledges from me?

perseus-eng2	My advice is to put this man out of the way as speedily as possible, so that we may no longer have to be on our guard against the fellow, but may be left free, so far as concerns him, to requite with benefits these willing servants.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.7.3
glaux1.0-sentence	394
perseus-grc2	ὦ ἄνδρες Ἕλληνες , οὐκ ἀνθρώπων ἀπορῶν βαρβάρων συμμάχους ὑμᾶς ἄγω , ἀλλὰ νομίζων ἀμείνονας καὶ κρείττους πολλῶν βαρβάρων ὑμᾶς εἶναι , διὰ τοῦτο προσέλαβον .
perseus-eng2	Men of  Greece , it is not because I have not barbarians enough that I have brought you hither to fight for me; but because I believe that you are braver and stronger than many barbarians, for this reason I took you also.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.7.3
glaux1.0-sentence	395

perseus-eng2	Be sure, therefore, to be men worthy of the freedom you possess, upon the possession of which I congratulate you.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.7.3
glaux1.0-sentence	396
perseus-grc2	εὖ γὰρ ἴστε ὅτι τὴν ἐλευθερίαν ἑλοίμην ἂν ἀντὶ ὧν ἔχω πάντων καὶ ἄλλων πολλαπλασίων .
perseus-eng2	For you may be certain that freedom is the thing I should choose in preference to all that I have and many times more.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.7.4

perseus-eng2	And now, in order that you may know what sort of a contest it is into which you are going, I who do know will tell you.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.7.4

perseus-eng2	Our enemies have great numbers and they will come on with a great outcry;

cts:urn:0032-006:1.7.4
glaux1.0-sentence	399
perseus-grc2	ἂν δὲ ταῦτα ἀνάσχησθε , τὰ ἄλλα καὶ αἰσχύνεσθαί μοι δοκῶ οἵους ἡμῖν γνώσεσθε τοὺς ἐν τῇ χώρᾳ ὄντας ἀνθρώπους .
perseus-eng2	for the rest, however, if you can hold out against these things, I am ashamed, I assure you, to think what sorry fellows you will find the people of our country to be.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.7.4
glaux1.0-sentence	400
perseus-grc2	ὑμῶν δὲ ἀνδρῶν ὄντων καὶ εὖ τῶν ἐμῶν γενομένων , ἐγὼ ὑμῶν τὸν μὲν οἴκαδε βουλόμενον ἀπιέναι τοῖς οἴκοι ζηλωτὸν ποιήσω ἀπελθεῖν , πολλοὺς δὲ οἶμαι ποιήσειν τὰ παρ’ ἐμοὶ ἑλέσθαι ἀντὶ τῶν οἴκοι .
perseus-eng2	But if you be men and if my undertaking turn out well, I shall make anyone among you who wishes to return home an object of envy to his friends at home upon his return, while I shall cause many of you, I imagine, to choose life with me in preference to life at home.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.7.5

cts:urn:0032-006:1.7.5

perseus-eng2	And yet,  Cyrus , there are those who say that your promises are big now because you are in such a critical situation—for the danger is upon you—but that if any good fortune befall, you will fail to remember them.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.7.5
glaux1.0-sentence	403
perseus-grc2	ἔνιοι δὲ οὐδ’ εἰ μεμνῇό τε καὶ βούλοιο δύνασθαι ἂν ἀποδοῦναι ὅσα ὑπισχνῇ .
perseus-eng2	Some say that even if you should remember and have the will, you would not have the means to make good all your promises.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.7.6

perseus-eng2	Upon hearing these words  Cyrus  said:

cts:urn:0032-006:1.7.6
glaux1.0-sentence	405

perseus-eng2	Well, gentlemen, my father’s realm extends toward the south to a region where men cannot dwell by reason of the heat, and to the north to a region where they cannot dwell by reason of the cold;

cts:urn:0032-006:1.7.6
glaux1.0-sentence	406
perseus-grc2	τὰ δ’ ἐν μέσῳ τούτων πάντα σατραπεύουσιν οἱ τοῦ ἐμοῦ ἀδελφοῦ φίλοι .
perseus-eng2	and all that lies between these limits my brother’s friends rule as satraps.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.7.7
glaux1.0-sentence	407
perseus-grc2	ἢν δ’ ἡμεῖς νικήσωμεν , ἡμᾶς δεῖ τοὺς ἡμετέρους φίλους τούτων ἐγκρατεῖς ποιῆσαι .
perseus-eng2	Now if we win the victory, we must put our friends in control of these provinces.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.7.7
glaux1.0-sentence	408
perseus-grc2	ὥστε οὐ τοῦτο δέδοικα , μὴ οὐκ ἔχω ὅ τι δῶ ἑκάστῳ τῶν φίλων , ἂν εὖ γένηται , ἀλλὰ μὴ οὐκ ἔχω ἱκανοὺς οἷς δῶ .
perseus-eng2	I fear, therefore, not that I shall not have enough to give to each of my friends, if success attends us, but that I shall not have enough friends to give to.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.7.7
glaux1.0-sentence	409
perseus-grc2	ὑμῶν δὲ τῶν Ἑλλήνων καὶ στέφανον ἑκάστῳ χρυσοῦν δώσω .
perseus-eng2	And as for you men of  Greece , I shall give each one of you a wreath of gold besides.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.7.8

perseus-eng2	When they heard these words, the officers were far more eager themselves and carried the news away with them to the other Greeks.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.7.8
glaux1.0-sentence	411

perseus-eng2	Then some of the others also sought  Cyrus ’ presence, demanding to know what they should have, in case of victory;

cts:urn:0032-006:1.7.8
glaux1.0-sentence	412

perseus-eng2	and he satisfied the expectations of every one of them before dismissing them.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.7.9
glaux1.0-sentence	413

perseus-eng2	Now all alike who conversed with him urged him not to take part in the fighting, but to station himself in their rear.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.7.9
glaux1.0-sentence	414
perseus-grc2	ἐν δὲ τῷ καιρῷ τούτῳ Κλέαρχος ὧδέ πως ἤρετο τὸν Κῦρον ·
perseus-eng2	Taking this opportunity Clearchus asked  Cyrus  a question like this:

cts:urn:0032-006:1.7.9
glaux1.0-sentence	415
perseus-grc2	οἴει γάρ σοι μαχεῖσθαι , ὦ Κῦρε , τὸν ἀδελφόν ;
perseus-eng2	But do you think,  Cyrus , that your brother will fight with you?

cts:urn:0032-006:1.7.9
glaux1.0-sentence	416
perseus-grc2	νὴ Δί’ , ἔφη ὁ Κῦρος , εἴπερ γε Δαρείου καὶ Παρυσάτιδός ἐστι παῖς , ἐμὸς δὲ ἀδελφός , οὐκ ἀμαχεὶ ταῦτ’ ἐγὼ λήψομαι .
perseus-eng2	"Yes, by Zeus," said  Cyrus , "if he is really a son of Darius and Parysatis and a brother of mine, I shall not win this realm without fighting for it."

cts:urn:0032-006:1.7.10
glaux1.0-sentence	417
perseus-grc2	ἐνταῦθα δὴ ἐν τῇ ἐξοπλισίᾳ ἀριθμὸς ἐγένετο τῶν μὲν Ἑλλήνων ἀσπὶς μυρία καὶ τετρακοσία , πελτασταὶ δὲ δισχίλιοι καὶ πεντακόσιοι , τῶν δὲ μετὰ Κύρου βαρβάρων δέκα μυριάδες καὶ ἅρματα δρεπανηφόρα ἀμφὶ τὰ εἴκοσι .
perseus-eng2	At this time, when the troops were marshalled under arms, while the number of the barbarians under  Cyrus  was one hundred thousand and there were about twenty scythe-bearing chariots.

perseus-eng2	But of the forces just enumerated only nine hundred thousand, with one hundred and fifty scythe-bearing chariots, were present at the battle.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.7.12

perseus-eng2	For Abrocomas, marching from  Phoenicia , arrived five days too late for the engagement.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.7.13

perseus-eng2	Such were the reports brought to  Cyrus  by those who deserted from the Great King before the battle, and after the battle identical reports were made by the prisoners taken thereafter.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.7.14

perseus-grc2	ἐντεῦθεν δὲ Κῦρος ἐξελαύνει σταθμὸν ἕνα παρασάγγας τρεῖς συντεταγμένῳ τῷ στρατεύματι παντὶ καὶ τῷ Ἑλληνικῷ καὶ τῷ βαρβαρικῷ ·
perseus-eng2	From there  Cyrus  marched one stage, three parasangs, with his whole army, Greek and barbarian alike, drawn up in line of battle;

cts:urn:0032-006:1.7.14
glaux1.0-sentence	426
perseus-grc2	ᾤετο γὰρ ταύτῃ τῇ ἡμέρᾳ μαχεῖσθαι βασιλέα ·
perseus-eng2	for he supposed that on that day the King would come to an engagement;

cts:urn:0032-006:1.7.14
glaux1.0-sentence	427
perseus-grc2	κατὰ γὰρ μέσον τὸν σταθμὸν τοῦτον τάφρος ἦν ὀρυκτὴ βαθεῖα , τὸ μὲν εὖρος ὀργυιαὶ πέντε , τὸ δὲ βάθος ὀργυιαὶ τρεῖς .
perseus-eng2	for about midway of this day’s march there was a deep trench, five fathoms in width and three fathoms in depth.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.7.15
glaux1.0-sentence	428
perseus-grc2	παρετέτατο δὲ ἡ τάφρος ἄνω διὰ τοῦ πεδίου ἐπὶ δώδεκα παρασάγγας μέχρι τοῦ Μηδίας τείχους .
perseus-eng2	This trench extended up through the plain for a distance of twelve parasangs, reaching to the wall of Media, Described by Xenophon in  Xen. Anab. 2.4.12 . It extended from the  Euphrates  north east to the  Tigris , and was built by the Babylonians, apparently in the sixth century B.C., as a defence against the Medes. It is supposed that the southern part of the wall was now in ruins. Such a supposition serves to explain (1) the need of the King’s trench, and (2) the fact that Xenophon does not describe the wall here, but only in  Xen. Anab. 2.4.12 .

cts:urn:0032-006:1.7.15

perseus-eng2	[Here also are the canals, which flow from the Tigris river;

cts:urn:0032-006:1.7.15
glaux1.0-sentence	430

perseus-eng2	they are four in number, each a plethrum wide and exceedingly deep, and grain-carrying ships ply in them;

cts:urn:0032-006:1.7.15

cts:urn:0032-006:1.7.15

cts:urn:0032-006:1.7.16

perseus-eng2	Now on that day the King did not offer battle, but tracks of both horses and men in retreat were to be seen in great numbers.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.7.18

perseus-eng2	Then  Cyrus  summoned  Silanus , his Ambraciot soothsayer, and gave him three thousand darics; for on the eleventh day before this, while sacrificing, he had told  Cyrus  that the King would not fight within ten days, and  Cyrus  had said:

cts:urn:0032-006:1.7.18

cts:urn:0032-006:1.7.18

perseus-eng2	But since the King did not appear at the trench and try to prevent the passage of  Cyrus ’ army, both  Cyrus  and the rest concluded that he had given up the idea of fighting.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.7.20

perseus-eng2	and on the third day he was making the march seated in his chariot and with only a small body of troops drawn up in line in front of him, while the greater part of the army was proceeding in disorder and many of the soldiers’ arms and accoutrements were being carried in wagons and on pack-animals.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.8.1
glaux1.0-sentence	443
perseus-grc2	καὶ ἤδη τε ἦν ἀμφὶ ἀγορὰν πλήθουσαν καὶ πλησίον ἦν ὁ σταθμὸς ἔνθα ἔμελλε καταλύειν , ἡνίκα Πατηγύας , ἀνὴρ Πέρσης τῶν ἀμφὶ Κῦρον χρηστός , προφαίνεται ἐλαύνων ἀνὰ κράτος ἱδροῦντι τῷ ἵππῳ , καὶ εὐθὺς πᾶσιν οἷς ἐνετύγχανεν ἐβόα καὶ βαρβαρικῶς καὶ ἑλληνικῶς ὅτι βασιλεὺς σὺν στρατεύματι πολλῷ προσέρχεται ὡς εἰς μάχην παρεσκευασμένος .
perseus-eng2	It was now about full-market time and the stopping-place where  Cyrus  was intending to halt had been almost reached, when Pategyas, a trusty Persian of  Cyrus ’ staff, came into sight, riding at full speed, with his horse in a sweat, and at once shouted out to everyone he met, in the barbarian tongue and in Greek, that the King was approaching with a large army, all ready for battle.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.8.2

cts:urn:0032-006:1.8.3

glaux1.0-sentence	449

perseus-eng2	and in the centre  Cyrus  and his horsemen, about six hundred in number. These troopers were armed with breast-plates and thigh-pieces and, all of them except  Cyrus , with helmets— Cyrus , however, went into the battle with his head unprotected. [In fact, it is said of the Persians in general that they venture all the perils of war with their heads unprotected.]

cts:urn:0032-006:1.8.10

perseus-grc2	εἶχον δὲ τὰ δρέπανα ἐκ τῶν ἀξόνων εἰς πλάγιον ἀποτεταμένα καὶ ὑπὸ τοῖς δίφροις εἰς γῆν βλέποντα , ὡς διακόπτειν ὅτῳ ἐντυγχάνοιεν .
perseus-eng2	and the scythes they carried reached out sideways from the axles and were also set under the chariot bodies, pointing towards the ground, so as to cut to pieces whatever they met;

cts:urn:0032-006:1.8.10
glaux1.0-sentence	463
perseus-grc2	ἡ δὲ γνώμη ἦν ὡς εἰς τὰς τάξεις τῶν Ἑλλήνων ἐλῶντα καὶ διακόψοντα .
perseus-eng2	the intention, then, was that they should drive into the ranks of the Greeks and cut the troops to pieces.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.8.11
glaux1.0-sentence	464
perseus-grc2	ὃ μέντοι Κῦρος εἶπεν ὅτε καλέσας παρεκελεύετο τοῖς Ἕλλησι τὴν κραυγὴν τῶν βαρβάρων ἀνέχεσθαι , ἐψεύσθη τοῦτο ·
perseus-eng2	As for the statement, however, which  Cyrus  made when he called the Greeks together and urged them to hold out against the shouting of the barbarians, he proved to be mistaken in this point;

cts:urn:0032-006:1.8.11
glaux1.0-sentence	465
perseus-grc2	οὐ γὰρ κραυγῇ ἀλλὰ σιγῇ ὡς ἁνυστὸν καὶ ἡσυχῇ ἐν ἴσῳ καὶ βραδέως προσῇσαν .
perseus-eng2	for they came on, not with shouting, but in the utmost silence and quietness, with equal step and slowly.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.8.12
glaux1.0-sentence	466
perseus-grc2	καὶ ἐν τούτῳ Κῦρος παρελαύνων αὐτὸς σὺν Πίγρητι τῷ ἑρμηνεῖ καὶ ἄλλοις τρισὶν ἢ τέτταρσι τῷ Κλεάρχῳ ἐβόα ἄγειν τὸ στράτευμα κατὰ μέσον τὸ τῶν πολεμίων , ὅτι ἐκεῖ βασιλεὺς εἴη ·
perseus-eng2	At this moment  Cyrus  rode along the line, attended only by Pigres, his interpreter, and three or four others, and shouted to Clearchus to lead his army against the enemy’s centre, for the reason that the King was stationed there;

cts:urn:0032-006:1.8.12
glaux1.0-sentence	467
perseus-grc2	κἂν τοῦτ’ , ἔφη , νικῶμεν , πάνθ’ ἡμῖν πεποίηται .
perseus-eng2	and if," he said, "we are victorious there, our whole task is accomplished.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.8.13
glaux1.0-sentence	468
perseus-grc2	ὁρῶν δὲ ὁ Κλέαρχος τὸ μέσον στῖφος καὶ ἀκούων Κύρου ἔξω ὄντα τοῦ Ἑλληνικοῦ εὐωνύμου βασιλέα ( τοσοῦτον γὰρ πλήθει περιῆν βασιλεὺς ὥστε μέσον τῶν ἑαυτοῦ ἔχων τοῦ Κύρου εὐωνύμου ἔξω ἦν ) ἀλλ’ ὅμως ὁ Κλέαρχος οὐκ ἤθελεν ἀποσπάσαι ἀπὸ τοῦ ποταμοῦ τὸ δεξιὸν κέρας , φοβούμενος μὴ κυκλωθείη ἑκατέρωθεν , τῷ δὲ Κύρῳ ἀπεκρίνατο ὅτι αὐτῷ μέλει ὅπως καλῶς ἔχοι .
perseus-eng2	Clearchus, however, since he saw the compact body at the enemy’s centre and heard from  Cyrus  that the King was beyond his left wing (for the King was so superior in numbers that, although occupying the centre of his own line, he was beyond  Cyrus ’ left wing), was unwilling to draw the right wing away from the river, for fear that he might be turned on both flanks; and he told  Cyrus , in reply, that he was taking care to make everything go well.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.8.14
glaux1.0-sentence	469
perseus-grc2	καὶ ἐν τούτῳ τῷ καιρῷ τὸ μὲν βαρβαρικὸν στράτευμα ὁμαλῶς προῄει , τὸ δὲ Ἑλληνικὸν ἔτι ἐν τῷ αὐτῷ μένον συνετάττετο ἐκ τῶν ἔτι προσιόντων .
perseus-eng2	At this critical time the King’s army was advancing evenly, while the Greek force, still remaining in the same place, was forming its line from those who were still coming up.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.8.14
glaux1.0-sentence	470
perseus-grc2	καὶ ὁ Κῦρος παρελαύνων οὐ πάνυ πρὸς αὐτῷ στρατεύματι κατεθεᾶτο ἑκατέρωσε ἀποβλέπων εἴς τε τοὺς πολεμίους καὶ τοὺς φίλους .
perseus-eng2	And  Cyrus , riding along at some distance from his army, was taking a survey, looking in either direction, both at his enemies and his friends.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.8.15

perseus-eng2	Then Xenophon, an Athenian, seeing him from the Greek army, approached so as to meet him and asked if he had any orders to give;

cts:urn:0032-006:1.8.15

cts:urn:0032-006:1.8.16

perseus-eng2	While saying this he heard a noise running through the ranks, and asked what the noise was.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.8.16

cts:urn:0032-006:1.8.17

perseus-eng2	At length the opposing lines were not three or four stadia apart, and then the Greeks struck up the paean and began to advance against the enemy.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.8.18

cts:urn:0032-006:1.8.19

perseus-eng2	And before an arrow reached them, the barbarians broke and fled.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.8.19
glaux1.0-sentence	485
perseus-grc2	καὶ ἐνταῦθα δὴ ἐδίωκον μὲν κατὰ κράτος οἱ Ἕλληνες , ἐβόων δὲ ἀλλήλοις μὴ θεῖν δρόμῳ , ἀλλ’ ἐν τάξει ἕπεσθαι .
perseus-eng2	Thereupon the Greeks pursued with all their might, but shouted meanwhile to one another not to run at a headlong pace, but to keep their ranks in the pursuit.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.8.20
glaux1.0-sentence	486
perseus-grc2	τὰ δ’ ἅρματα ἐφέροντο τὰ μὲν δι’ αὐτῶν τῶν πολεμίων , τὰ δὲ καὶ διὰ τῶν Ἑλλήνων κενὰ ἡνιόχων .
perseus-eng2	As for the enemy’s chariots, some of them plunged through the lines of their own troops, others, however, through the Greek lines, but without charioteers.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.8.20

cts:urn:0032-006:1.8.20
glaux1.0-sentence	488

cts:urn:0032-006:1.8.20
glaux1.0-sentence	489
perseus-grc2	καὶ οὐδὲν μέντοι οὐδὲ τοῦτον παθεῖν ἔφασαν , οὐδ’ ἄλλος δὲ τῶν Ἑλλήνων ἐν ταύτῃ τῇ μάχῃ ἔπαθεν οὐδεὶς οὐδέν , πλὴν ἐπὶ τῷ εὐωνύμῳ τοξευθῆναί τις ἐλέγετο .
perseus-eng2	Yet it was said that even he was not hurt in the least, nor, for that matter, did any other single man among the Greeks get any hurt whatever in this battle, save that some one on the left wing was reported to have been hit by an arrow.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.8.21
glaux1.0-sentence	490
perseus-grc2	Κῦρος δ’ ὁρῶν τοὺς Ἕλληνας νικῶντας τὸ καθ’ αὑτοὺς καὶ διώκοντας , ἡδόμενος καὶ προσκυνούμενος ἤδη ὡς βασιλεὺς ὑπὸ τῶν ἀμφ’ αὐτόν , οὐδ’ ὣς ἐξήχθη διώκειν , ἀλλὰ συνεσπειραμένην ἔχων τὴν τῶν σὺν ἑαυτῷ ἑξακοσίων ἱππέων τάξιν ἐπεμελεῖτο ὅ τι ποιήσει βασιλεύς .
perseus-eng2	When  Cyrus  saw that the Greeks were victorious over the division opposite them and were in pursuit, although he was pleased and was already being saluted with homage as King by his attendants, he nevertheless was not induced to join the pursuit, but, keeping in close formation the six hundred horsemen of his troop, he was watching to see what the King would do.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.8.21
glaux1.0-sentence	491
perseus-grc2	καὶ γὰρ ᾔδει αὐτὸν ὅτι μέσον ἔχοι τοῦ Περσικοῦ στρατεύματος .
perseus-eng2	For he knew that the King held the centre of the Persian army;

cts:urn:0032-006:1.8.22
glaux1.0-sentence	492
perseus-grc2	καὶ πάντες δ’ οἱ τῶν βαρβάρων ἄρχοντες μέσον ἔχοντες τὸ αὑτῶν ἡγοῦνται , νομίζοντες οὕτω καὶ ἐν ἀσφαλεστάτῳ εἶναι , ἢν ᾖ ἡ ἰσχὺς αὐτῶν ἑκατέρωθεν , καὶ εἴ τι παραγγεῖλαι χρῄζοιεν , ἡμίσει ἂν χρόνῳ αἰσθάνεσθαι τὸ στράτευμα .
perseus-eng2	in fact, all the generals of the barbarians hold their own centre when they are in command, for they think that this is the safest position, namely, with their forces on either side of them, and also that if they want to pass along an order, the army will get it in half the time;

cts:urn:0032-006:1.8.23
glaux1.0-sentence	493
perseus-grc2	καὶ βασιλεὺς δὴ τότε μέσον ἔχων τῆς αὑτοῦ στρατιᾶς ὅμως ἔξω ἐγένετο τοῦ Κύρου εὐωνύμου κέρατος .
perseus-eng2	so in this instance the King held the centre of the army under his command, but still he found himself beyond the left wing of  Cyrus .

cts:urn:0032-006:1.8.23
glaux1.0-sentence	494
perseus-grc2	ἐπεὶ δ’ οὐδεὶς αὐτῷ ἐμάχετο ἐκ τοῦ ἀντίου οὐδὲ τοῖς αὐτοῦ τεταγμένοις ἔμπροσθεν , ἐπέκαμπτεν ὡς εἰς κύκλωσιν .
perseus-eng2	Since, then, there was no one in his front to give battle to him or to the troops drawn up before him, he proceeded to wheel round his line with the intention of encircling the enemy.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.8.24
glaux1.0-sentence	495
perseus-grc2	ἔνθα δὴ Κῦρος δείσας μὴ ὄπισθεν γενόμενος κατακόψῃ τὸ Ἑλληνικὸν ἐλαύνει ἀντίος ·
perseus-eng2	Thereupon  Cyrus , seized with fear lest he might get in the rear of the Greek troops and cut them to pieces, charged to meet him; and attacking with his six hundred, he was victorious over the forces stationed in front of the King and put to flight the six thousand, slaying with his own hand, it is said, their commander Artagerses.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.8.25
glaux1.0-sentence	497
perseus-grc2	ὡς δ’ ἡ τροπὴ ἐγένετο , διασπείρονται καὶ οἱ Κύρου ἑξακόσιοι εἰς τὸ διώκειν ὁρμήσαντες , πλὴν πάνυ ὀλίγοι ἀμφ’ αὐτὸν κατελείφθησαν , σχεδὸν οἱ ὁμοτράπεζοι καλούμενοι .
perseus-eng2	But when they turned to flight,  Cyrus ’ six hundred, setting out in pursuit, became scattered also, and only a very few were left about him, chiefly his so-called table companions.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.8.26

perseus-eng2	and on the instant he lost control of himself and, with the cry the physician says, adding also that he himself healed the wound.

cts:urn:0032-006:1.8.27

perseus-eng2	and then followed a struggle between the King and  Cyrus  and the attendants who supported each of them. The number that fell on the King’s side is stated by Ctesias,

cts:urn:0032-006:1.8.28

perseus-eng2	Of Artapates, the one among  Cyrus ’ chamberlains who was his most faithful follower, it is told that when he saw  Cyrus  fallen, he leaped down from his horse and threw his arms about him.

perseus-eng2	And one report is that the King ordered someone to slay him upon the body of  Cyrus , while others say that he drew his dagger and slew himself with his own hand;

cts:urn:0032-006:1.8.29
