perseus-eng2	After this it was deemed necessary to distribute the troops again to quarters in the houses of the several villages.

cts:urn:0032-006:4.4.14
glaux1.0-sentence	1737
perseus-grc2	ἔνθα δὴ οἱ στρατιῶται σὺν πολλῇ κραυγῇ καὶ ἡδονῇ ᾖσαν ἐπὶ τὰς στέγας καὶ τὰ ἐπιτήδεια ·
perseus-eng2	Then followed plenty of joyful shouting as the men went back to their houses and provisions.

cts:urn:0032-006:4.4.14
glaux1.0-sentence	1738
perseus-grc2	ὅσοι δὲ ὅτε τὸ πρότερον ἀπῇσαν τὰς οἰκίας ἐνέπρησαν ὑπὸ ἀτασθαλίας , δίκην ἐδίδοσαν κακῶς σκηνοῦντες .
perseus-eng2	All those who just before had wantonly burned the houses they were leaving, paid the penalty by getting poor quarters.

cts:urn:0032-006:4.4.15
glaux1.0-sentence	1739
perseus-grc2	ἐντεῦθεν ἔπεμψαν νυκτὸς Δημοκράτην Τημνίτην ἄνδρας δόντες ἐπὶ τὰ ὄρη ἔνθα ἔφασαν οἱ ἀποσκεδαννύμενοι καθορᾶν τὰ πυρά ·
perseus-eng2	After this they sent Democrates of Temnus with a body of troops during the night to the mountains where the stragglers said they had seen the fires;

cts:urn:0032-006:4.4.15
glaux1.0-sentence	1740
perseus-grc2	οὗτος γὰρ ἐδόκει καὶ πρότερον πολλὰ ἤδη ἀληθεῦσαι τοιαῦτα , τὰ ὄντα τε ὡς ὄντα καὶ τὰ μὴ ὄντα ὡς οὐκ ὄντα .
perseus-eng2	for this Democrates enjoyed the reputation of having made accurate reports in many previous cases of the same sort, describing what were facts as facts and what were fictions as fictions.

cts:urn:0032-006:4.4.16
glaux1.0-sentence	1741
perseus-grc2	πορευθεὶς δὲ τὰ μὲν πυρὰ οὐκ ἔφη ἰδεῖν , ἄνδρα δὲ συλλαβὼν ἧκεν ἄγων ἔχοντα τόξον Περσικὸν καὶ φαρέτραν καὶ σάγαριν οἵανπερ καὶ αἱ Ἀμαζόνες ἔχουσιν .
perseus-eng2	Upon his return he stated that he had not seen the fires; he had captured, however, and brought back with him a man with a Persian bow and quiver and a battleaxe of the same sort that Amazons carry.

cts:urn:0032-006:4.4.17
glaux1.0-sentence	1742
perseus-grc2	ἐρωτώμενος δὲ ποδαπὸς εἴη Πέρσης μὲν ἔφη εἶναι , πορεύεσθαι δ’ ἀπὸ τοῦ Τιριβάζου στρατοπέδου , ὅπως ἐπιτήδεια λάβοι .
perseus-eng2	When this man was asked from what country he came, he said he was a Persian and was on his way from the camp of Tiribazus to get provisions.

cts:urn:0032-006:4.4.17
glaux1.0-sentence	1743
perseus-grc2	οἱ δὲ ἠρώτων αὐτὸν τὸ στράτευμα ὁπόσον τε εἴη καὶ ἐπὶ τίνι συνειλεγμένον .
perseus-eng2	They asked him how large Tiribazus’ army was and for what purpose it had been gathered.

cts:urn:0032-006:4.4.18
glaux1.0-sentence	1744
perseus-grc2	ὁ δὲ εἶπεν ὅτι Τιρίβαζος εἴη ἔχων τήν τε ἑαυτοῦ δύναμιν καὶ μισθοφόρους Χάλυβας καὶ Ταόχους ·
perseus-eng2	He replied that it was Tiribazus with his own forces and Chalybian and Taochian mercenaries,

cts:urn:0032-006:4.4.18
glaux1.0-sentence	1745
perseus-grc2	παρεσκευάσθαι δὲ αὐτὸν ἔφη ὡς ἐπὶ τῇ ὑπερβολῇ τοῦ ὄρους ἐν τοῖς στενοῖς ᾗπερ μοναχῇ εἴη πορεία , ἐνταῦθα ἐπιθησόμενον τοῖς Ἕλλησιν .
perseus-eng2	and that he had made his preparations with the idea of taking a position upon the mountain pass, in the defile through which ran the only road, and there attacking the Greeks.

cts:urn:0032-006:4.4.19
glaux1.0-sentence	1746
perseus-grc2	ἀκούσασι τοῖς στρατηγοῖς ταῦτα ἔδοξε τὸ στράτευμα συναγαγεῖν ·
perseus-eng2	When the generals heard these statements, they resolved to bring the troops together into a camp;

cts:urn:0032-006:4.4.19
glaux1.0-sentence	1747
perseus-grc2	καὶ εὐθὺς φύλακας καταλιπόντες καὶ στρατηγὸν ἐπὶ τοῖς μένουσι Σοφαίνετον Στυμφάλιον ἐπορεύοντο ἔχοντες ἡγεμόνα τὸν ἁλόντα ἄνθρωπον .
perseus-eng2	then, after leaving a garrison and Sophaenetus the Stymphalian as general in command of those who stayed behind, they set out at once, with the captured man as guide.

cts:urn:0032-006:4.4.20
glaux1.0-sentence	1748
perseus-grc2	ἐπειδὴ δὲ ὑπερέβαλλον τὰ ὄρη , οἱ πελτασταὶ προϊόντες καὶ κατιδόντες τὸ στρατόπεδον οὐκ ἔμειναν τοὺς ὁπλίτας , ἀλλ’ ἀνακραγόντες ἔθεον ἐπὶ τὸ στρατόπεδον .
perseus-eng2	As soon as they had begun to cross the mountains, the peltasts, pushing on ahead and descrying the enemy’s camp, did not wait for the hoplites, but raised a shout and charged upon the camp.

cts:urn:0032-006:4.4.21
glaux1.0-sentence	1749
perseus-grc2	οἱ δὲ βάρβαροι ἀκούσαντες τὸν θόρυβον οὐχ ὑπέμειναν , ἀλλ’ ἔφευγον ·
perseus-eng2	When the barbarians heard the uproar, they did not wait to offer resistance, but took to flight;

cts:urn:0032-006:4.4.21
glaux1.0-sentence	1750
perseus-grc2	ὅμως δὲ καὶ ἀπέθανόν τινες τῶν βαρβάρων καὶ ἵπποι ἥλωσαν εἰς εἴκοσι καὶ ἡ σκηνὴ ἡ Τιριβάζου ἑάλω καὶ ἐν αὐτῇ κλῖναι ἀργυρόποδες καὶ ἐκπώματα καὶ οἱ ἀρτοκόποι καὶ οἱ οἰνοχόοι φάσκοντες εἶναι .
perseus-eng2	nevertheless, some of them were killed, about twenty horses were captured, and likewise Tiribazus’ tent, with silver-footed couches in it, and drinking cups, and people who said they were his bakers and his cup-bearers.

cts:urn:0032-006:4.4.22
glaux1.0-sentence	1751
perseus-grc2	ἐπειδὴ δὲ ἐπύθοντο ταῦτα οἱ τῶν ὁπλιτῶν στρατηγοί , ἐδόκει αὐτοῖς ἀπιέναι τὴν ταχίστην ἐπὶ τὸ στρατόπεδον , μή τις ἐπίθεσις γένοιτο τοῖς καταλελειμμένοις .
perseus-eng2	As soon as the generals of the hoplites learned of these results, they deemed it best to go back as speedily as possible to their own camp, lest some attack might be made upon those they had left behind.

cts:urn:0032-006:4.4.22
glaux1.0-sentence	1752
perseus-grc2	καὶ εὐθὺς ἀνακαλεσάμενοι τῇ σάλπιγγι ἀπῇσαν , καὶ ἀφίκοντο αὐθημερὸν ἐπὶ τὸ στρατόπεδον .
perseus-eng2	So they immediately sounded the recall with the trumpet and set out on the return journey, arriving at their camp on the same day.

cts:urn:0032-006:4.5.1
glaux1.0-sentence	1753
perseus-grc2	τῇ δ’ ὑστεραίᾳ ἐδόκει πορευτέον εἶναι ὅπῃ δύναιντο τάχιστα πρὶν ἢ συλλεγῆναι τὸ στράτευμα πάλιν καὶ καταλαβεῖν τὰ στενά .
perseus-eng2	On the next day it seemed that they must continue their march with all speed, before the hostile army could be gathered together again and take possession of the narrow passes.

cts:urn:0032-006:4.5.1
glaux1.0-sentence	1754
perseus-grc2	συσκευασάμενοι δ’ εὐθὺς ἐπορεύοντο διὰ χιόνος πολλῆς ἡγεμόνας ἔχοντες πολλούς ·
perseus-eng2	They accordingly packed up and set out at once, marching through deep snow with a large number of guides;

cts:urn:0032-006:4.5.1
glaux1.0-sentence	1755
perseus-grc2	καὶ αὐθημερὸν ὑπερβαλόντες τὸ ἄκρον ἐφ’ ᾧ ἔμελλεν ἐπιτίθεσθαι Τιρίβαζος κατεστρατοπεδεύσαντο .
perseus-eng2	and before the day ended they crossed over the summit at which Tiribazus was intending to attack them and went into camp.

cts:urn:0032-006:4.5.2
glaux1.0-sentence	1756
perseus-grc2	ἐντεῦθεν δ’ ἐπορεύθησαν σταθμοὺς ἐρήμους τρεῖς παρασάγγας πεντεκαίδεκα ἐπὶ τὸν Εὐφράτην ποταμόν , καὶ διέβαινον αὐτὸν βρεχόμενοι πρὸς τὸν ὀμφαλόν .
perseus-eng2	From there they marched three stages through desert country, fifteen parasangs, to the Euphrates river, and crossed it, wetting themselves up to the navel;

cts:urn:0032-006:4.5.3
glaux1.0-sentence	1757
perseus-grc2	ἐλέγοντο δ’ οὐδὲ πηγαὶ πρόσω εἶναι .
perseus-eng2	and report was that the sources of the river were not far distant.

cts:urn:0032-006:4.5.3
glaux1.0-sentence	1758
perseus-grc2	ἐντεῦθεν ἐπορεύοντο διὰ χιόνος πολλῆς καὶ πεδίου σταθμοὺς τρεῖς παρασάγγας πεντεκαίδεκα .
perseus-eng2	From there they marched over a plain and through deep snow three stages, thirteen parasangs.

cts:urn:0032-006:4.5.3
glaux1.0-sentence	1759
perseus-grc2	ὁ δὲ τρίτος ἐγένετο χαλεπὸς καὶ ἄνεμος βορρᾶς ἐναντίος ἔπνει παντάπασιν ἀποκαίων πάντα καὶ πηγνὺς τοὺς ἀνθρώπους .
perseus-eng2	The third stage proved a hard one, with the north wind, which blew full in their faces, absolutely blasting everything and freezing the men.

cts:urn:0032-006:4.5.4
glaux1.0-sentence	1760
perseus-grc2	ἔνθα δὴ τῶν μάντεών τις εἶπε σφαγιάσασθαι τῷ ἀνέμῳ , καὶ σφαγιάζεται ·
perseus-eng2	Then it was that one of the soothsayers bade them offer sacrifice to the wind, and sacrifice was offered;

cts:urn:0032-006:4.5.4
glaux1.0-sentence	1761
perseus-grc2	καὶ πᾶσι δὴ περιφανῶς ἔδοξεν λῆξαι τὸ χαλεπὸν τοῦ πνεύματος .
perseus-eng2	and it seemed quite clear to everybody that the violence of the wind abated.

cts:urn:0032-006:4.5.4
glaux1.0-sentence	1762
perseus-grc2	ἦν δὲ τῆς χιόνος τὸ βάθος ὀργυιά ·
perseus-eng2	But the depth of the snow was a fathom.

cts:urn:0032-006:4.5.4
glaux1.0-sentence	1763
perseus-grc2	ὥστε καὶ τῶν ὑποζυγίων καὶ τῶν ἀνδραπόδων πολλὰ ἀπώλετο καὶ τῶν στρατιωτῶν ὡς τριάκοντα .
perseus-eng2	The result was that many of the baggage animals and slaves perished, and about thirty of the soldiers.

cts:urn:0032-006:4.5.5
glaux1.0-sentence	1764
perseus-grc2	διεγένοντο δὲ τὴν νύκτα πῦρ καίοντες ·
perseus-eng2	They got through that night by keeping up fires.

cts:urn:0032-006:4.5.5
glaux1.0-sentence	1765
perseus-grc2	ξύλα δ’ ἦν ἐν τῷ σταθμῷ πολλά ·
perseus-eng2	For there was wood in abundance at the halting-place;

cts:urn:0032-006:4.5.5
glaux1.0-sentence	1766
perseus-grc2	οἱ δὲ ὀψὲ προσιόντες ξύλα οὐκ εἶχον .
perseus-eng2	those who came up late, however, had none.

cts:urn:0032-006:4.5.5
glaux1.0-sentence	1767
perseus-grc2	οἱ οὖν πάλαι ἥκοντες καὶ τὸ πῦρ καίοντες οὐ προσίεσαν πρὸς τὸ πῦρ τοὺς ὀψίζοντας , εἰ μὴ μεταδοῖεν αὐτοῖς πυροὺς ἢ ἄλλο τι εἴ τι ἔχοιεν βρωτόν .
perseus-eng2	Consequently the men who had arrived early and were keeping a fire would not allow the late comers to get near it unless they gave them a share of their wheat or anything else they had that was edible.

cts:urn:0032-006:4.5.6
glaux1.0-sentence	1768
perseus-grc2	ἔνθα δὴ μετεδίδοσαν ἀλλήλοις ὧν εἶχον ἕκαστοι .
perseus-eng2	So then they shared with one another what they severally possessed.

cts:urn:0032-006:4.5.6
glaux1.0-sentence	1769
perseus-grc2	ἔνθα δὲ τὸ πῦρ ἐκαίετο , διατηκομένης τῆς χιόνος βόθροι ἐγένοντο μεγάλοι ἔστε ἐπὶ τὸ δάπεδον ·
perseus-eng2	Now where the fire was kindled the snow melted, and the result was great holes clear down to the ground;

cts:urn:0032-006:4.5.6
glaux1.0-sentence	1770
perseus-grc2	οὗ δὴ παρῆν μετρεῖν τὸ βάθος τῆς χιόνος .
perseus-eng2	and there, of course, one could measure the depth of the snow.

cts:urn:0032-006:4.5.7
glaux1.0-sentence	1771
perseus-grc2	ἐντεῦθεν δὲ τὴν ἐπιοῦσαν ἡμέραν ὅλην ἐπορεύοντο διὰ χιόνος , καὶ πολλοὶ τῶν ἀνθρώπων ἐβουλιμίασαν .
perseus-eng2	From there they marched all the following day through snow, and many of the men fell ill with hunger-faintness.

cts:urn:0032-006:4.5.7
glaux1.0-sentence	1772
perseus-grc2	Ξενοφῶν δ’ ὀπισθοφυλακῶν καὶ καταλαμβάνων τοὺς πίπτοντας τῶν ἀνθρώπων ἠγνόει ὅ τι τὸ πάθος εἴη .
perseus-eng2	And Xenophon, with the rear-guard, as he came upon the men who were falling by the way, did not know what the trouble was.

cts:urn:0032-006:4.5.8
glaux1.0-sentence	1773
perseus-grc2	ἐπειδὴ δὲ εἶπέ τις αὐτῷ τῶν ἐμπείρων ὅτι σαφῶς βουλιμιῶσι κἄν τι φάγωσιν ἀναστήσονται , περιιὼν περὶ τὰ ὑποζύγια , εἴ πού τι ὁρῴη βρωτόν , διεδίδου καὶ διέπεμπε διδόντας τοὺς δυναμένους περιτρέχειν τοῖς βουλιμιῶσιν .
perseus-eng2	But as soon as a person who was acquainted with the disease had told him that they manifestly had hunger-faintness, and if they were given something to eat would be able to get up, he went around among the baggage animals, and wherever he saw anything that was edible, he would distribute it among the sick men, or send hither and thither people who had the strength to run along the lines, to give it to them.

cts:urn:0032-006:4.5.9
glaux1.0-sentence	1774
perseus-grc2	ἐπειδὴ δέ τι ἐμφάγοιεν , ἀνίσταντο καὶ ἐπορεύοντο .
perseus-eng2	And when they had eaten something, they would get up and continue the march.

cts:urn:0032-006:4.5.9
glaux1.0-sentence	1775
perseus-grc2	πορευομένων δὲ Χειρίσοφος μὲν ἀμφὶ κνέφας πρὸς κώμην ἀφικνεῖται , καὶ ὑδροφορούσας ἐκ τῆς κώμης πρὸς τῇ κρήνῃ γυναῖκας καὶ κόρας καταλαμβάνει ἔμπροσθεν τοῦ ἐρύματος .
perseus-eng2	As the army went on, Cheirisophus reached a village about dusk, and found at the spring outside the wall women and girls who had come from the village to fetch water.

cts:urn:0032-006:4.5.10
glaux1.0-sentence	1776
perseus-grc2	αὗται ἠρώτων αὐτοὺς τίνες εἶεν .
perseus-eng2	They asked the Greeks who they were.

cts:urn:0032-006:4.5.10
glaux1.0-sentence	1777
perseus-grc2	ὁ δ’ ἑρμηνεὺς εἶπε περσιστὶ ὅτι παρὰ βασιλέως πορεύονται πρὸς τὸν σατράπην .
perseus-eng2	The interpreter replied in Persian that they were on their way from the King to the satrap.

cts:urn:0032-006:4.5.10
glaux1.0-sentence	1778
perseus-grc2	αἱ δὲ ἀπεκρίναντο ὅτι οὐκ ἐνταῦθα εἴη , ἀλλ’ ἀπέχει ὅσον παρασάγγην .
perseus-eng2	The women answered that he was not there, but about a parasang away.

cts:urn:0032-006:4.5.10
glaux1.0-sentence	1779
perseus-grc2	οἱ δ’ , ἐπεὶ ὀψὲ ἦν , πρὸς τὸν κώμαρχον συνεισέρχονται εἰς τὸ ἔρυμα σὺν ταῖς ὑδροφόροις .
perseus-eng2	Then, inasmuch as it was late, the Greeks accompanied the water-carriers within the wall to visit the village chief.

cts:urn:0032-006:4.5.11
glaux1.0-sentence	1780
perseus-grc2	Χειρίσοφος μὲν οὖν καὶ ὅσοι ἐδυνήθησαν τοῦ στρατεύματος ἐνταῦθα ἐστρατοπεδεύσαντο , τῶν δ’ ἄλλων στρατιωτῶν οἱ μὴ δυνάμενοι διατελέσαι τὴν ὁδὸν ἐνυκτέρευσαν ἄσιτοι καὶ ἄνευ πυρός ·
perseus-eng2	So it was that Cheirisophus and all the troops who could muster strength enough to reach the village, went into quarters there, but such of the others as were unable to complete the journey spent the night in the open without food or fire;

cts:urn:0032-006:4.5.11
glaux1.0-sentence	1781
perseus-grc2	καὶ ἐνταῦθά τινες ἀπώλοντο τῶν στρατιωτῶν .
perseus-eng2	and in this way some of the soldiers perished.

cts:urn:0032-006:4.5.12
glaux1.0-sentence	1782
perseus-grc2	ἐφείποντο δὲ τῶν πολεμίων συνειλεγμένοι τινὲς καὶ τὰ μὴ δυνάμενα τῶν ὑποζυγίων ἥρπαζον καὶ ἀλλήλοις ἐμάχοντο περὶ αὐτῶν .
perseus-eng2	Meanwhile they were being followed by the enemy, some of whom had banded together and were seizing such of the pack animals as lacked the strength to go on, and fighting over them with one another.

cts:urn:0032-006:4.5.12
glaux1.0-sentence	1783
perseus-grc2	ἐλείποντο δὲ τῶν στρατιωτῶν οἵ τε διεφθαρμένοι ὑπὸ τῆς χιόνος τοὺς ὀφθαλμοὺς οἵ τε ὑπὸ τοῦ ψύχους τοὺς δακτύλους τῶν ποδῶν ἀποσεσηπότες .
perseus-eng2	Some of the soldiers likewise were falling behind—those whose eyes had been blinded by the snow, or whose toes had rotted off by reason of the cold.

cts:urn:0032-006:4.5.13
glaux1.0-sentence	1784
perseus-grc2	ἦν δὲ τοῖς μὲν ὀφθαλμοῖς ἐπικούρημα τῆς χιόνος εἴ τις μέλαν τι ἔχων πρὸ τῶν ὀφθαλμῶν ἐπορεύετο , τῶν δὲ ποδῶν εἴ τις κινοῖτο καὶ μηδέποτε ἡσυχίαν ἔχοι καὶ εἰς τὴν νύκτα ὑπολύοιτο ·
perseus-eng2	It was a protection to the eyes against the snow if a man marched with something black in front of them, and a protection to the feet if one kept moving and never quiet, and if he took off his shoes for the night;

cts:urn:0032-006:4.5.14
glaux1.0-sentence	1785
perseus-grc2	ὅσοι δὲ ὑποδεδεμένοι ἐκοιμῶντο , εἰσεδύοντο εἰς τοὺς πόδας οἱ ἱμάντες καὶ τὰ ὑποδήματα περιεπήγνυντο ·
perseus-eng2	but in all cases where men slept with their shoes on, the straps sunk into their flesh and the shoes froze on their feet;

cts:urn:0032-006:4.5.14
glaux1.0-sentence	1786
perseus-grc2	καὶ γὰρ ἦσαν , ἐπειδὴ ἐπέλιπε τὰ ἀρχαῖα ὑποδήματα , καρβάτιναι πεποιημέναι ἐκ τῶν νεοδάρτων βοῶν .
perseus-eng2	for what they were wearing, since their old shoes had given out, were brogues made of freshly flayed ox-hides.

cts:urn:0032-006:4.5.15
glaux1.0-sentence	1787
perseus-grc2	διὰ τὰς τοιαύτας οὖν ἀνάγκας ὑπελείποντό τινες τῶν στρατιωτῶν ·
perseus-eng2	It was under compulsion of such difficulties that some of the soldiers were falling behind;

cts:urn:0032-006:4.5.15
glaux1.0-sentence	1788
perseus-grc2	καὶ ἰδόντες μέλαν τι χωρίον διὰ τὸ ἐκλελοιπέναι αὐτόθι τὴν χιόνα εἴκαζον τετηκέναι ·
perseus-eng2	and espying a spot that was dark because the snow just there had disappeared, they surmised that it had melted;

cts:urn:0032-006:4.5.15
glaux1.0-sentence	1789
perseus-grc2	καὶ ἐτετήκει διὰ κρήνην τινὰ ἣ πλησίον ἦν ἀτμίζουσα ἐν νάπῃ .
perseus-eng2	and in fact it had melted, on account of a spring which was near by, steaming in a dell;

cts:urn:0032-006:4.5.15
glaux1.0-sentence	1790
perseus-grc2	ἐνταῦθ’ ἐκτραπόμενοι ἐκάθηντο καὶ οὐκ ἔφασαν πορεύεσθαι .
perseus-eng2	here they turned aside and sat down, refusing to go any farther.

cts:urn:0032-006:4.5.16
glaux1.0-sentence	1791
perseus-grc2	ὁ δὲ Ξενοφῶν ἔχων ὀπισθοφύλακας ὡς ᾔσθετο , ἐδεῖτο αὐτῶν πάσῃ τέχνῃ καὶ μηχανῇ μὴ ἀπολείπεσθαι , λέγων ὅτι ἕπονται πολλοὶ πολέμιοι συνειλεγμένοι , καὶ τελευτῶν ἐχαλέπαινεν .
perseus-eng2	But when Xenophon with some of the rearguard observed them, he begged them by all manner of means not to be left behind, telling them that a large body of the enemy had gathered and were pursuing, and finally he became angry.

cts:urn:0032-006:4.5.16
glaux1.0-sentence	1792
perseus-grc2	οἱ δὲ σφάττειν ἐκέλευον ·
perseus-eng2	They told him, however, to kill them.

cts:urn:0032-006:4.5.16
glaux1.0-sentence	1793
perseus-grc2	οὐ γὰρ ἂν δύνασθαι πορευθῆναι .
perseus-eng2	For they could not go on.

cts:urn:0032-006:4.5.17
glaux1.0-sentence	1794
perseus-grc2	ἐνταῦθα ἔδοξε κράτιστον εἶναι τοὺς ἑπομένους πολεμίους φοβῆσαι , εἴ τις δύναιτο , μὴ ἐπίοιεν τοῖς κάμνουσι .
perseus-eng2	In this situation it seemed to be best to frighten the pursuing enemy, if they could, in order to prevent their falling upon the sick men.

cts:urn:0032-006:4.5.17
glaux1.0-sentence	1795
perseus-grc2	καὶ ἦν μὲν σκότος ἤδη , οἱ δὲ προσῇσαν πολλῷ θορύβῳ ἀμφὶ ὧν εἶχον διαφερόμενοι .
perseus-eng2	It was dark by this time, and the enemy were coming on with a great uproar, quarrelling over the booty they had.

cts:urn:0032-006:4.5.18
glaux1.0-sentence	1796
perseus-grc2	ἔνθα δὴ οἱ ὀπισθοφύλακες , ἅτε ὑγιαίνοντες , ἐξαναστάντες ἔδραμον εἰς τοὺς πολεμίους ·
perseus-eng2	Then the men of the rearguard, since they were sound and well, started up and charged upon the enemy.

cts:urn:0032-006:4.5.18
glaux1.0-sentence	1797
perseus-grc2	οἱ δὲ κάμνοντες ἀνακραγόντες ὅσον ἐδύναντο μέγιστον τὰς ἀσπίδας πρὸς τὰ δόρατα ἔκρουσαν .
perseus-eng2	The invalids raised as big a shout as they could and clashed their shields against their spears.

cts:urn:0032-006:4.5.18
glaux1.0-sentence	1798
perseus-grc2	οἱ δὲ πολέμιοι δείσαντες ἧκαν ἑαυτοὺς κατὰ τῆς χιόνος εἰς τὴν νάπην , καὶ οὐδεὶς ἔτι οὐδαμοῦ ἐφθέγξατο .
perseus-eng2	And the enemy, seized with fear, threw themselves down over the snow into the dell, and not a sound was heard from them afterwards.

cts:urn:0032-006:4.5.19
glaux1.0-sentence	1799
perseus-grc2	καὶ Ξενοφῶν μὲν καὶ οἱ σὺν αὐτῷ εἰπόντες τοῖς ἀσθενοῦσιν ὅτι τῇ ὑστεραίᾳ ἥξουσί τινες ἐπ’ αὐτούς , πορευόμενοι πρὶν τέτταρα στάδια διελθεῖν ἐντυγχάνουσιν ἐν τῇ ὁδῷ ἀναπαυομένοις ἐπὶ τῆς χιόνος τοῖς στρατιώταις ἐγκεκαλυμμένοις , καὶ οὐδὲ φυλακὴ οὐδεμία καθειστήκει ·
perseus-eng2	Thereupon Xenophon and his men, after telling the invalids that on the next day people would come back after them, continued their march, but before they had gone four stadia they came upon their comrades lying down in the road upon the snow, wrapped up in their cloaks, and without so much as a single guard posted.

cts:urn:0032-006:4.5.19
glaux1.0-sentence	1800
perseus-grc2	καὶ ἀνίστασαν αὐτούς .
perseus-eng2	They tried to get them up.

cts:urn:0032-006:4.5.19
glaux1.0-sentence	1801
perseus-grc2	οἱ δ’ ἔλεγον ὅτι οἱ ἔμπροσθεν οὐχ ὑποχωροῖεν .
perseus-eng2	But the men said that the troops in front would not make way for them.

cts:urn:0032-006:4.5.20
glaux1.0-sentence	1802
perseus-grc2	ὁ δὲ παριὼν καὶ παραπέμπων τῶν πελταστῶν τοὺς ἰσχυροτάτους ἐκέλευε σκέψασθαι τί εἴη τὸ κωλῦον .
perseus-eng2	Xenophon accordingly passed along and, sending forward the strongest of the peltasts, directed them to see what the hindrance was.

cts:urn:0032-006:4.5.20
glaux1.0-sentence	1803
perseus-grc2	οἱ δὲ ἀπήγγελλον ὅτι ὅλον οὕτως ἀναπαύοιτο τὸ στράτευμα .
perseus-eng2	They reported back that the whole army was resting in this way.

cts:urn:0032-006:4.5.21
glaux1.0-sentence	1804
perseus-grc2	ἐνταῦθα καὶ οἱ περὶ Ξενοφῶντα ηὐλίσθησαν αὐτοῦ ἄνευ πυρὸς καὶ ἄδειπνοι , φυλακὰς οἵας ἐδύναντο καταστησάμενοι .
perseus-eng2	Thereupon Xenophon also and his party bivouacked where they were, without a fire and without dinner, after stationing such guards as they could.

cts:urn:0032-006:4.5.21
glaux1.0-sentence	1805
perseus-grc2	ἐπεὶ δὲ πρὸς ἡμέραν ἦν , ὁ μὲν Ξενοφῶν πέμψας πρὸς τοὺς ἀσθενοῦντας τοὺς νεωτάτους ἀναστήσαντας ἐκέλευεν ἀναγκάζειν προϊέναι .
perseus-eng2	When it came toward morning, Xenophon sent the youngest of his troops to the sick men with orders to make them get up and force them to proceed.

cts:urn:0032-006:4.5.22
glaux1.0-sentence	1806
perseus-grc2	ἐν δὲ τούτῳ Χειρίσοφος πέμπει τῶν ἐκ τῆς κώμης σκεψομένους πῶς ἔχοιεν οἱ τελευταῖοι .
perseus-eng2	Meanwhile Cheirisophus sent some of the troops quartered in the village to find out how the people at the rear were faring.

cts:urn:0032-006:4.5.22
glaux1.0-sentence	1807
perseus-grc2	οἱ δὲ ἄσμενοι ἰδόντες τοὺς μὲν ἀσθενοῦντας τούτοις παρέδοσαν κομίζειν ἐπὶ τὸ στρατόπεδον , αὐτοὶ δὲ ἐπορεύοντο , καὶ πρὶν εἴκοσι στάδια διεληλυθέναι ἦσαν πρὸς τῇ κώμῃ ἔνθα Χειρίσοφος ηὐλίζετο .
perseus-eng2	Xenophon’s party were glad enough to see them, and turned over the invalids to them to carry on to the camp, while they themselves continued their journey, and before completing twenty stadia reached the village where Cheirisophus was quartered.

cts:urn:0032-006:4.5.23
glaux1.0-sentence	1808
perseus-grc2	ἐπεὶ δὲ συνεγένοντο ἀλλήλοις , ἔδοξε κατὰ τὰς κώμας ἀσφαλὲς εἶναι τὰς τάξεις σκηνοῦν .
perseus-eng2	When all had come together, the generals decided that it was safe for the different divisions of the army to take up quarters in the several villages.

cts:urn:0032-006:4.5.23
glaux1.0-sentence	1809
perseus-grc2	καὶ Χειρίσοφος μὲν αὐτοῦ ἔμενεν , οἱ δὲ ἄλλοι διαλαχόντες ἃς ἑώρων κώμας ἐπορεύοντο ἕκαστοι τοὺς ἑαυτῶν ἔχοντες .
perseus-eng2	Cheirisophus accordingly remained where he was, while the other generals distributed by lot the villages within sight, and all set off with their respective commands.

cts:urn:0032-006:4.5.24

cts:urn:0032-006:4.5.24

perseus-eng2	and with an active group of men he ran to the village which had fallen to Xenophon’s lot and there took possession of all the villagers, the village chief included, seventeen colts which were being reared for tribute to the King, and the village chief’s daughter, who had been married eight days before;

cts:urn:0032-006:4.5.24

perseus-eng2	her husband, however, was off hunting hares, and was not taken in the village.

cts:urn:0032-006:4.5.25
glaux1.0-sentence	1813

perseus-eng2	The houses here were underground, with a mouth like that of a well, but spacious below;

cts:urn:0032-006:4.5.25

perseus-eng2	and while entrances were tunnelled down for the beasts of burden, the human inhabitants descended by a ladder.

perseus-eng2	Here were also wheat, barley, and beans, and barleywine in large bowls.

cts:urn:0032-006:4.5.26
glaux1.0-sentence	1818

perseus-eng2	Floating on the top of this drink were the barley-grains and in it were straws, some larger and others smaller, without joints;

cts:urn:0032-006:4.5.27
glaux1.0-sentence	1819
perseus-grc2	τούτους ἔδει ὁπότε τις διψῴη λαβόντα εἰς τὸ στόμα μύζειν .
perseus-eng2	and when one was thirsty, he had to take these straws into his mouth and suck.

cts:urn:0032-006:4.5.27
glaux1.0-sentence	1820
perseus-grc2	καὶ πάνυ ἄκρατος ἦν , εἰ μή τις ὕδωρ ἐπιχέοι ·
perseus-eng2	It was an extremely strong drink unless one diluted it with water.

cts:urn:0032-006:4.5.27
glaux1.0-sentence	1821
perseus-grc2	καὶ πάνυ ἡδὺ συμμαθόντι τὸ πῶμα ἦν .
perseus-eng2	And it was extremely good when one was used to it.

cts:urn:0032-006:4.5.28
glaux1.0-sentence	1822
perseus-grc2	ὁ δὲ Ξενοφῶν τὸν ἄρχοντα τῆς κώμης ταύτης σύνδειπνον ἐποιήσατο καὶ θαρρεῖν αὐτὸν ἐκέλευε λέγων ὅτι οὔτε τῶν τέκνων στερήσοιτο τήν τε οἰκίαν αὐτοῦ ἀντεμπλήσαντες τῶν ἐπιτηδείων ἀπίασιν , ἢν ἀγαθόν τι τῷ στρατεύματι ἐξηγησάμενος φαίνηται ἔστ’ ἂν ἐν ἄλλῳ ἔθνει γένωνται .
perseus-eng2	Xenophon made the chief man of this village his guest at dinner and bade him be of good cheer, telling him that he should not be deprived of his children, and that before they went away they would fill his house with provisions by way of reward in case he should prove to have given the army good guidance until they should reach another tribe.

cts:urn:0032-006:4.5.29
glaux1.0-sentence	1823
perseus-grc2	ὁ δὲ ταῦτα ὑπισχνεῖτο , καὶ φιλοφρονούμενος οἶνον ἔφρασεν ἔνθα ἦν κατορωρυγμένος .
perseus-eng2	He promised to do this, and in a spirit of kindliness told them where there was wine buried.

cts:urn:0032-006:4.5.29
glaux1.0-sentence	1824
perseus-grc2	ταύτην μὲν τὴν νύκτα διασκηνήσαντες οὕτως ἐκοιμήθησαν ἐν πᾶσιν ἀφθόνοις πάντες οἱ στρατιῶται , ἐν φυλακῇ ἔχοντες τὸν κώμαρχον καὶ τὰ τέκνα αὐτοῦ ὁμοῦ ἐν ὀφθαλμοῖς .
perseus-eng2	 For that night, then, all Xenophon’s soldiers, in this village where they were thus separately quartered, went to bed amid an abundance of everything, keeping the village chief under guard and his children all together within sight.

cts:urn:0032-006:4.5.30
glaux1.0-sentence	1825
perseus-grc2	τῇ δ’ ἐπιούσῃ ἡμέρᾳ Ξενοφῶν λαβὼν τὸν κώμαρχον πρὸς Χειρίσοφον ἐπορεύετο ·
perseus-eng2	On the next day Xenophon took the village chief and set out to visit Cheirisophus;

cts:urn:0032-006:4.5.30
glaux1.0-sentence	1826

perseus-eng2	whenever he passed a village, he would turn aside to visit the troops quartered there, and everywhere he found them faring sumptuously and in fine spirits; there was no place from which the men would let them go until they had served them a luncheon,

cts:urn:0032-006:4.5.31
glaux1.0-sentence	1827
perseus-grc2	οὐκ ἦν δ’ ὅπου οὐ παρετίθεσαν ἐπὶ τὴν αὐτὴν τράπεζαν κρέα ἄρνεια , ἐρίφεια , χοίρεια , μόσχεια , ὀρνίθεια , σὺν πολλοῖς ἄρτοις τοῖς μὲν πυρίνοις τοῖς δὲ κριθίνοις .
perseus-eng2	and no place where they did not serve on the same table lamb, kid, pork, veal, and poultry, together with many loaves of bread, some of wheat and some of barley.

cts:urn:0032-006:4.5.32
glaux1.0-sentence	1828
perseus-grc2	ὁπότε δέ τις φιλοφρονούμενός τῳ βούλοιτο προπιεῖν , εἷλκεν ἐπὶ τὸν κρατῆρα , ἔνθεν ἐπικύψαντα ἔδει ῥοφοῦντα πίνειν ὥσπερ βοῦν .
perseus-eng2	And whenever a man wanted out of good fellowship to drink another’s health, he would draw him to the bowl, and then one had to stoop over and drink from it, sucking like an ox.

cts:urn:0032-006:4.5.32
glaux1.0-sentence	1829
perseus-grc2	καὶ τῷ κωμάρχῳ ἐδίδοσαν λαμβάνειν ὅ τι βούλοιτο .
perseus-eng2	To the village chief they offered the privilege of taking whatever he wanted.

cts:urn:0032-006:4.5.32
glaux1.0-sentence	1830

perseus-eng2	He declined for the most part to accept anything, but whenever he caught sight of one of his kinsmen, he would always take the man to his side.

cts:urn:0032-006:4.5.33
glaux1.0-sentence	1831
perseus-grc2	ἐπεὶ δ’ ἦλθον πρὸς Χειρίσοφον , κατελάμβανον κ- ἐκείνους σκηνοῦντας ἐστεφανωμένους τοῦ ξηροῦ χιλοῦ στεφάνοις , καὶ διακονοῦντας Ἀρμενίους παῖδας σὺν ταῖς βαρβαρικαῖς στολαῖς ·
perseus-eng2	Again, when they reached Cheirisophus, they found his troops also feasting in their quarters, crowned with wreaths of hay and served by Armenian boys in their strange, foreign dress;

cts:urn:0032-006:4.5.34
glaux1.0-sentence	1833

perseus-eng2	As soon as Cheirisophus and Xenophon had exchanged warm greetings, they together asked the village chief, through their Persian-speaking interpreter, what this land was.

cts:urn:0032-006:4.5.34

perseus-eng2	He answered, as tribute for the King;

perseus-eng2	and he said that the neighbouring country was that of the Chalybians, and told them where the road was.

cts:urn:0032-006:4.5.35
glaux1.0-sentence	1838
perseus-grc2	καὶ αὐτὸν τότε μὲν ᾤχετο ἄγων ὁ Ξενοφῶν πρὸς τοὺς ἑαυτοῦ οἰκέτας , καὶ ἵππον ὃν εἰλήφει παλαίτερον δίδωσι τῷ κωμάρχῳ ἀναθρέψαντι καταθῦσαι , ὅτι ἤκουεν αὐτὸν ἱερὸν εἶναι τοῦ Ἡλίου , δεδιὼς μὴ ἀποθάνῃ ·
perseus-eng2	Then Xenophon took the village chief back for the time to his own household, and gave him a horse that he had got when it was rather old, to fatten up and sacrifice, for he understood that it was sacred to the Sun-god. He did this out of fear that the horse might die.

cts:urn:0032-006:4.5.35

perseus-eng2	For it had been injured by the journey;

perseus-eng2	and he took for himself one of the colts and gave his captains also a colt apiece.

perseus-eng2	The horses of this region were smaller than the Persian horses, but very much more spirited.

cts:urn:0032-006:4.5.36

perseus-eng2	It was here also that the village chief instructed them about wrapping small bags round the feet of their horses and beasts of burden when they were going through the snow;

perseus-eng2	for without these bags the animals would sink in up to their bellies.

cts:urn:0032-006:4.6.1

perseus-eng2	When seven days had passed, Xenophon gave over the village chief to Cheirisophus to act as guide, leaving his family behind with the exception of his son, who was just coming into the prime of youth;

cts:urn:0032-006:4.6.1
glaux1.0-sentence	1845
perseus-grc2	τοῦτον δὲ Πλεισθένει Ἀμφιπολίτῃ δίδωσι φυλάττειν , ὅπως εἰ καλῶς ἡγήσοιτο , ἔχων καὶ τοῦτον ἀπίοι .
perseus-eng2	this son he gave into the keeping of Pleisthenes of  Amphipolis , in order that the father, if he should serve them well as guide, might take him also back with him.

cts:urn:0032-006:4.6.1

perseus-grc2	καὶ εἰς τὴν οἰκίαν αὐτοῦ εἰσεφόρησαν ὡς ἐδύναντο πλεῖστα , καὶ ἀναζεύξαντες ἐπορεύοντο .
perseus-eng2	Then, after putting into his house as large a quantity of supplies as they could, they broke camp and set out upon the march.

cts:urn:0032-006:4.6.2
glaux1.0-sentence	1847
perseus-grc2	ἡγεῖτο δ’ αὐτοῖς ὁ κώμαρχος λελυμένος διὰ χιόνος ·
perseus-eng2	The village chief, who was not bound, guided their way through the snow;

cts:urn:0032-006:4.6.2
glaux1.0-sentence	1848
perseus-grc2	καὶ ἤδη τε ἦν ἐν τῷ τρίτῳ σταθμῷ , καὶ Χειρίσοφος αὐτῷ ἐχαλεπάνθη ὅτι οὐκ εἰς κώμας ἤγαγεν .
perseus-eng2	but by the time they were on the third stage Cheirisophus got angry with him for not leading them to villages.

cts:urn:0032-006:4.6.2
glaux1.0-sentence	1849
perseus-grc2	ὁ δ’ ἔλεγεν ὅτι οὐκ εἶεν ἐν τῷ τόπῳ τούτῳ .
perseus-eng2	He replied that there were none in this region.

cts:urn:0032-006:4.6.3
glaux1.0-sentence	1850
perseus-grc2	ὁ δὲ Χειρίσοφος αὐτὸν ἔπαισεν , ἔδησε δ’ οὔ .
perseus-eng2	Then Cheirisophus struck him, but neglected to bind him.

cts:urn:0032-006:4.6.3
glaux1.0-sentence	1851
perseus-grc2	ἐκ δὲ τούτου ἐκεῖνος τῆς νυκτὸς ἀποδρὰς ᾤχετο καταλιπὼν τὸν υἱόν .
perseus-eng2	The result was that he stole away during the night, leaving his son behind.

cts:urn:0032-006:4.6.3
glaux1.0-sentence	1852
perseus-grc2	τοῦτό γε δὴ Χειρισόφῳ καὶ Ξενοφῶντι μόνον διάφορον ἐν τῇ πορείᾳ ἐγένετο , ἡ τοῦ ἡγεμόνος κάκωσις καὶ ἀμέλεια .
perseus-eng2	And this was the only cause of difference between Cheirisophus and Xenophon during the course of the march, this ill-treatment of the guide and carelessness in not guarding him.

cts:urn:0032-006:4.6.3
glaux1.0-sentence	1853
perseus-grc2	Πλεισθένης δὲ ἠράσθη τοῦ παιδὸς καὶ οἴκαδε κομίσας πιστοτάτῳ ἐχρῆτο .
perseus-eng2	Pleisthenes, however, fell in love with the boy, took him home with him, and found him absolutely faithful.

cts:urn:0032-006:4.6.4
glaux1.0-sentence	1854
perseus-grc2	μετὰ τοῦτο ἐπορεύθησαν ἑπτὰ σταθμοὺς ἀνὰ πέντε παρασάγγας τῆς ἡμέρας παρὰ τὸν Φᾶσιν ποταμόν , εὖρος πλεθριαῖον .
perseus-eng2	After this they marched seven stages at the rate of five parasangs a day to the Phasis river, which was a plethrum in width.

cts:urn:0032-006:4.6.5
glaux1.0-sentence	1855
perseus-grc2	ἐντεῦθεν ἐπορεύθησαν σταθμοὺς δύο παρασάγγας δέκα ·
perseus-eng2	From there they marched two stages, ten parasangs;

cts:urn:0032-006:4.6.5
glaux1.0-sentence	1856
perseus-grc2	ἐπὶ δὲ τῇ εἰς τὸ πεδίον ὑπερβολῇ ἀπήντησαν αὐτοῖς Χάλυβες καὶ Τάοχοι καὶ Φασιανοί .
perseus-eng2	and on the pass leading over to the plain they encountered a body of Chalybians, Taochians, and Phasians.

cts:urn:0032-006:4.6.6
glaux1.0-sentence	1857
perseus-grc2	Χειρίσοφος δ’ ἐπεὶ κατεῖδε τοὺς πολεμίους ἐπὶ τῇ ὑπερβολῇ , ἐπαύσατο πορευόμενος , ἀπέχων εἰς τριάκοντα σταδίους , ἵνα μὴ κατὰ κέρας ἄγων πλησιάσῃ τοῖς πολεμίοις ·
perseus-eng2	As soon as Cheirisophus caught sight of the enemy on the pass, he halted, while still at a distance of about thirty stadia, in order not to get near the enemy while his troops were marching in column;

cts:urn:0032-006:4.6.6
glaux1.0-sentence	1858
perseus-grc2	παρήγγειλε δὲ καὶ τοῖς ἄλλοις παράγειν τοὺς λόχους , ὅπως ἐπὶ φάλαγγος γένοιτο τὸ στράτευμα .
perseus-eng2	and he gave orders to the other officers also to move along their companies so as to bring the army into line of battle.

cts:urn:0032-006:4.6.7
glaux1.0-sentence	1859
perseus-grc2	ἐπεὶ δὲ ἦλθον οἱ ὀπισθοφύλακες , συνεκάλεσε στρατηγοὺς καὶ λοχαγούς , καὶ ἔλεξεν ὧδε .
perseus-eng2	When the rearguard had come up, he called generals and captains together and spoke as follows:

cts:urn:0032-006:4.6.7
glaux1.0-sentence	1860
perseus-grc2	οἱ μὲν πολέμιοι , ὡς ὁρᾶτε , κατέχουσι τὰς ὑπερβολὰς τοῦ ὄρους ·
perseus-eng2	The enemy, as you see, are in possession of the pass over the mountain.

cts:urn:0032-006:4.6.7
glaux1.0-sentence	1861
perseus-grc2	ὥρα δὲ βουλεύεσθαι ὅπως ὡς κάλλιστα ἀγωνιούμεθα .
perseus-eng2	It is time for us to take counsel as to how we can best make our fight.

cts:urn:0032-006:4.6.8
glaux1.0-sentence	1862
perseus-grc2	ἐμοὶ μὲν οὖν δοκεῖ παραγγεῖλαι μὲν ἀριστοποιεῖσθαι τοῖς στρατιώταις , ἡμᾶς δὲ βουλεύεσθαι εἴτε τήμερον εἴτε αὔριον δοκεῖ ὑπερβάλλειν τὸ ὄρος .
perseus-eng2	My own view is, that we should give orders to the soldiers to get their breakfast while we ourselves consider whether it is best to attempt to cross over the mountain today or to-morrow.

cts:urn:0032-006:4.6.9
glaux1.0-sentence	1863
perseus-grc2	ἐμοὶ δέ γε , ἔφη ὁ Κλεάνωρ , δοκεῖ , ἐπὰν τάχιστα ἀριστήσωμεν , ἐξοπλισαμένους ὡς κράτιστα ἰέναι ἐπὶ τοὺς ἄνδρας .
perseus-eng2	My opinion is," said Cleanor, "that as soon as we have breakfasted, we should arm ourselves and advance upon these men with all the strength we have.

cts:urn:0032-006:4.6.9
glaux1.0-sentence	1864
perseus-grc2	εἰ γὰρ διατρίψομεν τὴν τήμερον ἡμέραν , οἵ τε νῦν ἡμᾶς ὁρῶντες πολέμιοι θαρραλεώτεροι ἔσονται καὶ ἄλλους εἰκὸς τούτων θαρρούντων πλείους προσγενέσθαι .
perseus-eng2	For if we waste this day, not only will the enemy who are now looking at us become bolder, but others, in greater numbers, when these are once emboldened, are likely to join them.

cts:urn:0032-006:4.6.10
glaux1.0-sentence	1865
perseus-grc2	μετὰ τοῦτον Ξενοφῶν εἶπεν ·
perseus-eng2	After Cleanor had spoken, Xenophon said:

cts:urn:0032-006:4.6.10
glaux1.0-sentence	1866
perseus-grc2	ἐγὼ δ’ οὕτω γιγνώσκω .
perseus-eng2	And I think this way:

cts:urn:0032-006:4.6.10
glaux1.0-sentence	1867
perseus-grc2	εἰ μὲν ἀνάγκη ἐστὶ μάχεσθαι , τοῦτο δεῖ παρασκευάσασθαι , ὅπως ὡς κράτιστα μαχούμεθα ·
perseus-eng2	if it is necessary for us to fight, our preparation should have this end in view, to make the strongest possible fight;

cts:urn:0032-006:4.6.10
glaux1.0-sentence	1868
perseus-grc2	εἰ δὲ βουλόμεθα ὡς ῥᾷστα ὑπερβάλλειν , τοῦτό μοι δοκεῖ σκεπτέον εἶναι , ὅπως ὡς ἐλάχιστα μὲν τραύματα λάβωμεν , ὡς ἐλάχιστα δὲ σώματα ἀνδρῶν ἀποβάλωμεν .
perseus-eng2	but if we wish to effect a passage in the easiest way we can, then, in my opinion, our consideration should be on this point, how we may sustain the fewest wounds and sacrifice the fewest lives.

cts:urn:0032-006:4.6.11
glaux1.0-sentence	1869
perseus-grc2	τὸ μὲν οὖν ὄρος ἐστὶ τὸ ὁρώμενον πλέον ἢ ἐφ’ ἑξήκοντα στάδια , ἄνδρες δ’ οὐδαμοῦ φυλάττοντες ἡμᾶς φανεροί εἰσιν ἀλλ’ ἢ κατ’ αὐτὴν τὴν ὁδόν ·
perseus-eng2	Now this mountain—or the part of it that we see—extends over more than sixty stadia, but as for men to guard it against us, none are to be seen anywhere except on the road above;

cts:urn:0032-006:4.6.11
glaux1.0-sentence	1870
perseus-grc2	πολὺ οὖν κρεῖττον τοῦ ἐρήμου ὄρους καὶ κλέψαι τι πειρᾶσθαι λαθόντας καὶ ἁρπάσαι φθάσαντας , εἰ δυναίμεθα , μᾶλλον ἢ πρὸς ἰσχυρὰ χωρία καὶ ἀνθρώπους παρεσκευασμένους μάχεσθαι .
perseus-eng2	it is far better, therefore, to turn to the unoccupied part of the mountain and try either to steal a position by eluding the enemy’s observation or to seize it by getting ahead of them, in whatever way we can, rather than to fight against strong places and men prepared.

cts:urn:0032-006:4.6.12
glaux1.0-sentence	1871
perseus-grc2	πολὺ γὰρ ῥᾷον ὄρθιον ἀμαχεὶ ἰέναι ἢ ὁμαλὲς ἔνθεν καὶ ἔνθεν πολεμίων ὄντων , καὶ νύκτωρ ἀμαχεὶ μᾶλλον ἂν τὰ πρὸ ποδῶν ὁρῴη τις ἢ μεθ’ ἡμέραν μαχόμενος , καὶ ἡ τραχεῖα τοῖς ποσὶν ἀμαχεὶ ἰοῦσιν εὐμενεστέρα ἢ ἡ ὁμαλὴ τὰς κεφαλὰς βαλλομένοις .
perseus-eng2	For it is far easier to march uphill without fighting than over level ground with enemies on this side and that; one can see what is in front of him more easily by night if he is not fighting than by day if he is fighting; and the rough road is more comfortable to men who are going over it without fighting than the smooth road to men who are being pelted on the head.

cts:urn:0032-006:4.6.13
glaux1.0-sentence	1872
perseus-grc2	καὶ κλέψαι δ’ οὐκ ἀδύνατόν μοι δοκεῖ εἶναι , ἐξὸν μὲν νυκτὸς ἰέναι , ὡς μὴ ὁρᾶσθαι , ἐξὸν δ’ ἀπελθεῖν τοσοῦτον ὡς μὴ αἴσθησιν παρέχειν .
perseus-eng2	And as for stealing a position, that does not seem to me impossible, for we can go during the night so as not to be seen, and we can get far enough away from the enemy so as not to be heard.

cts:urn:0032-006:4.6.13
glaux1.0-sentence	1873
perseus-grc2	δοκοῦμεν δ’ ἄν μοι ταύτῃ προσποιούμενοι προσβάλλειν ἐρημοτέρῳ ἂν τῷ ὄρει χρῆσθαι ·
perseus-eng2	I do think, however, that if we should make a feint of attacking here, we should find the rest of the mountain all the more deserted.

cts:urn:0032-006:4.6.13
glaux1.0-sentence	1874
perseus-grc2	μένοιεν γὰρ ἂν αὐτοῦ μᾶλλον ἁθρόοι οἱ πολέμιοι .
perseus-eng2	For the enemy would be more likely to remain in a body where they are.

cts:urn:0032-006:4.6.14
glaux1.0-sentence	1875
perseus-grc2	ἀτὰρ τί ἐγὼ περὶ κλοπῆς συμβάλλομαι ;
perseus-eng2	But why should I be the man to make suggestions about stealing?

cts:urn:0032-006:4.6.14
glaux1.0-sentence	1876
perseus-grc2	ὑμᾶς γὰρ ἔγωγε , ὦ Χειρίσοφε , ἀκούω τοὺς Λακεδαιμονίους ὅσοι ἐστὲ τῶν ὁμοίων εὐθὺς ἐκ παίδων κλέπτειν μελετᾶν , καὶ οὐκ αἰσχρὸν εἶναι ἀλλὰ καλὸν κλέπτειν ὅσα μὴ κωλύει νόμος .
perseus-eng2	For, as I hear, Cheirisophus, you Lacedaemonians, at least those among you who belong to the peers, practise stealing even from childhood, and count it not disgraceful but honourable to steal anything that the law does not prevent you from taking.

cts:urn:0032-006:4.6.15
glaux1.0-sentence	1877
perseus-grc2	ὅπως δὲ ὡς κράτιστα κλέπτητε καὶ πειρᾶσθε λανθάνειν , νόμιμον ἄρα ὑμῖν ἐστιν , ἐὰν ληφθῆτε κλέπτοντες , μαστιγοῦσθαι .
perseus-eng2	And in order that you may steal with all possible skill and may try not to be caught at it, it is the law of your land that, if you are caught stealing, you are flogged.

cts:urn:0032-006:4.6.15
glaux1.0-sentence	1878
perseus-grc2	νῦν οὖν μάλα σοι καιρός ἐστιν ἐπιδείξασθαι τὴν παιδείαν , καὶ φυλάξασθαι μὴ ληφθῶμεν κλέπτοντες τοῦ ὄρους , ὡς μὴ πληγὰς λάβωμεν .
perseus-eng2	Now, therefore, is just the time for you to display your training, and to take care that we do not get caught stealing any of the mountain, so that we shall not get a beating.

cts:urn:0032-006:4.6.16
glaux1.0-sentence	1879
perseus-grc2	ἀλλὰ μέντοι , ἔφη ὁ Χειρίσοφος , κ- ἐγὼ ὑμᾶς τοὺς Ἀθηναίους ἀκούω δεινοὺς εἶναι κλέπτειν τὰ δημόσια , καὶ μάλα ὄντος δεινοῦ κινδύνου τῷ κλέπτοντι , καὶ τοὺς κρατίστους μέντοι μάλιστα , εἴπερ ὑμῖν οἱ κράτιστοι ἄρχειν ἀξιοῦνται ·
perseus-eng2	Well, for all that," said Cheirisophus, "I hear on my side that you Athenians are terribly clever at stealing the public funds, even though it is terribly dangerous for the stealer, and, in fact, that your best people do it most, at least if they really are your best who are deemed worthy to rule;

cts:urn:0032-006:4.6.16
glaux1.0-sentence	1880
perseus-grc2	ὥστε ὥρα καὶ σοὶ ἐπιδείκνυσθαι τὴν παιδείαν .
perseus-eng2	hence it is time for you also to be displaying your training.

cts:urn:0032-006:4.6.17
glaux1.0-sentence	1881
perseus-grc2	ἐγὼ μὲν τοίνυν , ἔφη ὁ Ξενοφῶν , ἕτοιμός εἰμι τοὺς ὀπισθοφύλακας ἔχων , ἐπειδὰν δειπνήσωμεν , ἰέναι καταληψόμενος τὸ ὄρος .
perseus-eng2	Well," said Xenophon, "I am ready to set out with the rearguard, as soon as we have dined, to seize possession of the mountain.

cts:urn:0032-006:4.6.17

perseus-eng2	And I have guides, too;

cts:urn:0032-006:4.6.17

perseus-eng2	From these fellows I also learn that the mountain is not impassable, but is pastured with goats and cattle;

cts:urn:0032-006:4.6.17
glaux1.0-sentence	1885

perseus-eng2	therefore if we once get possession of any part of the mountain, our pack animals also will find it passable.

cts:urn:0032-006:4.6.18

perseus-eng2	And I hope that the enemy will remove themselves from our way as soon as they see us on a level with them upon the heights;

cts:urn:0032-006:4.6.18

perseus-eng2	for they are not willing now to come down and meet us on our level.

cts:urn:0032-006:4.6.19

perseus-eng2	But why should you be the one to go, and leave your post with the rearguard?

cts:urn:0032-006:4.6.19

perseus-eng2	Send others rather, unless some good men offer themselves as volunteers.

cts:urn:0032-006:4.6.20
glaux1.0-sentence	1891

cts:urn:0032-006:4.6.21
glaux1.0-sentence	1894

perseus-eng2	and immediately after breakfast Cheirisophus led the whole army forward about ten stadia toward the enemy, in order to make them quite certain that he was going to advance upon them by this road.

cts:urn:0032-006:4.6.22

perseus-grc2	ἐπειδὴ δὲ ἐδείπνησαν καὶ νὺξ ἐγένετο , οἱ μὲν ταχθέντες ᾤχοντο , καὶ καταλαμβάνουσι τὸ ὄρος , οἱ δὲ ἄλλοι αὐτοῦ ἀνεπαύοντο .
perseus-eng2	After they had had dinner and night had come on, the men appointed to the task set forward and gained possession of the mountain, while the remainder of the troops rested where they were.

cts:urn:0032-006:4.6.22

perseus-grc2	οἱ δὲ πολέμιοι ἐπεὶ ᾔσθοντο τὸ ὄρος ἐχόμενον , ἐγρηγόρεσαν καὶ ἔκαιον πυρὰ πολλὰ διὰ νυκτός .
perseus-eng2	And when the enemy perceived that the mountain was occupied, they   staid   stayed   awake and kept many fires burning through the night.

cts:urn:0032-006:4.6.23

perseus-grc2	ἐπειδὴ δὲ ἡμέρα ἐγένετο Χειρίσοφος μὲν θυσάμενος ἦγε κατὰ τὴν ὁδόν , οἱ δὲ τὸ ὄρος καταλαβόντες κατὰ τὰ ἄκρα ἐπῇσαν .
perseus-eng2	As soon as day came Cheirisophus offered sacrifice and led the army forward along the road, while the party that had seized the mountain, advanced along the heights.

cts:urn:0032-006:4.6.24
glaux1.0-sentence	1898
perseus-grc2	τῶν δὲ πολεμίων τὸ μὲν πολὺ ἔμενεν ἐπὶ τῇ ὑπερβολῇ τοῦ ὄρους , μέρος δ’ αὐτῶν ἀπήντα τοῖς κατὰ τὰ ἄκρα .
perseus-eng2	As for the enemy, the majority remained at the pass over the mountain, but a part of them went to meet the detachment on the heights.

cts:urn:0032-006:4.6.24
glaux1.0-sentence	1899
perseus-grc2	πρὶν δὲ ὁμοῦ εἶναι τοὺς πολλοὺς ἀλλήλοις , συμμιγνύασιν οἱ κατὰ τὰ ἄκρα , καὶ νικῶσιν οἱ Ἕλληνες καὶ διώκουσιν .
perseus-eng2	Now before the two main bodies got near one another, those upon the heights came to close combat, and the Greeks were victorious and began their pursuit.

cts:urn:0032-006:4.6.25
glaux1.0-sentence	1900
perseus-grc2	ἐν τούτῳ δὲ καὶ οἱ ἐκ τοῦ πεδίου οἱ μὲν πελτασταὶ τῶν Ἑλλήνων δρόμῳ ἔθεον πρὸς τοὺς παρατεταγμένους , Χειρίσοφος δὲ βάδην ταχὺ ἐφείπετο σὺν τοῖς ὁπλίταις .
perseus-eng2	Meanwhile the main body of the Greeks was moving upward from the plain, the peltasts charging at a run upon the enemy’s battleline and Cheirisophus following at a quick-step with the hoplites.

cts:urn:0032-006:4.6.26
glaux1.0-sentence	1901
perseus-grc2	οἱ δὲ πολέμιοι οἱ ἐπὶ τῇ ὁδῷ ἐπειδὴ τὸ ἄνω ἑώρων ἡττώμενον , φεύγουσι ·
perseus-eng2	But the enemy on the road no sooner saw their detachment on the heights being defeated than they took to flight;

cts:urn:0032-006:4.6.26
glaux1.0-sentence	1902
perseus-grc2	καὶ ἀπέθανον μὲν οὐ πολλοὶ αὐτῶν , γέρρα δὲ πάμπολλα ἐλήφθη ·
perseus-eng2	and while not many of them were killed, a great number of wicker shields were captured.

cts:urn:0032-006:4.6.26
glaux1.0-sentence	1903

perseus-eng2	These the Greeks rendered useless by slashing them with their sabres.

cts:urn:0032-006:4.6.27
glaux1.0-sentence	1904

perseus-eng2	When they had climbed to the top of the pass, after offering sacrifice and setting up a trophy they descended into the plain on the farther side, and reached villages full of many good things.

cts:urn:0032-006:4.7.1
glaux1.0-sentence	1905
perseus-grc2	ἐκ δὲ τούτων ἐπορεύθησαν εἰς Ταόχους σταθμοὺς πέντε παρασάγγας τριάκοντα ·
perseus-eng2	After this they marched into the country of the Taochians five stages, thirty parasangs;

cts:urn:0032-006:4.7.1
glaux1.0-sentence	1906
perseus-grc2	καὶ τὰ ἐπιτήδεια ἐπέλειπε ·
perseus-eng2	and their provisions were running low.

cts:urn:0032-006:4.7.1
glaux1.0-sentence	1907
perseus-grc2	χωρία γὰρ ᾤκουν ἰσχυρὰ οἱ Τάοχοι , ἐν οἷς καὶ τὰ ἐπιτήδεια ἅπαντα εἶχον ἀνακεκομισμένοι .
perseus-eng2	For the Taochians dwelt in strongholds, and in these strongholds they kept all their provisions stored away.

cts:urn:0032-006:4.7.2

perseus-eng2	for enemies were following behind them from the district that was in flames, and the rearguard had killed some of them and captured others by setting an ambush, and had also taken about twenty wicker shields covered with raw, shaggy ox-hides.

cts:urn:0032-006:4.7.23
glaux1.0-sentence	1974
perseus-grc2	ἐπειδὴ δὲ βοὴ πλείων τε ἐγίγνετο καὶ ἐγγύτερον καὶ οἱ ἀεὶ ἐπιόντες ἔθεον δρόμῳ ἐπὶ τοὺς ἀεὶ βοῶντας καὶ πολλῷ μείζων ἐγίγνετο ἡ βοὴ ὅσῳ δὴ πλείους ἐγίγνοντο , ἐδόκει δὴ μεῖζόν τι εἶναι τῷ Ξενοφῶντι , καὶ ἀναβὰς ἐφ’ ἵππον καὶ Λύκιον καὶ τοὺς ἱππέας ἀναλαβὼν παρεβοήθει ·
perseus-eng2	But as the shout kept getting louder and nearer, as the successive ranks that came up all began to run at full speed toward the ranks ahead that were one after another joining in the shout, and as the shout kept growing far louder as the number of men grew steadily greater, it became quite clear to Xenophon that here was something of unusual importance; so he mounted a horse, took with him Lycius and the cavalry, and pushed ahead to lend aid.

perseus-eng2	on the other hand, if we are formed in a line a few ranks deep, it would be nothing surprising if our line should be cut through by a multitude both of missiles and men falling upon us in a mass;

perseus-eng2	But it seems to me we should form the companies in column and, by leaving spaces between them, cover enough ground so that the outermost companies should get beyond the enemy’s wings;

cts:urn:0032-006:4.8.12
glaux1.0-sentence	2016
perseus-grc2	καὶ οὕτως ἐσόμεθα τῆς τε τῶν πολεμίων φάλαγγος ἔξω οἱ ἔσχατοι λόχοι , καὶ ὀρθίους ἄγοντες οἱ κράτιστοι ἡμῶν πρῶτοι προσίασιν , ᾗ τε ἂν εὔοδον ᾖ , ταύτῃ ἕκαστος ἄξει ὁ λόχος .
perseus-eng2	in this way not only shall we outflank the enemy’s line, but advancing in column our best men will be in the van of the attack, and wherever it is good going, there each captain will lead forward his men.

cts:urn:0032-006:4.8.13

perseus-eng2	And it will not be easy for the enemy to push into the space between the columns when there are companies on this side and that, and not any easier for him to cut through a company that is advancing in column.

perseus-eng2	and if one single company can somehow climb to the summit, not a man of the enemy will stand any longer.

perseus-eng2	and when the enemy saw this, they ran out, some to the right and others to the left, to confront them, with the result that their line was pulled apart and a large portion of it in the centre was left deserted.

cts:urn:0032-006:4.8.18
glaux1.0-sentence	2030

perseus-eng2	Then the peltasts of the Arcadian division, who were commanded by Aeschines the Acarnanian, getting the idea that the enemy were in flight, set up a shout and began to run;

cts:urn:0032-006:4.8.18
glaux1.0-sentence	2031
perseus-grc2	καὶ οὗτοι πρῶτοι ἐπὶ τὸ ὄρος ἀναβαίνουσι ·

cts:urn:0032-006:4.8.18

cts:urn:0032-006:4.8.19
glaux1.0-sentence	2033

cts:urn:0032-006:4.8.19
glaux1.0-sentence	2034
perseus-grc2	οἱ δὲ Ἕλληνες ἀναβάντες ἐστρατοπεδεύοντο ἐν πολλαῖς κώμαις καὶ τ- ἐπιτήδεια πολλὰ ἐχούσαις .
perseus-eng2	After accomplishing the ascent the Greeks took up quarters in numerous villages, which contained provisions in abundance.

cts:urn:0032-006:4.8.20
glaux1.0-sentence	2035
perseus-grc2	καὶ τὰ μὲν ἄλλα οὐδὲν ὅ τι καὶ ἐθαύμασαν ·
perseus-eng2	Now for the most part there was nothing here which they really found strange;

cts:urn:0032-006:4.8.20
glaux1.0-sentence	2036
perseus-grc2	τὰ δὲ σμήνη πολλὰ ἦν αὐτόθι , καὶ τῶν κηρίων ὅσοι ἔφαγον τῶν στρατιωτῶν πάντες ἄφρονές τε ἐγίγνοντο καὶ ἤμουν καὶ κάτω διεχώρει αὐτοῖς καὶ ὀρθὸς οὐδεὶς ἐδύνατο ἵστασθαι , ἀλλ’ οἱ μὲν ὀλίγον ἐδηδοκότες σφόδρα μεθύουσιν ἐῴκεσαν , οἱ δὲ πολὺ μαινομένοις , οἱ δὲ καὶ ἀποθνῄσκουσιν .
perseus-eng2	but the swarms of bees in the neighbourhood were numerous, and the soldiers who ate of the honey all went off their heads, and suffered from vomiting and diarrhoea, and not one of them could stand up, but those who had eaten a little were like people exceedingly drunk, while those who had eaten a great deal seemed like crazy, or even, in some cases, dying men.

cts:urn:0032-006:4.8.21
glaux1.0-sentence	2037
perseus-grc2	ἔκειντο δὲ οὕτω πολλοὶ ὥσπερ τροπῆς γεγενημένης , καὶ πολλὴ ἦν ἀθυμία .
perseus-eng2	So they lay there in great numbers as though the army had suffered a defeat, and great despondency prevailed.

cts:urn:0032-006:4.8.21
glaux1.0-sentence	2038
perseus-grc2	τῇ δ’ ὑστεραίᾳ ἀπέθανε μὲν οὐδείς , ἀμφὶ δὲ τὴν αὐτήν πως ὥραν ἀνεφρόνουν ·
perseus-eng2	On the next day, however, no one had died, and at approximately the same hour as they had eaten the honey they began to come to their senses;

cts:urn:0032-006:4.8.21
glaux1.0-sentence	2039
perseus-grc2	τρίτῃ δὲ καὶ τετάρτῃ ἀνίσταντο ὥσπερ ἐκ φαρμακοποσίας .

cts:urn:0032-006:4.8.22
glaux1.0-sentence	2040
perseus-grc2	ἐντεῦθεν δ’ ἐπορεύθησαν δύο σταθμοὺς παρασάγγας ἑπτά , καὶ ἦλθον ἐπὶ θάλατταν εἰς Τραπεζοῦντα πόλιν Ἑλληνίδα οἰκουμένην ἐν τῷ Εὐξείνῳ Πόντῳ , Σινωπέων ἀποικίαν , ἐν τῇ Κόλχων χώρᾳ .

cts:urn:0032-006:4.8.22
glaux1.0-sentence	2041

perseus-eng2	There they remained about thirty days in the villages of the Colchians.

cts:urn:0032-006:4.8.23
glaux1.0-sentence	2042

perseus-eng2	From these as a base they plundered  Colchis .

cts:urn:0032-006:4.8.23

perseus-eng2	And the Trapezuntians supplied a market for the army, received the Greeks kindly, and gave them oxen, barley-meal, and wine as gifts of hospitality.

cts:urn:0032-006:4.8.24

perseus-eng2	They likewise took part in negotiations with the Greeks in behalf of the near-by Colchians, who dwelt for the most part on the plain, and from these people also the Greeks received hospitable gifts of oxen.

cts:urn:0032-006:4.8.25

perseus-eng2	A sufficient number of oxen had come to them so that they could pay their thank-offerings to Zeus for deliverance, to Heracles for guidance, and to the other gods according as they had vowed.

cts:urn:0032-006:4.8.25

cts:urn:0032-006:4.8.25

perseus-eng2	and they chose Dracontius, a Spartan, who had been exiled from home as a boy because he had accidentally killed another boy with the stroke of a dagger, to look out for a race-course and to act as manager of the games.

cts:urn:0032-006:4.8.26

perseus-eng2	When, accordingly, the sacrifice had been completed, they turned over the hides to Dracontius and bade him lead the way to the place he had fixed upon for his race-course.

cts:urn:0032-006:4.8.26
glaux1.0-sentence	2050

perseus-eng2	He pointed out the precise spot where they chanced to be standing, and said "This hill is superb for running, wherever you please."

perseus-eng2	The events were, a stadium race and it made a fine spectacle.

cts:urn:0032-006:5.1.1
glaux1.0-sentence	2060
perseus-grc2	ὅσα μὲν δὴ ἐν τῇ ἀναβάσει τῇ μετὰ Κύρου ἔπραξαν οἱ Ἕλληνες , καὶ ἐν τῇ πορείᾳ τῇ μέχρι ἐπὶ θάλατταν τὴν ἐν τῷ Εὐξείνῳ Πόντῳ , καὶ ὡς εἰς Τραπεζοῦντα Ἑλληνίδα πόλιν ἀφίκοντο , καὶ ὡς ἀπέθυσαν ἃ εὔξαντο σωτήρια θύειν ἔνθα πρῶτον εἰς φιλίαν γῆν ἀφίκοντο , ἐν τῷ πρόσθεν λόγῳ δεδήλωται .
perseus-eng2
[The preceding narrative has described all that the Greeks did on their upward march with  Cyrus  and on their journey to the shore of the  Euxine Sea , how they arrived at the Greek city of  Trapezus , and how they paid the thankofferings for deliverance which they had vowed to sacrifice at the place where they should first reach a friendly land.]

glaux1.0-sentence	2061

cts:urn:0032-006:5.1.2
glaux1.0-sentence	2062

cts:urn:0032-006:5.1.2
glaux1.0-sentence	2063

perseus-eng2	Well, I, for my part, gentlemen," he said, "am tired by this time of packing up and walking and running and carrying my arms and being in line and standing guard and fighting, and what I long for now is to be rid of these toils, since we have the sea, and to sail the rest of the way, and so reach  Greece  stretched out on my back, like Odysseus.

cts:urn:0032-006:5.1.4

cts:urn:0032-006:5.1.4

perseus-eng2	For we neither have an adequate market, nor have we, with some few exceptions, the means wherewith to buy;

cts:urn:0032-006:5.1.6

perseus-eng2	but the territory is hostile.

cts:urn:0032-006:5.1.6

perseus-eng2	Hence there is danger that many of you will perish if you set out after provisions carelessly and unguardedly.

cts:urn:0032-006:5.1.7

perseus-eng2	Rather, it seems to me that you ought to get your provisions in foraging parties and not roam about at random, in order that you may be kept safe, and that we generals ought to have charge of this matter.

perseus-eng2	Listen, then, to this further point.

cts:urn:0032-006:5.1.8
glaux1.0-sentence	2082
perseus-grc2	ἐπὶ λείαν γὰρ ὑμῶν ἐκπορεύσονταί τινες .
perseus-eng2	Some of you are to journey forth after plunder.

cts:urn:0032-006:5.1.8
glaux1.0-sentence	2083
perseus-grc2	οἴομαι οὖν βέλτιστον εἶναι ἡμῖν εἰπεῖν τὸν μέλλοντα ἐξιέναι , φράζειν δὲ καὶ ὅποι , ἵνα καὶ τὸ πλῆθος εἰδῶμεν τῶν ἐξιόντων καὶ τῶν μενόντων καὶ ξυμπαρασκευάζωμεν , ἐάν τι δέῃ , κἂν βοηθῆσαί τισι καιρὸς ᾖ , εἰδῶμεν ὅποι δεήσει βοηθεῖν , καὶ ἐάν τις τῶν ἀπειροτέρων ἐγχειρῇ ποι , ξυμβουλεύωμεν πειρώμενοι εἰδέναι τὴν δύναμιν ἐφ’ οὓς ἂν ἴωσιν .
perseus-eng2	Now I think it is best for the man who is going out to inform us of the fact and to tell us also whither he is going, in order that we may know the number of men who are going out and the number who are staying behind; then we can help, if need be, in making preparations, and if there be occasion to go to any one’s assistance, we shall know whither we are to go with such assistance, and if a man who is without experience is making an attempt in any quarter, we can advise him by trying to ascertain the strength of those against whom he may be going.

cts:urn:0032-006:5.1.9
glaux1.0-sentence	2084

perseus-eng2	This proposal also was adopted.

perseus-eng2	Our enemies have leisure for plundering and they are plotting against us—quite properly.

cts:urn:0032-006:5.1.9

cts:urn:0032-006:5.1.9

perseus-eng2	So it seems to me that we ought to have guards around our camp;

cts:urn:0032-006:5.1.9
glaux1.0-sentence	2090
perseus-grc2	ἐὰν οὖν κατὰ μέρος μερισθέντες φυλάττωμεν καὶ σκοπῶμεν , ἧττον ἂν δύναιντο ἡμᾶς θηρᾶν οἱ πολέμιοι .
perseus-eng2	supposing, then, that we take turns in standing guard and keeping watch, the enemy would be less able to harry us.

cts:urn:0032-006:5.1.9

cts:urn:0032-006:5.1.10

perseus-eng2	If we knew beyond doubt that Cheirisophus would bring back with him an adequate number of ships, there would be no need of what I am about to say;

cts:urn:0032-006:5.1.10
glaux1.0-sentence	2093
perseus-grc2	νῦν δ’ ἐπεὶ τοῦτο ἄδηλον , δοκεῖ μοι πειρᾶσθαι πλοῖα συμπαρασκευάζειν καὶ αὐτόθεν .
perseus-eng2	but since in fact that is uncertain, I think we should try to do our part by procuring ships here also.

cts:urn:0032-006:5.1.10
glaux1.0-sentence	2094
perseus-grc2	ἢν μὲν γὰρ ἔλθῃ , ὑπαρχόντων ἐνθάδε ἐν ἀφθονωτέροις πλευσόμεθα ·
perseus-eng2	For if he does bring enough, then with those at hand here we shall have a more abundant supply to sail in.

cts:urn:0032-006:5.1.10
glaux1.0-sentence	2095
perseus-grc2	ἢν δὲ μὴ ἄγῃ , τοῖς ἐνθάδε χρησόμεθα .
perseus-eng2	But if he does not, we shall use those which we have here.

cts:urn:0032-006:5.1.11
glaux1.0-sentence	2096
perseus-grc2	ὁρῶ δὲ ἐγὼ πλοῖα πολλάκις παραπλέοντα ·
perseus-eng2	Now I see ships sailing past frequently.

cts:urn:0032-006:5.1.11
glaux1.0-sentence	2097
perseus-grc2	εἰ οὖν αἰτησάμενοι παρὰ Τραπεζουντίων μακρὰ πλοῖα κατάγοιμεν καὶ φυλάττοιμεν αὐτά , τὰ πηδάλια παραλυόμενοι , ἕως ἂν ἱκανὰ τὰ ἄξοντα γένηται , ἴσως ἂν οὐκ ἀπορήσαιμεν κομιδῆς οἵας δεόμεθα .
perseus-eng2	If we can get the Trapezuntians to give us men-of-war and so bring these ships into port and keep them under guard, unshipping their rudders meanwhile, until we get enough to carry us, perhaps we should not lack such means of transport as we need.

cts:urn:0032-006:5.1.11
glaux1.0-sentence	2098
perseus-grc2	ἔδοξε καὶ ταῦτα .
perseus-eng2	This proposal also was adopted.

cts:urn:0032-006:5.1.12
glaux1.0-sentence	2099
perseus-grc2	ἐννοήσατε δ’ , ἔφη , εἰ εἰκὸς καὶ τρέφειν ἀπὸ κοινοῦ οὓς ἂν καταγάγωμεν ὅσον ἂν χρόνον ἡμῶν ἕνεκεν μένωσι , καὶ ναῦλον ξυνθέσθαι , ὅπως ὠφελοῦντες καὶ ὠφελῶνται .
perseus-eng2	Again," he said, "do you not think it reasonable that we should maintain from our common fund the sailors we thus bring into port for as long a time as they may be waiting for our sakes, and that we should agree upon a price for our passage, so that in conferring a benefit upon us they may also benefit themselves?

cts:urn:0032-006:5.1.12
glaux1.0-sentence	2100
perseus-grc2	ἔδοξε καὶ ταῦτα .
perseus-eng2	This proposal also was adopted.

cts:urn:0032-006:5.1.13
glaux1.0-sentence	2101
perseus-grc2	δοκεῖ τοίνυν μοι , ἔφη , ἢν ἄρα καὶ ταῦτα ἡμῖν μὴ ἐκπεραίνηται ὥστε ἀρκεῖν πλοῖα , τὰς ὁδοὺς ἃς δυσπόρους ἀκούομεν εἶναι ταῖς παρὰ θάλατταν οἰκούσαις πόλεσιν ἐντείλασθαι ὁδοποιεῖν ·
perseus-eng2	Now it seems to me," he continued, "that if perchance this plan also shall fail to provide us with enough ships, we must turn to the roads, which we hear are difficult to travel, and direct the cities that are situated along the sea to repair them;

cts:urn:0032-006:5.1.13
glaux1.0-sentence	2102
perseus-grc2	πείσονται γὰρ καὶ διὰ τὸ φοβεῖσθαι καὶ διὰ τὸ βούλεσθαι ἡμῶν ἀπαλλαγῆναι .
perseus-eng2	for they will obey, not only from fear, but also from the desire to be rid of us.

cts:urn:0032-006:5.1.14
glaux1.0-sentence	2103

perseus-eng2	At this the soldiers set up a shout, saying that they did not want to go by land.

cts:urn:0032-006:5.1.14
glaux1.0-sentence	2104
perseus-grc2	ὁ δὲ ὡς ἔγνω τὴν ἀφροσύνην αὐτῶν , ἐπεψήφισε μὲν οὐδέν , τὰς δὲ πόλεις ἑκούσας ἔπεισεν ὁδοποιεῖν , λέγων ὅτι θᾶττον ἀπαλλάξονται , ἢν εὔποροι γένωνται αἱ ὁδοί .
perseus-eng2	And Xenophon, realizing their foolishness, did not put any proposal regarding this matter to vote, but persuaded the cities to repair the roads voluntarily, urging that they would be rid of the army the more quickly if the roads should be made easy to travel.

cts:urn:0032-006:5.1.15
glaux1.0-sentence	2105
perseus-grc2	ἔλαβον δὲ καὶ πεντηκόντορον παρὰ τῶν Τραπεζουντίων , ᾗ ἐπέστησαν Δέξιππον Λάκωνα περίοικον .
perseus-eng2	Furthermore, they got a fifty-oared warship from the Trapezuntians, and put it under the command of Dexippus, a Laconian perioecus.

cts:urn:0032-006:5.1.15
glaux1.0-sentence	2106
perseus-grc2	οὗτος ἀμελήσας τοῦ ξυλλέγειν πλοῖα ἀποδρὰς ᾤχετο ἔξω τοῦ Πόντου , ἔχων τὴν ναῦν .
perseus-eng2	This fellow, however, paying no heed to the duty of collecting vessels, slipped away with his man-of-war and left the Euxine.

cts:urn:0032-006:5.1.15

perseus-eng2	He did indeed get his deserts afterwards;

cts:urn:0032-006:5.1.15

perseus-eng2	for while engaged in some intrigue at the court of Seuthes in  Thrace  he was killed by Nicander the Laconian.

cts:urn:0032-006:5.1.16

perseus-eng2	They also got a thirty-oared galley, and put it under the command of Polycrates the Athenian, who brought in to the camp all the merchant vessels that he captured.

cts:urn:0032-006:5.1.16
glaux1.0-sentence	2110

perseus-eng2	And they would unload the cargoes, in case the ships had any, and put them under guard, in order to keep these safe and to use the vessels themselves for transport service.

cts:urn:0032-006:5.1.17

perseus-eng2	While these things were going on, the Greeks were making forays in quest of booty, and while some parties would secure it, others did not.

cts:urn:0032-006:5.1.17

perseus-grc2	Κλεαίνετος δ’ ἐξαγαγὼν καὶ τὸν ἑαυτοῦ καὶ ἄλλον λόχον πρὸς χωρίον χαλεπὸν αὐτός τε ἀπέθανε καὶ ἄλλοι πολλοὶ τῶν σὺν αὐτῷ .
perseus-eng2	And in one case, when Cleaenetus led forth his own company and another against a difficult stronghold, the commander himself was killed and many of his men besides.

cts:urn:0032-006:5.2.1

perseus-eng2	The time came when it was no longer possible to obtain provisions and return to the camp on the same day. Then Xenophon took some Trapezuntians for guides and led forth half the army to the country of the Drilae, leaving the other half behind to guard the camp.

perseus-eng2	For the Colchians, since they had been driven out of their houses, were now gathered together in one great body and had taken a position on the heights above the camp.

perseus-eng2	For the Trapezuntians would not lead the Greeks to districts from which provisions could be secured easily.

perseus-eng2	When the Greeks had reached the highlands, the Drilae set fire to such of their strongholds as seemed to them easy to capture, and fell back;

perseus-eng2	Now the peltasts, who had run five or six stadia ahead of the hoplites, crossed this ravine and, seeing quantities of sheep and other property, essayed an attack upon the stronghold;

perseus-eng2	But when they found themselves unable with all their fighting to capture the place (for there was a wide trench around it, backed by a rampart, and upon the rampart palisades had been set and wooden towers constructed at frequent intervals), their next move was to try to withdraw;

perseus-eng2	To get away by running proved impossible, inasmuch as the descent from the stronghold to the ravine only allowed them to go in single file, and they accordingly sent a messenger to Xenophon.

cts:urn:0032-006:5.2.8

perseus-eng2	Upon hearing this message Xenophon led on to the ravine, ordered the hoplites to halt there under arms, and himself crossed over with the captains and looked about to see whether it was better to withdraw the troops that had already crossed, or to lead over the hoplites also, on the presumption that the stronghold could be captured.

cts:urn:0032-006:5.2.9
glaux1.0-sentence	2136

perseus-eng2	The withdrawal, it seemed clear, could not be accomplished without the loss of many lives, while the capture of the place, in the opinion of the captains, was feasible, and Xenophon fell in with their opinion, in reliance upon his sacrifices;

cts:urn:0032-006:5.2.9

perseus-eng2	for the seers had declared that while there would be fighting to do, the issue of the expedition would be fortunate.

cts:urn:0032-006:5.2.10

perseus-eng2	Accordingly he sent the captains to bring over the hoplites, while he himself remained on the further side, having drawn back the entire body of peltasts and forbidding any one to shoot at long range.

cts:urn:0032-006:5.2.11

cts:urn:0032-006:5.2.11

perseus-eng2	for near one another were the captains who had all the time been vieing with one another in valour.

cts:urn:0032-006:5.2.12

perseus-eng2	Meanwhile Xenophon passed word to all the peltasts to advance with hand on the thong, so that they could discharge their javelins when the signal should be given, to the bowmen to have their arrows upon the string, ready to shoot upon the signal, and to the slingers to have their bags full of stones;

cts:urn:0032-006:5.2.12

perseus-eng2	and he despatched the proper persons to look after all these things.

cts:urn:0032-006:5.2.13
glaux1.0-sentence	2144
perseus-grc2	ἐπεὶ δὲ πάντα παρεσκεύαστο καὶ οἱ λοχαγοὶ καὶ οἱ ὑπολόχαγοι καὶ οἱ ἀξιοῦντες τούτων μὴ χείρους εἶναι πάντες παρατεταγμένοι ἦσαν , καὶ ἀλλήλους μὲν δὴ ξυνεώρων ( μηνοειδὴς γὰρ διὰ τὸ χωρίον ἡ τάξις ἦν ) ·
perseus-eng2	When all preparations had been made and the captains, lieutenants, and those among the men who claimed to be not inferior to them in bravery were all grouped together in the line and, moreover, watching one another (for the line was crescent-shaped, to conform with the position they were attacking),

cts:urn:0032-006:5.2.14
glaux1.0-sentence	2145
perseus-grc2	ἐπεὶ δ’ ἐπαιάνισαν καὶ ἡ σάλπιγξ ἐφθέγξατο , ἅμα τε τῷ Ἐνυαλίῳ ἠλέλιξαν καὶ ἔθεον δρόμῳ οἱ ὁπλῖται , καὶ τὰ βέλη ὁμοῦ ἐφέρετο , λόγχαι , τοξεύματα , σφενδόναι , πλεῖστοι δ’ ἐκ τῶν χειρῶν λίθοι , ἦσαν δὲ οἳ καὶ πῦρ προσέφερον .
perseus-eng2	then they struck up the paean and the trumpet sounded, and then, at the same moment, they raised the war cry to Enyalius, the hoplites charged forward on the run, and the missiles began to fly all together—spears, arrows, sling-stones, and very many stones thrown by hand, while some of the men employed firebrands also.

cts:urn:0032-006:5.2.15
glaux1.0-sentence	2146
perseus-grc2	ὑπὸ δὲ τοῦ πλήθους τῶν βελῶν ἔλιπον οἱ πολέμιοι τά τε σταυρώματα καὶ τὰς τύρσεις ·
perseus-eng2	By reason of the quantity of the missiles the enemy abandoned both their ramparts and their towers.

cts:urn:0032-006:5.2.15
glaux1.0-sentence	2147
perseus-grc2	ὥστε Ἀγασίας Στυμφάλιος καταθέμενος τὰ ὅπλα ἐν χιτῶνι μόνον ἀνέβη , καὶ ἄλλος ἄλλον εἷλκε , καὶ ἄλλος ἀνεβεβήκει , καὶ ἡλώκει τὸ χωρίον , ὡς ἐδόκει .
perseus-eng2	The result was that Agasias the Stymphalian, putting aside his arms and clad only in his tunic, climbed up, then pulled up another man, and meanwhile another had made the climb, so that the capture of the stronghold was accomplished, as it seemed.

cts:urn:0032-006:5.2.16
glaux1.0-sentence	2148

perseus-eng2	Thereupon the peltasts and the light troops rushed in and proceeded to snatch whatever plunder they severally could;

cts:urn:0032-006:5.2.16

cts:urn:0032-006:5.2.17
glaux1.0-sentence	2151

perseus-eng2	After no long interval a shout arose within and men came pouring forth in flight, some carrying with them what they had seized, then soon a number of men that were wounded;

cts:urn:0032-006:5.2.17

perseus-grc2	καὶ πολὺς ἦν ὠθισμὸς ἀμφὶ τὰ θύρετρα .

cts:urn:0032-006:5.2.17
glaux1.0-sentence	2153

perseus-eng2	When those who were tumbling out were questioned, they said that there was a citadel within, that the enemy were numerous, and that they had sallied forth and were dealing blows upon the men inside.

cts:urn:0032-006:5.2.18
glaux1.0-sentence	2154

cts:urn:0032-006:5.2.18

perseus-eng2	At that many proceeded to rush into the gates, and the crowd that was pushing in overcame the crowd that was tumbling out and shut up the enemy again in their citadel.

cts:urn:0032-006:5.2.19

cts:urn:0032-006:5.2.20

perseus-eng2	Meanwhile Xenophon and the captains were looking to see whether it was possible to capture the citadel.

cts:urn:0032-006:5.2.20
glaux1.0-sentence	2159

perseus-eng2	For in that case their safety was secured, while otherwise they thought it would be very difficult to effect their withdrawal;

cts:urn:0032-006:5.2.20
glaux1.0-sentence	2160

perseus-eng2	but the upshot of their consideration was, that the place was quite impregnable.

cts:urn:0032-006:5.2.21
glaux1.0-sentence	2161
perseus-grc2	ἐνταῦθα παρεσκευάζοντο τὴν ἄφοδον , καὶ τοὺς μὲν σταυροὺς ἕκαστοι τοὺς καθ’ αὑτοὺς διῄρουν , καὶ τοὺς ἀχρείους καὶ φορτία ἔχοντάς τε ἐξεπέμποντο καὶ τῶν ὁπλιτῶν τὸ πλῆθος , καταλιπόντες οἱ λοχαγοὶ οἷς ἕκαστος ἐπίστευεν .
perseus-eng2	Then they made preparations for the withdrawal: they tore down the palisades, each division taking those on its own front, and sent off the men who were unfit for service or were carrying burdens, and likewise the greater part of the hoplites, the captains keeping behind only those troops that they each relied upon.

cts:urn:0032-006:5.2.22
glaux1.0-sentence	2162
perseus-grc2	ἐπεὶ δὲ ἤρξαντο ἀποχωρεῖν , ἐπεξέθεον ἔνδοθεν πολλοὶ γέρρα καὶ λόγχας ἔχοντες καὶ κνημῖδας καὶ κράνη Παφλαγονικά , καὶ ἄλλοι ἐπὶ τὰς οἰκίας ἀνέβαινον τὰς ἔνθεν καὶ ἔνθεν τῆς εἰς τὴν ἄκραν φερούσης ὁδοῦ ·
perseus-eng2	But the moment they began to retire, there rushed out upon them from within a great crowd of men armed with wicker shields, spears, greaves, and Paphlagonian helmets, while others set about climbing to the tops of the houses that were on either side of the road leading up to the citadel.

cts:urn:0032-006:5.2.23
glaux1.0-sentence	2163
perseus-grc2	ὥστε οὐδὲ διώκειν ἀσφαλὲς ἦν κατὰ τὰς πύλας τὰς εἰς τὴν ἄκραν φερούσας .
perseus-eng2	The result was that even a pursuit in the direction of the gates that led into the citadel was unsafe;

perseus-eng2	for they would hurl down great logs from above, so that it was difficult either to remain or to retire.

perseus-eng2	The moment Xenophon grasped this lesson which chance had given him, he gave orders to set fire to the houses on the left also, which were of wood and so fell to burning very quickly.

perseus-eng2	The share which belonged to Artemis of the Ephesians he left behind, at the time when he was returning from  Asia  with Agesilaus to take part in the campaign against  Boeotia , in charge of Megabyzus, the sacristan of Artemis, for the reason that his own journey seemed likely to be a dangerous one;and his instructions were that in case he should escape with his life, the money was to be returned to him.

cts:urn:0032-006:5.3.6
glaux1.0-sentence	2205
perseus-grc2	ἢν δέ τι πάθῃ , ἀναθεῖναι ποιησάμενον τῇ Ἀρτέμιδι ὅ τι οἴοιτο χαριεῖσθαι τῇ θεῷ .
perseus-eng2	But in case any ill should befall him, Megabyzus was to cause to be made and dedicated to Artemis whatever offering he thought would please the goddess.

cts:urn:0032-006:5.3.7

perseus-grc2	ἐπειδὴ δ’ ἔφευγεν ὁ Ξενοφῶν , κατοικοῦντος ἤδη αὐτοῦ ἐν Σκιλλοῦντι ὑπὸ τῶν Λακεδαιμονίων οἰκισθέντος παρὰ τὴν Ὀλυμπίαν ἀφικνεῖται Μεγάβυζος εἰς Ὀλυμπίαν θεωρήσων καὶ ἀποδίδωσι τὴν παρακαταθήκην αὐτῷ .
perseus-eng2	In the time of Xenophon’s exile and while he was living at Scillus, near  Olympia , where he had been established as a colonist by the Lacedaemonians, Megabyzus came to  Olympia  to attend the games and returned to him his deposit.

cts:urn:0032-006:5.3.7
glaux1.0-sentence	2207

perseus-eng2	Upon receiving it Xenophon bought a plot of ground for the goddess in a place which Apollo’s oracle appointed.

cts:urn:0032-006:5.3.8

cts:urn:0032-006:5.3.8
glaux1.0-sentence	2211

perseus-eng2	In the plot at Scillus there is hunting of all manner of beasts of the chase.

cts:urn:0032-006:5.3.9
glaux1.0-sentence	2212
perseus-grc2	ἐποίησε δὲ καὶ βωμὸν καὶ ναὸν ἀπὸ τοῦ ἱεροῦ ἀργυρίου , καὶ τὸ λοιπὸν δὲ ἀεὶ δεκατεύων τὰ ἐκ τοῦ ἀγροῦ ὡραῖα θυσίαν ἐποίει τῇ θεῷ , καὶ πάντες οἱ πολῖται καὶ οἱ πρόσχωροι ἄνδρες καὶ γυναῖκες μετεῖχον τῆς ἑορτῆς .
perseus-eng2	Here Xenophon built an altar and a temple with the sacred money, and from that time forth he would every year take the tithe of the products of the land in their season and offer sacrifice to the goddess, all the citizens and the men and women of the neighbourhood taking part in the festival.

cts:urn:0032-006:5.3.9
glaux1.0-sentence	2213
perseus-grc2	παρεῖχε δὲ ἡ θεὸς τοῖς σκηνοῦσιν ἄλφιτα , ἄρτους , οἶνον , τραγήματα , καὶ τῶν θυομένων ἀπὸ τῆς ἱερᾶς νομῆς λάχος , καὶ τῶν θηρευομένων δέ .
perseus-eng2	And the goddess would provide for the banqueters barley meal and loaves of bread, wine and sweetmeats, and a portion of the sacrificial victims from the sacred herd as well as of the victims taken in the chase.

cts:urn:0032-006:5.3.10
glaux1.0-sentence	2214

perseus-eng2	For Xenophon’s sons and the sons of the other citizens used to have a hunting expedition at the time of the festival, and any grown men who so wished would join them;

cts:urn:0032-006:5.3.10

perseus-eng2	and they captured their game partly from the sacred precinct itself and partly from Mount Pholoe—boars and gazelles and stags.

cts:urn:0032-006:5.3.11

perseus-eng2	The place is situated on the road which leads from  Lacedaemon  to  Olympia , and is about twenty stadia from the temple of Zeus at  Olympia .

cts:urn:0032-006:5.3.11

perseus-eng2	Within the sacred precinct there is meadowland and treecovered hills, suited for the rearing of swine, goats, cattle and horses, so that even the draught animals which bring people to the festival have their feast also.

cts:urn:0032-006:5.3.12
glaux1.0-sentence	2218
perseus-grc2	περὶ δὲ αὐτὸν τὸν ναὸν ἄλσος ἡμέρων δένδρων ἐφυτεύθη ὅσα ἐστὶ τρωκτὰ ὡραῖα .

perseus-eng2	The temple itself is like the one at  Ephesus , although small as compared with great, and the image of the goddess, although cypress wood as compared with gold, is like the Ephesian image.

perseus-eng2	If you wish, therefore, it is within your power to secure us as allies, to exact vengeance for any wrong these people have ever done you, and to make them henceforth your subjects.

cts:urn:0032-006:5.4.7

perseus-grc2	εἰ δὲ ἡμᾶς ἀφήσετε , σκέψασθε πόθεν αὖθις ἂν τοσαύτην δύναμιν λάβοιτε ξύμμαχον .
perseus-eng2	But if you dismiss us with a refusal, where, bethink you, could you ever again secure so large a force to help fight your battles?

cts:urn:0032-006:5.4.8

perseus-eng2	To these words the chief of the Mossynoecians replied that they desired this arrangement and accepted the alliance.

cts:urn:0032-006:5.4.9

perseus-grc2	ἄγετε δή , ἔφη ὁ Ξενοφῶν , τί ἡμῶν δεήσεσθε χρήσασθαι , ἂν ξύμμαχοι ὑμῶν γενώμεθα , καὶ ὑμεῖς τί οἷοί τε ἔσεσθε ἡμῖν ξυμπρᾶξαι περὶ τῆς διόδου ;
perseus-eng2	Well, then," said Xenophon, "what use will you want to make of us if we become your allies, and what assistance will you, in your turn, be able to render us in the matter of our passage through this territory?

cts:urn:0032-006:5.4.10
glaux1.0-sentence	2240
perseus-grc2	οἱ δὲ εἶπον ὅτι ἱκανοί ἐσμεν εἰς τὴν χώραν εἰσβάλλειν ἐκ τοῦ ἐπὶ θάτερα τὴν τῶν ὑμῖν τε καὶ ἡμῖν πολεμίων , καὶ δεῦρο ὑμῖν πέμψαι ναῦς τε καὶ ἄνδρας οἵτινες ὑμῖν ξυμμαχοῦνταί τε καὶ τὴν ὁδὸν ἡγήσονται .
perseus-eng2	They replied: "We are able to invade this land of your enemies and ours from the opposite side, and to send to you here not only ships, but men who will aid you in the fighting and will guide you on your way."

cts:urn:0032-006:5.4.11

cts:urn:0032-006:5.4.11

perseus-eng2	The next day they returned, bringing with them three hundred canoes, each made out of a single log and each containing three men, two of whom disembarked and fell into line under arms, while the third remained in the canoe.

cts:urn:0032-006:5.4.12
glaux1.0-sentence	2243

perseus-eng2	Then the second group took their canoes and sailed back again, and those who stayed behind marshalled themselves in the following way.

cts:urn:0032-006:5.4.12
glaux1.0-sentence	2244
perseus-grc2	ἔστησαν ὥσπερ ἀνὰ ἑκατὸν μάλιστα οἷον χοροὶ ἀντιστοιχοῦντες ἀλλήλοις , ἔχοντες γέρρα πάντες λευκῶν βοῶν δασέα , ᾐκασμένα κιττοῦ πετάλῳ , ἐν δὲ τῇ δεξιᾷ παλτὸν ὡς ἕξπηχυ , ἔμπροσθεν μὲν λόγχην ἔχον , ὄπισθεν δὲ τοῦ ξύλου σφαιροειδές .
perseus-eng2	They took position in lines of about a hundred each, like choral dancers ranged opposite one another, all of them with wicker shields covered with white, shaggy ox-hide and like an ivy leaf in shape, and each man holding in his right hand a lance about six cubits long, with a spearhead at one end and a round ball at the butt end of the shaft.

cts:urn:0032-006:5.4.13
glaux1.0-sentence	2245
perseus-grc2	χιτωνίσκους δὲ ἐνεδεδύκεσαν ὑπὲρ γονάτων , πάχος ὡς λινοῦ στρωματοδέσμου , ἐπὶ τῇ κεφαλῇ δὲ κράνη σκύτινα οἷάπερ τὰ Παφλαγονικά , κρωβύλον ἔχοντα κατὰ μέσον , ἐγγύτατα τιαροειδῆ ·
perseus-eng2	They wore short tunics which did not reach their knees and were as thick as a linen bag for bedclothes, and upon their heads leathern helmets just such as the Paphlagonian helmets, with a tuft in the middle very like a tiara in shape;

cts:urn:0032-006:5.4.13

perseus-eng2	and they had also iron battle-axes.

cts:urn:0032-006:5.4.14
glaux1.0-sentence	2247
perseus-grc2	ἐντεῦθεν ἐξῆρχε μὲν αὐτῶν εἷς , οἱ δὲ ἄλλοι ἅπαντες ἐπορεύοντο ᾄδοντες ἐν ῥυθμῷ , καὶ διελθόντες διὰ τῶν τάξεων καὶ διὰ τῶν ὅπλων τῶν Ἑλλήνων ἐπορεύοντο εὐθὺς πρὸς τοὺς πολεμίους ἐπὶ χωρίον ὃ ἐδόκει ἐπιμαχώτατον εἶναι .
perseus-eng2	After they had formed their lines one of them led off, and the rest after him, every man of them, fell into a rhythmic march and song, and passing through the battalions and through the quarters of the Greeks they went straight on against the enemy, toward a stronghold which seemed to be especially assailable.

cts:urn:0032-006:5.4.15
glaux1.0-sentence	2248
perseus-grc2	ᾠκεῖτο δὲ τοῦτο πρὸ τῆς πόλεως τῆς Μητροπόλεως καλουμένης αὐτοῖς καὶ ἐχούσης τὸ ἀκρότατον τῶν Μοσσυνοίκων .
perseus-eng2	It was situated in front of the city which is called by them Metropolis and contains the chief citadel of the Mossynoecians.

cts:urn:0032-006:5.4.15
glaux1.0-sentence	2249
perseus-grc2	καὶ περὶ τούτου ὁ πόλεμος ἦν ·
perseus-eng2	In fact, it was for the possession of this citadel that the war was going on;

cts:urn:0032-006:5.4.15
glaux1.0-sentence	2250
perseus-grc2	οἱ γὰρ ἀεὶ τοῦτ’ ἔχοντες ἐδόκουν ἐγκρατεῖς εἶναι καὶ πάντων Μοσσυνοίκων , καὶ ἔφασαν τούτους οὐ δικαίως ἔχειν τοῦτο , ἀλλὰ κοινὸν ὂν καταλαβόντας πλεονεκτεῖν .
perseus-eng2	for those who at any time held it were deemed to be masters of all the other Mossynoecians, and they said that the present occupants did not hold it by right, but that it was common property and they had seized it in order to gain a selfish advantage.

cts:urn:0032-006:5.4.16

perseus-eng2	The attacking party was followed by some of the Greeks, not under orders from their generals, but seeking plunder.

cts:urn:0032-006:5.4.16

cts:urn:0032-006:5.4.16

perseus-eng2	but when they had got near the stronghold, they sallied forth and put them to flight, killing a considerable number of the barbarians and some of the Greeks who had gone up the hill with them, and pursuing the rest until they saw the Greeks coming to the rescue;

cts:urn:0032-006:5.4.17

perseus-eng2	then they turned and fell back, and after cutting off the heads of the dead men displayed them to the Greeks and to their own enemies, at the same time dancing to a kind of strain which they sang.

cts:urn:0032-006:5.4.18
glaux1.0-sentence	2255

perseus-eng2	And the Greeks were exceedingly angry, not only because the enemy had been made bolder, but because the Greeks who went to the attack with the barbarians had taken to flight, though in very considerable numbers—

perseus-grc2	ὃ οὔπω πρόσθεν ἐπεποιήκεσαν ἐν τῇ στρατείᾳ .
perseus-eng2	a thing which they had never done before in the course of the expedition.

cts:urn:0032-006:5.4.19
glaux1.0-sentence	2257

perseus-eng2	Then Xenophon called the Greeks together and said:

cts:urn:0032-006:5.4.19
glaux1.0-sentence	2258

perseus-eng2	Fellow-soldiers, do not by any means lose heart on account of what has happened;

cts:urn:0032-006:5.4.19
