perseus-eng2	That you are angry, fellow soldiers, and believe you are outrageously treated in being so deceived, I do not wonder.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.1.25
glaux1.0-sentence	3151
perseus-grc2	ἢν δὲ τῷ θυμῷ χαριζώμεθα καὶ Λακεδαιμονίους τε τοὺς παρόντας τῆς ἐξαπάτης τιμωρησώμεθα καὶ τὴν πόλιν τὴν οὐδὲν αἰτίαν διαρπάσωμεν , ἐνθυμεῖσθε ἃ ἔσται ἐντεῦθεν .
perseus-eng2	But if we indulge our anger, by taking vengeance for this deception upon the Lacedaemonians who are here and by sacking the city which is in no way to blame, consider the results that will follow.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.1.26
glaux1.0-sentence	3152
perseus-grc2	πολέμιοι μὲν ἐσόμεθα ἀποδεδειγμένοι Λακεδαιμονίοις καὶ τοῖς συμμάχοις .
perseus-eng2	We shall be declared to be at war with the Lacedaemonians and their allies.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.1.26

perseus-eng2	And what sort of a war that would prove to be one may at least conjecture by having seen and by recalling to mind the events which have quite lately taken place.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.1.27
glaux1.0-sentence	3154
perseus-grc2	ἡμεῖς γὰρ οἱ Ἀθηναῖοι ἤλθομεν εἰς τὸν πόλεμον τὸν πρὸς Λακεδαιμονίους καὶ τοὺς συμμάχους ἔχοντες τριήρεις τὰς μὲν ἐν θαλάττῃ τὰς δ’ ἐν τοῖς νεωρίοις οὐκ ἐλάττους τριακοσίων , ὑπαρχόντων δὲ πολλῶν χρημάτων ἐν τῇ πόλει καὶ προσόδου οὔσης κατ’ ἐνιαυτὸν ἀπό τε τῶν ἐνδήμων καὶ τῆς ὑπερορίας οὐ μεῖον χιλίων ταλάντων ·
perseus-eng2	We Athenians, remember, entered upon our war against the Lacedaemonians and their allies with no fewer than three hundred triremes, some afloat and others in the dockyards, with an abundance of treasure already at hand in our city, and with a yearly revenue, accruing at home or coming in from our foreign possessions, of not less than a thousand talents;

cts:urn:0032-006:7.1.27
glaux1.0-sentence	3155
perseus-grc2	ἄρχοντες δὲ τῶν νήσων ἁπασῶν καὶ ἔν τε τῇ Ἀσίᾳ πολλὰς ἔχοντες πόλεις καὶ ἐν τῇ Εὐρώπῃ ἄλλας τε πολλὰς καὶ αὐτὸ τοῦτο τὸ Βυζάντιον , ὅπου νῦν ἐσμεν , ἔχοντες κατεπολεμήθημεν οὕτως ὡς πάντες ὑμεῖς ἐπίστασθε .
perseus-eng2	we ruled over all the islands, we possessed many cities in  Asia , in  Europe  we possessed among many others this very city of  Byzantium  also, where we now are,—and we were vanquished, in the way that all of you remember.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.1.28
glaux1.0-sentence	3156
perseus-grc2	νῦν δὲ δὴ τί ἂν οἰόμεθα παθεῖν , Λακεδαιμονίοις μὲν καὶ τῶν ἀρχαίων συμμάχων ὑπαρχόντων , Ἀθηναίων δὲ καὶ οἳ ἐκείνοις τότε ἦσαν σύμμαχοι πάντων προσγεγενημένων , Τισσαφέρνους δὲ καὶ τῶν ἐπὶ θαλάττῃ ἄλλων βαρβάρων πάντων πολεμίων ἡμῖν ὄντων , πολεμιωτάτου δὲ αὐτοῦ τοῦ ἄνω βασιλέως , ὃν ἤλθομεν ἀφαιρησόμενοι τὴν ἀρχὴν καὶ ἀποκτενοῦντες , εἰ δυναίμεθα ;
perseus-eng2	What fate, then, may you and I expect to suffer now, when the Lacedaemonians still have their old allies, when the Athenians and all who at that time were allied with them have been added to the number, when Tissaphernes and all the rest of the barbarians on the coast are hostile to us, and most hostile of all the King himself, up in the interior, the man whom we came to deprive of his empire, and to kill if we could?

cts:urn:0032-006:7.1.28
glaux1.0-sentence	3157
perseus-grc2	τούτων δὴ πάντων ὁμοῦ ὄντων ἔστι τις οὕτως ἄφρων ὅστις οἴεται ἂν ἡμᾶς περιγενέσθαι ;
perseus-eng2	With all these banded together against us, is there any man so witless as to suppose that we should come off victorious?

cts:urn:0032-006:7.1.29
glaux1.0-sentence	3158
perseus-grc2	μὴ πρὸς θεῶν μαινώμεθα μηδ’ αἰσχρῶς ἀπολώμεθα πολέμιοι ὄντες καὶ ταῖς πατρίσι καὶ τοῖς ἡμετέροις αὐτῶν φίλοις τε καὶ οἰκείοις .
perseus-eng2	In the name of the gods let us not be mad, nor let us perish disgracefully as enemies both to our native states and to our own friends and kinsmen.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.1.29
glaux1.0-sentence	3159
perseus-grc2	ἐν γὰρ ταῖς πόλεσίν εἰσι πάντες ταῖς ἐφ’ ἡμᾶς στρατευσομέναις , καὶ δικαίως , εἰ βάρβαρον μὲν πόλιν οὐδεμίαν ἠθελήσαμεν κατασχεῖν , καὶ ταῦτα κρατοῦντες , Ἑλληνίδα δὲ εἰς ἣν πρώτην ἤλθομεν πόλιν , ταύτην ἐξαλαπάξομεν .
perseus-eng2	For all of them are in the cities which will take the field against us, and will do so justly if we, after refraining from the seizure of any barbarian city, conquerors though we were, are to take the first Greek city we have come to and pillage that.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.1.30
glaux1.0-sentence	3160
perseus-grc2	ἐγὼ μὲν τοίνυν εὔχομαι πρὶν ταῦτα ἐπιδεῖν ὑφ’ ὑμῶν γενόμενα μυρίας ἐμέ γε κατὰ τῆς γῆς ὀργυιὰς γενέσθαι .
perseus-eng2	For my part, therefore, I pray that sooner than live to behold this deed wrought by you, I may be laid ten thousand fathoms underground.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.1.30

perseus-grc2	καὶ ὑμῖν δὲ συμβουλεύω Ἕλληνας ὄντας τοῖς τῶν Ἑλλήνων προεστηκόσι πειθομένους πειρᾶσθαι τῶν δικαίων τυγχάνειν .
perseus-eng2	And to you my advice is, that being Greeks you endeavour to obtain your just rights by obedience to the leaders of the Greeks.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.1.30

perseus-eng2	If you are unable to accomplish this, we must not at any rate, even though wronged, be deprived of our return to  Greece .

cts:urn:0032-006:7.1.31

perseus-eng2	And now it is my opinion that we should send messengers to Anaxibius and say to him: "We have not made our way into the city to do any violence, but to obtain some good thing from you if we can, or if that is not possible, at least to show that we go forth, not because we are deceived, but because we are obedient."

cts:urn:0032-006:7.1.32

perseus-eng2	This course was resolved upon, and they sent Hieronymus the Elean, Eurylochus the Arcadian, and Philesius the Achaean to bear this message.

perseus-eng2	While the soldiers were still in session Coeratadas the Theban came in, a man who was going up and down  Greece , not in exile, but because he was afflicted with a desire to be a general, and he was offering his services to any city or people that might be wanting a general;

perseus-eng2	so at this time he came to the troops and said that he was ready to lead them to the Delta, as it is called, of  Thrace , where they could get plenty of good things;

cts:urn:0032-006:7.1.34

perseus-eng2	When the soldiers heard this proposal and the word that came back at the same time from Anaxibius—his reply was, that if they were obedient they would not be sorry for it, but that he would report the matter to his government at home and would himself devise whatever good counsel he could in their case—they thereupon accepted Coeratadas as general and withdrew outside the walls.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.1.35

perseus-eng2	And Coeratadas made an agreement with them that he would join the army on the next day with sacrificial victims and a soothsayer, as well as food and drink for the troops.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.1.36
glaux1.0-sentence	3171
perseus-grc2	ἐπεὶ δὲ ἐξῆλθον , ὁ Ἀναξίβιος ἔκλεισε τὰς πύλας καὶ ἐκήρυξεν ὃς ἂν ἁλῷ ἔνδον ὢν τῶν στρατιωτῶν ὅτι πεπράσεται .
perseus-eng2	Meanwhile, as soon as they had gone forth from the city, Anaxibius closed the gates and made proclamation that any soldier who might be caught inside the city would be sold as a slave.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.1.37

perseus-eng2	On the next day Coeratadas arrived with his sacrificial victims and his soothsayer, and there followed him twenty men loaded with barley-meal, another twenty with wine, three with olives, another man with as big a load of garlic as he could carry, and another with onions.

perseus-eng2	And now Xenophon sent for Cleander and urged him to make arrangements so that he could enter within the wall and thus sail homeward from  Byzantium .

perseus-eng2	for Anaxibius said it was not well to have the soldiers close by the wall and Xenophon within it;

cts:urn:0032-006:7.1.40

perseus-eng2	Xenophon accordingly took his leave of the soldiers and went back within the wall in company with Cleander.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.1.40

perseus-eng2	As for Coeratadas, on the first day he could not get good omens from his sacrifices nor did he serve out any rations at all to the troops;

cts:urn:0032-006:7.1.40

perseus-eng2	on the following day the victims were standing beside the altar and Coeratadas had on his chaplet, ready for the sacrifice.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.1.40
glaux1.0-sentence	3182
perseus-grc2	προσελθὼν δὲ Τιμασίων ὁ Δαρδανεὺς καὶ Νέων ὁ Ἀσιναῖος καὶ Κλεάνωρ ὁ Ὀρχομένιος ἔλεγον Κοιρατάδᾳ μὴ θύειν , ὡς οὐχ ἡγησόμενον τῇ στρατιᾷ , εἰ μὴ δώσει τὰ ἐπιτήδεια .
perseus-eng2	Timasion the Dardanian, Neon the Asinaean, and Cleanor the Orchomenian came up and told him not to make the offering, for he was not to be leader of the army unless he should give them provisions.

perseus-eng2	When it proved, however, that his supply fell far short of amounting to a day’s food for each of the soldiers, he took his victims and went away, renouncing his generalship.

perseus-eng2	But meantime Aristarchus, the governor at  Byzantium , arrived with two triremes and, having been persuaded to this course by Pharnabazus, not only forbade the shipmasters to carry the army across, but came to the camp and told the soldiers not to pass over into  Asia .

cts:urn:0032-006:7.2.15
glaux1.0-sentence	3221
perseus-grc2	ἑώρα γὰρ οὔτε διαβαίνειν ἀσφαλὲς ὂν τριήρεις ἔχοντος τοῦ κωλύσοντος , οὔτ’ ἐπὶ Χερρόνησον ἐλθὼν κατακλεισθῆναι ἐβούλετο καὶ τὸ στράτευμα ἐν πολλῇ σπάνει πάντων γενέσθαι ἔνθα πείθεσθαι μὲν ἀνάγκη τῷ ἐκεῖ ἁρμοστῇ , τῶν δὲ ἐπιτηδείων οὐδὲν ἔμελλεν ἕξειν τὸ στράτευμα .
perseus-eng2	For he saw that it was not safe for them to try to cross over to  Asia  when the man who intended to prevent their passage possessed triremes; on the other hand, it was not his desire that the army should go to the  Chersonese  and find itself shut up and in sore need of everything in a place where it would be necessary to obey the resident governor and where the army would not obtain anything in the way of provisions.

perseus-eng2	Since, therefore, the sacrifices appeared to be favourable, portending that he and the army might go to Seuthes in safety, Xenophon took Polycrates, the Athenian captain, and from each of the generals except Neon a man in whom each had confidence, and set off by night to visit Seuthes’ army, sixty stadia away.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.2.18

cts:urn:0032-006:7.2.18

perseus-eng2	but when he became aware of a general uproar and heard Seuthes’ followers signalling to one another, he comprehended that the reason Seuthes had his watch-fires kindled in front of the pickets was in order that the pickets might remain unseen, in the darkness as they were, so that no one could tell either how many they were or where they were, while on the other hand people who were approaching could not escape notice, but would be visible in the light of the fires.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.2.19

perseus-eng2	When he did see pickets, he sent forward the interpreter he chanced to have and bade them tell Seuthes that Xenophon had come and desired to meet with him.

perseus-eng2	for out of fear he gave his horses their fodder by day, and by night kept them ready bridled to guard himself with.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.2.22

perseus-grc2	ἐλέγετο γὰρ καὶ πρόσθεν Τήρης ὁ τούτου πρόγονος ἐν ταύτῃ τῇ χώρᾳ πολὺ ἔχων στράτευμα ὑπὸ τούτων τῶν ἀνδρῶν πολλοὺς ἀπολέσαι καὶ τὰ σκευοφόρα ἀφαιρεθῆναι ·
perseus-eng2	For there was a story that in time gone by Teres, an ancestor of Seuthes, being in this region with a large army, lost many of his troops and was robbed of his baggage train at the hands of the people of this neighbourhood;

cts:urn:0032-006:7.2.22

perseus-eng2	As soon as they were inside, they first greeted one another and drank healths after the Thracian fashion in horns of wine;

cts:urn:0032-006:7.2.23
glaux1.0-sentence	3239

perseus-eng2	You sent to me, Seuthes, first at Calchedon, this man Medosades, with the request that I make every effort on your behalf to bring the army across from  Asia , and with the promise that if I should do this, you would treat me well—as Medosades here declared.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.2.25
glaux1.0-sentence	3242

perseus-eng2	Medosades here came to me a second time after I had crossed over from Parium to rejoin the army, and promised that if I should bring the army to you, you would not only treat me in all ways as a friend and a brother, but in particular would give me the places on the seacoast of which you hold possession.

perseus-eng2	Well, then," said Xenophon, "at this moment I am here myself, along with Phryniscus here, one of the generals, and Polycrates yonder, one of the captains, and outside are representatives of the other generals except Neon the Laconian, in each case the man most trusted by each general.

perseus-eng2	Maesades was my father, and his realm embraced the Melanditae, the Thynians, and the Tranipsae.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.2.32
glaux1.0-sentence	3261
perseus-grc2	ἐκ ταύτης οὖν τῆς χώρας , ἐπεὶ τὰ Ὀδρυσῶν πράγματα ἐνόσησεν , ἐκπεσὼν ὁ πατὴρ αὐτὸς μὲν ἀποθνῄσκει νόσῳ , ἐγὼ δ’ ἐξετράφην ὀρφανὸς παρὰ Μηδόκῳ τῷ νῦν βασιλεῖ .
perseus-eng2	Now when the affairs of the Odrysians fell into a bad state, my father was driven out of this country, and thereafter sickened and died, while I, the son, was brought up as an orphan at the court of Medocus, the present king.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.2.33
glaux1.0-sentence	3262
perseus-grc2	ἐπεὶ δὲ νεανίσκος ἐγενόμην , οὐκ ἐδυνάμην ζῆν εἰς ἀλλοτρίαν τράπεζαν ἀποβλέπων ·
perseus-eng2	When I became a young man, however, I could not endure to live with my eyes turned toward another’s table;

cts:urn:0032-006:7.2.33
glaux1.0-sentence	3263
perseus-grc2	καὶ ἐκαθεζόμην ἐνδίφριος αὐτῷ ἱκέτης δοῦναί μοι ὁπόσους δυνατὸς εἴη ἄνδρας , ὅπως καὶ τοὺς ἐκβαλόντας ἡμᾶς εἴ τι δυναίμην κακὸν ποιοίην καὶ ζῴην μὴ εἰς τὴν ἐκείνου τράπεζαν ἀποβλέπων .
perseus-eng2	so I sat myself down on the same seat with Medocus as a suppliant and besought him to give me as many men as he could, in order that I might inflict whatever harm I could upon those who drove us out, and might live without turning my eyes toward his table.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.2.34

perseus-eng2	Thereupon he gave me the men and the horses that you will see for yourselves as soon as day has come.

perseus-eng2	And Seuthes promised to give to each soldier a Cyzicene, to the captains twice as much, and to the generals four times as much; furthermore, as much land as they might wish, yokes of oxen, and a fortified place upon the seacoast.

perseus-eng2	And to you, Xenophon, I will also give my daughter, and if you have a daughter, I will buy her after the Thracian fashion; and I will give you for a residence  Bisanthe , the very fairest of all the places I have upon the seacoast.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.3.3

perseus-eng2	and if we make ourselves masters of the mountain and get to the  Chersonese , he says that he will not sell you any more, as he did at  Byzantium , that you will not be cheated any more but will receive pay, and that he will not shut his eyes any more, as he does now, to your being in want of provisions.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.3.4

cts:urn:0032-006:7.3.4
glaux1.0-sentence	3288
perseus-grc2	νῦν οὖν σκέψασθε πότερον ἐνθάδε μένοντες τοῦτο βουλεύσεσθε ἢ εἰς τὰ ἐπιτήδεια ἐπανελθόντες .
perseus-eng2	Now, therefore, make up your minds whether you will consider this question here and now or after you have set forth in quest of provisions.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.3.5

perseus-grc2	ἐμοὶ μὲν οὖν δοκεῖ , ἐπεὶ ἐνθάδε οὔτε ἀργύριον ἔχομεν ὥστε ἀγοράζειν οὔτε ἄνευ ἀργυρίου ἐῶσι λαμβάνειν , ἐπανελθόντας εἰς τὰς κώμας ὅθεν οἱ ἥττους ἐῶσι λαμβάνειν , ἐκεῖ ἔχοντας τὰ ἐπιτήδεια ἀκούοντας ὅ τι τις ἡμῶν δεῖται , αἱρεῖσθαι ὅ τι ἂν ἡμῖν δοκῇ κράτιστον εἶναι .
perseus-eng2	My own opinion is, seeing that here we neither have money with which to buy nor are permitted to take anything without money, that we ought to set forth to the villages from which we are permitted to take, since their inhabitants are weaker than ourselves, and that there, possessed of provisions and hearing what the service is that one wants us for, we should choose whatever course may seem best to us.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.3.6
glaux1.0-sentence	3290
perseus-grc2	καὶ ὅτῳ γε , ἔφη , ταῦτα δοκεῖ , ἀράτω τὴν χεῖρα .

cts:urn:0032-006:7.3.6

perseus-eng2	Every hand was raised.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.3.6

perseus-eng2	Go away, then," Xenophon continued, "and pack up, and when the word is given, follow the van.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.3.7

perseus-grc2	μετὰ ταῦτα Ξενοφῶν μὲν ἡγεῖτο , οἱ δ’ εἵποντο .
perseus-eng2	After this Xenophon led the way and the troops followed.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.3.7

perseus-eng2	Neon, indeed, and messengers from Aristarchus tried to persuade them to turn back.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.3.7
glaux1.0-sentence	3295
perseus-grc2	οἱ δ’ οὐχ ὑπήκουον .
perseus-eng2	But they would not listen to them.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.3.7

perseus-eng2	When they had advanced as much as thirty stadia, Seuthes met them.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.3.7
glaux1.0-sentence	3297
perseus-grc2	καὶ ὁ Ξενοφῶν ἰδὼν αὐτὸν προσελάσαι ἐκέλευσεν , ὅπως ὅτι πλείστων ἀκουόντων εἴποι αὐτῷ ἃ ἐδόκει συμφέρειν .
perseus-eng2	And Xenophon, catching sight of him, bade him ride up to the troops, in order that he might tell him within hearing of the greatest possible number what they had decided upon as advantageous.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.3.8
glaux1.0-sentence	3298
perseus-grc2	ἐπεὶ δὲ προσῆλθεν , εἶπε Ξενοφῶν ·

cts:urn:0032-006:7.3.8

perseus-eng2	We are on our way to a place where the army will be able to get food;

cts:urn:0032-006:7.3.8
glaux1.0-sentence	3300
perseus-grc2	ἐκεῖ δ’ ἀκούοντες καὶ σοῦ καὶ τῶν τοῦ Λακωνικοῦ αἱρησόμεθα ἃ ἂν κράτιστα δοκῇ εἶναι .
perseus-eng2	there we shall listen both to you and to the Laconian’s messengers, and make whatever choice may seem to be best.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.3.8
glaux1.0-sentence	3301

perseus-eng2	If, then, you will guide us to a spot where there are provisions in greatest abundance, we shall think we are being hospitably entertained by you.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.3.9
glaux1.0-sentence	3302

perseus-eng2	And Seuthes replied:

cts:urn:0032-006:7.3.9
glaux1.0-sentence	3303
perseus-grc2	ἀλλὰ οἶδα κώμας πολλὰς ἁθρόας καὶ πάντα ἐχούσας τὰ ἐπιτήδεια ἀπεχούσας ἡμῶν ὅσον διελθόντες ἂν ἡδέως ἀριστῴητε .
perseus-eng2	Why, I know a large number of villages, close together and containing all sorts of provisions, that are just far enough away from us so that, when you have covered the distance, you would enjoy your breakfast.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.3.10
glaux1.0-sentence	3304

cts:urn:0032-006:7.3.10

cts:urn:0032-006:7.3.10
glaux1.0-sentence	3306
perseus-grc2	ἐγώ , ὦ ἄνδρες , δέομαι ὑμῶν στρατεύεσθαι σὺν ἐμοί , καὶ ὑπισχνοῦμαι ὑμῖν δώσειν τοῖς στρατιώταις κυζικηνόν , λοχαγοῖς δὲ καὶ στρατηγοῖς τὰ νομιζόμενα ·
perseus-eng2	"I ask you, soldiers, to take the field with me, and I promise to give to you who are in the ranks a Cyzicene and to the captains and generals the customary pay;

cts:urn:0032-006:7.3.10
glaux1.0-sentence	3307

perseus-eng2	besides this, I shall honour the man who deserves it.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.3.10
glaux1.0-sentence	3308

cts:urn:0032-006:7.3.10
glaux1.0-sentence	3309
perseus-grc2	ὁπόσα δ’ ἂν ἁλίσκηται ἀξιώσω αὐτὸς ἔχειν , ἵνα ταῦτα διατιθέμενος ὑμῖν τὸν μισθὸν πορίζω .
perseus-eng2	but whatever may be captured I shall expect to retain for myself, so that by selling it I may provide you your pay.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.3.11

cts:urn:0032-006:7.3.11

cts:urn:0032-006:7.3.12

perseus-eng2	Xenophon asked,

cts:urn:0032-006:7.3.13
glaux1.0-sentence	3316

cts:urn:0032-006:7.3.13
glaux1.0-sentence	3317

cts:urn:0032-006:7.3.13
glaux1.0-sentence	3318
perseus-grc2	χειμὼν γὰρ εἴη καὶ οὔτε οἴκαδε ἀποπλεῖν τῷ τοῦτο βουλομένῳ δυνατὸν εἴη , διαγενέσθαι τε ἐν φιλίᾳ οὐχ οἷόν τε , εἰ δέοι ὠνουμένους ζῆν , ἐν δὲ τῇ πολεμίᾳ διατρίβειν καὶ τρέφεσθαι ἀσφαλέστερον μετὰ Σεύθου ἢ μόνους , ὄντων ἀγαθῶν τοσούτων .
perseus-eng2	for the season was winter, and it was impossible to sail back home, if that was what one wished, and impossible also to get along in a friendly country if they had to maintain themselves by purchasing; on the other hand, to spend their time and get their maintenance in a hostile country was a safer proceeding in Seuthes’ company than if they were alone.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.3.13

cts:urn:0032-006:7.3.16

cts:urn:0032-006:7.3.16

perseus-grc2	οὗτος προσιὼν ἑνὶ ἑκάστῳ οὕστινας ᾤετο ἔχειν τι δοῦναι Σεύθῃ , πρῶτον μὲν πρὸς Παριανούς τινας , οἳ παρῆσαν φιλίαν διαπραξόμενοι πρὸς Μήδοκον τὸν Ὀδρυσῶν βασιλέα καὶ δῶρα ἄγοντες αὐτῷ τε καὶ τῇ γυναικί , ἔλεγεν ὅτι Μήδοκος μὲν ἄνω εἴη δώδεκα ἡμερῶν ἀπὸ θαλάττης ὁδόν , Σεύθης δ’ ἐπεὶ τὸ στράτευμα τοῦτο εἴληφεν , ἄρχων ἔσοιτο ἐπὶ θαλάττῃ .
perseus-eng2	This fellow came up to each single one of the guests who, as he imagined, were able to make a present to Seuthes, first of all to some people of Parium who had come to arrange a friendship with Medocus, the king of the Odrysians, and brought gifts with them for him and his wife; to them Heracleides said that Medocus was a twelve days’ journey inland from the sea, while Seuthes, now that he had got this army, would be master upon the coast.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.3.17
glaux1.0-sentence	3328
perseus-grc2	γείτων οὖν ὢν ἱκανώτατος ἔσται ὑμᾶς καὶ εὖ καὶ κακῶς ποιεῖν .
perseus-eng2	He, therefore," Heracleides went on, "being your neighbour, will be best able to do you good or harm.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.3.17

cts:urn:0032-006:7.3.17

perseus-eng2	Next he came up to Timasion the Dardanian,—for he heard that he had some Persian drinking cups and carpets,—and said that it was customary when Seuthes invited people to dinner, for those who were thus invited to give him presents.

perseus-eng2	For I am quite sure that the greater the gifts you bestow upon this man, the greater the favours that you will receive at his hands.

perseus-eng2	for the Thracians had a custom which Seuthes now took the lead in practising,—he would pick up the loaves which lay beside him, break them into small pieces, and throw the pieces to whomever he pleased, following the same fashion with the meat also, and leaving himself only enough for a mere taste.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.3.23

perseus-eng2	But a certain Arcadian named Arystas, a terrible eater, would have none of this throwing about, but took in his hand a loaf as big as a three-quart measure, put some pieces of meat upon his knees, and proceeded to dine.

perseus-eng2	When the drinking was well under way, there came in a Thracian with a white horse, and taking a full horn he said:

cts:urn:0032-006:7.3.26
glaux1.0-sentence	3357
perseus-grc2	προπίνω σοι , ὦ Σεύθη , καὶ τὸν ἵππον τοῦτον δωροῦμαι , ἐφ’ οὗ καὶ διώκων ὃν ἂν θέλῃς αἱρήσεις καὶ ἀποχωρῶν οὐ μὴ δείσῃς τὸν πολέμιον .
perseus-eng2	I drink your health, Seuthes, and present to you this horse; on his back pursuing you shall catch whomever you choose, and retreating you shall not fear the enemy.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.3.27

cts:urn:0032-006:7.3.27

perseus-eng2	Timasion also drank his health and presented to him a silver bowl and a carpet worth ten minas.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.3.28
glaux1.0-sentence	3360
perseus-grc2	Γνήσιππος δέ τις Ἀθηναῖος ἀναστὰς εἶπεν ὅτι ἀρχαῖος εἴη νόμος κάλλιστος τοὺς μὲν ἔχοντας διδόναι τῷ βασιλεῖ τιμῆς ἕνεκα , τοῖς δὲ μὴ ἔχουσι διδόναι τὸν βασιλέα , ἵνα καὶ ἐγώ , ἔφη , ἔχω σοι δωρεῖσθαι καὶ τιμᾶν .
perseus-eng2	Then one Gnesippus, an Athenian, arose and said that it was an ancient and most excellent custom that those who had possessions should give to the king for honour’s sake, and that to those who had nought the king should give, "so that," he continued, "I too may be able to bestow gifts upon you and do you honour."

cts:urn:0032-006:7.3.29
glaux1.0-sentence	3361
perseus-grc2	ὁ δὲ Ξενοφῶν ἠπορεῖτο τί ποιήσει ·
perseus-eng2	As for Xenophon, he was at a loss to know what he should do;

cts:urn:0032-006:7.3.29
glaux1.0-sentence	3362
perseus-grc2	καὶ γὰρ ἐτύγχανεν ὡς τιμώμενος ἐν τῷ πλησιαιτάτῳ δίφρῳ Σεύθῃ καθήμενος .
perseus-eng2	for he chanced, as one held in honour, to be seated on the stool nearest to Seuthes.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.3.29
glaux1.0-sentence	3363
perseus-grc2	ὁ δὲ Ἡρακλείδης ἐκέλευεν αὐτῷ τὸ κέρας ὀρέξαι τὸν οἰνοχόον .
perseus-eng2	And Heracleides directed the cupbearer to proffer him the horn.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.3.29
glaux1.0-sentence	3364
perseus-grc2	ὁ δὲ Ξενοφῶν ( ἤδη γὰρ ὑποπεπωκὼς ἐτύγχανεν ) ἀνέστη θαρραλέως δεξάμενος τὸ κέρας καὶ εἶπεν ·
perseus-eng2	Then Xenophon, who already as it happened had been drinking a little, arose courageously after taking the horn and said:

cts:urn:0032-006:7.3.30
glaux1.0-sentence	3365
perseus-grc2	ἐγὼ δέ σοι , ὦ Σεύθη , δίδωμι ἐμαυτὸν καὶ τοὺς ἐμοὺς τούτους ἑταίρους φίλους εἶναι πιστούς , καὶ οὐδένα ἄκοντα , ἀλλὰ πάντας μᾶλλον ἔτι ἐμοῦ σοι βουλομένους φίλους εἶναι .
perseus-eng2	And I, Seuthes, give you myself and these my comrades to be your faithful friends; and not one of them do I give against his will, but all are even more desirous than I of being your friends.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.3.31
glaux1.0-sentence	3366
perseus-grc2	καὶ νῦν πάρεισιν οὐδέν σε προσαιτοῦντες , ἀλλὰ καὶ προϊέμενοι καὶ πονεῖν ὑπὲρ σοῦ καὶ προκινδυνεύειν ἐθέλοντες ·
perseus-eng2	And now they are here, asking you for nothing more, but rather putting themselves in your hands and willing to endure toil and danger on your behalf.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.3.31
glaux1.0-sentence	3367
perseus-grc2	μεθ’ ὧν , ἂν οἱ θεοὶ θέλωσι , πολλὴν χώραν τὴν μὲν ἀπολήψῃ πατρῴαν οὖσαν , τὴν δὲ κτήσῃ , πολλοὺς δὲ ἵππους , πολλοὺς δὲ ἄνδρας καὶ γυναῖκας καλὰς κτήσῃ , οὓς οὐ λῄζεσθαί σε δεήσει , ἀλλ’ αὐτοὶ φέροντες παρέσονται πρὸς σὲ δῶρα .
perseus-eng2	With them, if the gods so will, you will acquire great territory, recovering all that belonged to your fathers and gaining yet more, and you will acquire many horses, and many men and fair women; and these things you will not need to take as plunder, but my comrades of their own accord shall bring them before you as gifts.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.3.32
glaux1.0-sentence	3368
perseus-grc2	ἀναστὰς ὁ Σεύθης συνεξέπιε καὶ συγκατεσκεδάσατο μετ’ αὐτοῦ τὸ κέρας .
perseus-eng2	Up rose Seuthes, drained the horn with Xenophon, and joined him in sprinkling the last drops.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.3.32
glaux1.0-sentence	3369
perseus-grc2	μετὰ ταῦτα εἰσῆλθον κέρασί τε οἵοις σημαίνουσιν αὐλοῦντες καὶ σάλπιγξιν ὠμοβοείαις ῥυθμούς τε καὶ οἷον μαγάδι σαλπίζοντες .
perseus-eng2	After this there came in musicians blowing upon horns such as they use in giving signals, and playing upon trumpets of raw ox-hide not only measured notes, but music like that of a harp.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.3.33
glaux1.0-sentence	3370
perseus-grc2	καὶ αὐτὸς Σεύθης ἀναστὰς ἀνέκραγέ τε πολεμικὸν καὶ ἐξήλατο ὥσπερ βέλος φυλαττόμενος μάλα ἐλαφρῶς .
perseus-eng2	And Seuthes himself got up, raised a war-cry, and sprang aside very nimbly, as though avoiding a missile.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.3.33
glaux1.0-sentence	3371

cts:urn:0032-006:7.3.34
glaux1.0-sentence	3372

perseus-eng2	When the sun was about setting, the Greeks arose and said that it was time to post sentinels and give out the watchword.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.3.34

perseus-eng2	They also urged Seuthes to issue an order that none of the Thracians were to enter the Greek camp by night;

cts:urn:0032-006:7.3.34
glaux1.0-sentence	3374

cts:urn:0032-006:7.3.35

perseus-grc2	ἢν οὖν ἔλθωμεν ἐπ’ αὐτοὺς πρὶν φυλάξασθαι ὥστε μὴ ληφθῆναι ἢ παρασκευάσασθαι ὥστε ἀμύνασθαι , μάλιστ’ ἂν λάβοιμεν καὶ ἀνθρώπους καὶ χρήματα .
perseus-eng2	therefore if we go against them before they have got on guard against being captured or have made preparations to defend themselves, we should most surely get both captives and property.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.3.37

perseus-eng2	Well, now, consider this point, whether, if we are to make a night march, the Greek practice is not the better:

cts:urn:0032-006:7.3.37
glaux1.0-sentence	3385
perseus-grc2	μεθ’ ἡμέραν μὲν γὰρ ἐν ταῖς πορείαις ἡγεῖται τοῦ στρατεύματος ὁποῖον ἂν ἀεὶ πρὸς τὴν χώραν συμφέρῃ , ἐάν τε ὁπλιτικὸν ἐάν τε πελταστικὸν ἐάν τε ἱππικόν ·
perseus-eng2	in our marches by day, you know, that part of the army takes the lead which is suited to the nature of the ground in each case, whether it be hoplites or peltasts or cavalry;

cts:urn:0032-006:7.3.37
glaux1.0-sentence	3386

perseus-eng2	but by night it is the practice of the Greeks that the slowest arm should lead the way;

cts:urn:0032-006:7.3.38
glaux1.0-sentence	3387
perseus-grc2	οὕτω γὰρ ἥκιστα διασπᾶται τὰ στρατεύματα καὶ ἥκιστα λανθάνουσιν ἀποδιδράσκοντες ἀλλήλους ·
perseus-eng2	for thus the various parts of the army are least likely to become separated, and men are least likely to drop away from one another without knowing it;

cts:urn:0032-006:7.3.38
glaux1.0-sentence	3388

perseus-eng2	and it often happens that scattered divisions fall in with one another and in their ignorance inflict and suffer harm.

perseus-eng2	But unhappily my horsemen have gone off unsupported, scattering in their pursuit, and I fear that the enemy may get together somewhere in a body and work some harm.

perseus-eng2	Well," Xenophon replied, "I myself with the troops I have will seize the heights.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.3.48
glaux1.0-sentence	3428

perseus-eng2	And you, direct Cleanor to extend his line through the plain alongside the villages.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.3.48
glaux1.0-sentence	3429

perseus-eng2	When they had done these things, there were gathered together captives to the number of a thousand, two thousand cattle, and ten thousand smaller animals besides.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.3.48
glaux1.0-sentence	3430
perseus-grc2	τότε μὲν δὴ αὐτοῦ ηὐλίσθησαν .
perseus-eng2	Then they bivouacked where they were.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.4.1
glaux1.0-sentence	3431
perseus-grc2	τῇ δ’ ὑστεραίᾳ κατακαύσας ὁ Σεύθης τὰς κώμας παντελῶς καὶ οἰκίαν οὐδεμίαν λιπών , ὅπως φόβον ἐνθείη καὶ τοῖς ἄλλοις οἷα πείσονται , ἂν μὴ πείθωνται , ἀπῄει πάλιν .
perseus-eng2	On the following day, after Seuthes had burned up the villages completely and left not a single house, in order that he might inspire the rest of his enemies also with fear of the sort of fate they would suffer if they did not yield him obedience, he went back again.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.4.2
glaux1.0-sentence	3432
perseus-grc2	καὶ τὴν μὲν λείαν ἀπέπεμψε διατίθεσθαι Ἡρακλείδην εἰς Πέρινθον , ὅπως ἂν μισθὸς γένοιτο τοῖς στρατιώταις ·
perseus-eng2	Then he dispatched Heracleides to Perinthus to sell the booty, so that he might get money to pay the soldiers with;

cts:urn:0032-006:7.4.2
glaux1.0-sentence	3433

cts:urn:0032-006:7.4.3
glaux1.0-sentence	3434
perseus-grc2	οἱ δ’ ἐκλιπόντες ἔφευγον εἰς τὰ ὄρη .
perseus-eng2	The inhabitants, abandoning their homes, fled to the mountains.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.4.3
glaux1.0-sentence	3435
perseus-grc2	ἦν δὲ χιὼν πολλὴ καὶ ψῦχος οὕτως ὥστε τὸ ὕδωρ ὃ ἐφέροντο ἐπὶ δεῖπνον ἐπήγνυτο καὶ ὁ οἶνος ὁ ἐν τοῖς ἀγγείοις , καὶ τῶν Ἑλλήνων πολλῶν καὶ ῥῖνες ἀπεκαίοντο καὶ ὦτα .
perseus-eng2	There was deep snow on the plain, and it was so cold that the water which they carried in for dinner and the wine in the jars would freeze, and many of the Greeks had their noses and ears frost-bitten.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.4.4
glaux1.0-sentence	3436
perseus-grc2	καὶ τότε δῆλον ἐγένετο οὗ ἕνεκα οἱ Θρᾷκες τὰς ἀλωπεκᾶς ἐπὶ ταῖς κεφαλαῖς φοροῦσι καὶ τοῖς ὠσί , καὶ χιτῶνας οὐ μόνον περὶ τοῖς στέρνοις ἀλλὰ καὶ περὶ τοῖς μηροῖς , καὶ ζειρὰς μέχρι τῶν ποδῶν ἐπὶ τῶν ἵππων ἔχουσιν , ἀλλ’ οὐ χλαμύδας .
perseus-eng2	Then it became clear why the Thracians wear fox-skin caps on their heads and over their ears, and tunics not merely about their chests, but also round their thighs, and why, when on horseback, they wear long cloaks reaching to their feet instead of mantles.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.4.5
glaux1.0-sentence	3437
perseus-grc2	ἀφιεὶς δὲ τῶν αἰχμαλώτων ὁ Σεύθης εἰς τὰ ὄρη ἔλεγεν ὅτι εἰ μὴ καταβήσονται οἰκήσοντες καὶ πείσονται , ὅτι κατακαύσει καὶ τούτων τὰς κώμας καὶ τὸν σῖτον , καὶ ἀπολοῦνται τῷ λιμῷ .
perseus-eng2	And now Seuthes allowed some of his captives to go off to the mountains with word that if the Thynians did not come down to the plain to live and did not yield him obedience, he would burn up their villages also and their corn, and they would perish with hunger.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.4.5
glaux1.0-sentence	3438
perseus-grc2	ἐκ τούτου κατέβαινον καὶ γυναῖκες καὶ παῖδες καὶ πρεσβύτεροι ·

cts:urn:0032-006:7.4.5
glaux1.0-sentence	3439

cts:urn:0032-006:7.4.6
glaux1.0-sentence	3440

perseus-eng2	And Seuthes, upon learning of this, ordered Xenophon to take the youngest of the hoplites and follow him.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.4.6

cts:urn:0032-006:7.4.6

cts:urn:0032-006:7.4.6

cts:urn:0032-006:7.4.7
glaux1.0-sentence	3445
perseus-grc2	Ἐπισθένης δ’ ἦν τις Ὀλύνθιος παιδεραστής , ὃς ἰδὼν παῖδα καλὸν ἡβάσκοντα ἄρτι πέλτην ἔχοντα μέλλοντα ἀποθνῄσκειν , προσδραμὼν Ξενοφῶντα ἱκέτευε βοηθῆσαι παιδὶ καλῷ .
perseus-eng2	There was a certain Episthenes of Olynthus who was a lover of boys, and upon seeing a handsome boy, just in the bloom of youth and carrying a light shield, on the point of being put to death, he ran up to Xenophon and besought him to come to the rescue of a handsome lad.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.4.8
glaux1.0-sentence	3446
perseus-grc2	καὶ ὃς προσελθὼν τῷ Σεύθῃ δεῖται μὴ ἀποκτεῖναι τὸν παῖδα , καὶ τοῦ Ἐπισθένους διηγεῖται τὸν τρόπον , καὶ ὅτι λόχον ποτὲ συνελέξατο σκοπῶν οὐδὲν ἄλλο ἢ εἴ τινες εἶεν καλοί , καὶ μετὰ τούτων ἦν ἀνὴρ ἀγαθός .
perseus-eng2	So Xenophon went to Seuthes and begged him not to kill the boy, telling him of Episthenes’ turn of mind, how he had once assembled a battalion with an eye to nothing else save the question whether a man was handsome, and that with this battalion he proved himself a brave man.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.4.9
glaux1.0-sentence	3447

perseus-eng2	And Seuthes asked:

cts:urn:0032-006:7.4.9
glaux1.0-sentence	3449
perseus-grc2	ὁ δ’ ὑπερανατείνας τὸν τράχηλον , παῖε , ἔφη , εἰ κελεύει ὁ παῖς καὶ μέλλει χάριν εἰδέναι .
perseus-eng2	Then Episthenes stretched out his neck and said, "Strike, if the lad bids you and will be grateful."

cts:urn:0032-006:7.4.10

perseus-eng2	He resolved, however, to establish a camp where they were, in order that the people on the mountain should not be supplied with food from these villages, either.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.4.11

perseus-eng2	So he himself went quietly down the mountain and encamped upon the plain, while Xenophon with his picked men took quarters in the uppermost village below the summit and the rest of the Greeks close by, among the so-called "mountain" Thracians.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.4.12

perseus-eng2	Not many days had passed after this when the Thracians on the mountain came down and entered into negotiations with Seuthes in regard to a truce and hostages.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.4.12

perseus-eng2	And Xenophon came and told Seuthes that his men were in bad quarters and the enemy were close at hand;

cts:urn:0032-006:7.4.12

perseus-eng2	he would be better pleased, he said, to bivouac in the open in a strong position than to be in the houses and run the risk of being destroyed.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.4.12

cts:urn:0032-006:7.4.13

cts:urn:0032-006:7.4.13

perseus-eng2	He agreed to do so, told them to have no fear, and gave them his word that they would suffer no harm if they were obedient to Seuthes.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.4.15
glaux1.0-sentence	3470
perseus-grc2	ἐπεὶ δ’ ἐγένοντο κατὰ τὰς θύρας ἑκάστου τοῦ οἰκήματος , οἱ μὲν εἰσηκόντιζον , οἱ δὲ τοῖς σκυτάλοις ἔβαλλον , ἃ ἔχειν ἔφασαν ὡς ἀποκόψοντες τῶν δοράτων τὰς λόγχας , οἱ δ’ ἐνεπίμπρασαν , καὶ Ξενοφῶντα ὀνομαστὶ καλοῦντες ἐξιόντα ἐκέλευον ἀποθνῄσκειν , ἢ αὐτοῦ ἔφασαν κατακαυθήσεσθαι αὐτόν .
perseus-eng2	When they had reached the doors of a particular house, some would throw in javelins, others would lay on with their clubs, which they carried, so it was said, to knock off the heads of hostile spears, and still others would be setting the house on fire, meanwhile calling Xenophon by name and bidding him come out and be killed, or else, they said, he would be burned up then and there.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.4.16
glaux1.0-sentence	3471

perseus-eng2	And now fire was already showing through the roof, and Xenophon and his men inside the house had equipped themselves with breastplates and were furnished with shields and swords and helmets, when  Silanus  the Macistian, a lad of about eighteen years, gave a signal with the trumpet;

perseus-eng2	Now by this time Seuthes had a force quite three times as large as before;

cts:urn:0032-006:7.4.21
glaux1.0-sentence	3489
perseus-grc2	ἐκ γὰρ τῶν Ὀδρυσῶν ἀκούοντες ἃ πράττει ὁ Σεύθης πολλοὶ κατέβαινον συστρατευσόμενοι .
perseus-eng2	for many of the Odrysians, hearing what success Seuthes was enjoying, came down from the upper country to take service with him.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.4.22
glaux1.0-sentence	3490
perseus-grc2	οἱ δὲ Θυνοὶ ἐπεὶ εἶδον ἀπὸ τοῦ ὄρους πολλοὺς μὲν ὁπλίτας , πολλοὺς δὲ πελταστάς , πολλοὺς δὲ ἱππέας , καταβάντες ἱκέτευον σπείσασθαι , καὶ πάντα ὡμολόγουν ποιήσειν καὶ πιστὰ λαμβάνειν ἐκέλευον .
perseus-eng2	And when the Thynians saw from their mountain masses of hoplites, masses of peltasts, and troops of horsemen, they descended and besought him to grant them a truce, agreeing to do anything and everything and urging him to receive pledges.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.4.23
glaux1.0-sentence	3491
perseus-grc2	ὁ δὲ Σεύθης καλέσας τὸν Ξενοφῶντα ἐπεδείκνυεν ἃ λέγοιεν , καὶ οὐκ ἂν ἔφη σπείσασθαι , εἰ Ξενοφῶν βούλοιτο τιμωρήσασθαι αὐτοὺς τῆς ἐπιθέσεως .
perseus-eng2	Thereupon Seuthes summoned Xenophon, disclosed to him the proposals they were making, and said that he should not grant them a truce if Xenophon wanted to punish them for their attack.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.4.24
glaux1.0-sentence	3492
perseus-grc2	ὁ δ’ εἶπεν ·
perseus-eng2	And Xenophon said:

cts:urn:0032-006:7.4.24
glaux1.0-sentence	3493
perseus-grc2	ἀλλ’ ἔγωγε ἱκανὴν νομίζω καὶ νῦν δίκην ἔχειν , εἰ οὗτοι δοῦλοι ἔσονται ἀντ’ ἐλευθέρων .
perseus-eng2	Why, for my part I think I have abundant satisfaction as it is, if these people are to be slaves instead of free men.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.4.24
glaux1.0-sentence	3494
perseus-grc2	συμβουλεύειν μέντοι ἔφη αὐτῷ τὸ λοιπὸν ὁμήρους λαμβάνειν τοὺς δυνατωτάτους κακόν τι ποιεῖν , τοὺς δὲ γέροντας οἴκοι ἐᾶν .
perseus-eng2	He added, however, that he advised Seuthes to take as hostages in the future those who were most capable of doing harm and to leave the old men at home.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.4.24

cts:urn:0032-006:7.5.1
glaux1.0-sentence	3496

perseus-eng2	And now they crossed over to the country of the Thracians above  Byzantium , in the so-called Delta.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.5.1
glaux1.0-sentence	3497

cts:urn:0032-006:7.5.2
glaux1.0-sentence	3498

cts:urn:0032-006:7.5.2
glaux1.0-sentence	3499

perseus-eng2	And Seuthes, leading forth three pairs of mules—for there were no more than three—and the yokes of oxen besides, called Xenophon and bade him take for himself and then distribute the rest among the generals and captains.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.5.3

perseus-eng2	Well, for my part I am content to get something at a later time;

cts:urn:0032-006:7.5.3
glaux1.0-sentence	3502

cts:urn:0032-006:7.5.4

perseus-eng2	Seuthes also paid over the wages of the troops, but for twenty days only of the month that had now passed;

cts:urn:0032-006:7.5.4
glaux1.0-sentence	3506

perseus-eng2	for Heracleides said that he had not obtained any more than that from his sale.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.5.5

cts:urn:0032-006:7.5.5
glaux1.0-sentence	3508

cts:urn:0032-006:7.5.5
glaux1.0-sentence	3509

perseus-eng2	for if you were, you would have brought back with you our wages in full, even if you had to borrow something, in case you could not do it in any other way, or to sell your own clothes.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.5.6
glaux1.0-sentence	3510
perseus-grc2	ἐντεῦθεν ὁ Ἡρακλείδης ἠχθέσθη τε καὶ ἔδεισε μὴ ἐκ τῆς Σεύθου φιλίας ἐκβληθείη , καὶ ὅ τι ἐδύνατο ἀπὸ ταύτης τῆς ἡμέρας Ξενοφῶντα διέβαλλε πρὸς Σεύθην .
perseus-eng2	This made Heracleides not only angry, but fearful that he might be banished from the favour of Seuthes, and from that day he slandered Xenophon before Seuthes to the best of his ability.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.5.7
glaux1.0-sentence	3511
perseus-grc2	οἱ μὲν δὴ στρατιῶται Ξενοφῶντι ἐνεκάλουν ὅτι οὐκ εἶχον τὸν μισθόν ·
perseus-eng2	As for the soldiers, they held Xenophon to blame for their not having received their pay;

cts:urn:0032-006:7.5.7
glaux1.0-sentence	3512

perseus-eng2	and Seuthes, on the other hand, was angry with him because he was insistent in demanding their pay for the soldiers.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.5.8
glaux1.0-sentence	3513

perseus-eng2	Hitherto, he had continually been mentioning the fact that upon his return to the coast he was going to give Xenophon Bisanthe and Ganos and  Neonteichos .

cts:urn:0032-006:7.5.8

cts:urn:0032-006:7.5.8
glaux1.0-sentence	3515

perseus-eng2	For Heracleides had put in this slanderous suggestion with the rest, that it was not safe to be giving over fortresses to a man who had a force of troops.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.5.9

perseus-eng2	Hereupon Xenophon began to consider what it was best to do about continuing the march still farther inland;

cts:urn:0032-006:7.5.9

perseus-eng2	Heracleides, on the other hand, took the rest of the generals in to visit Seuthes and bade them say that they could lead the army just as well as Xenophon, while at the same time he promised them that within a few days they would have their pay in full for two months and urged them to continue the campaign with Seuthes.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.5.10

perseus-grc2	ἐγὼ μὲν τοίνυν οὐδ’ ἂν πέντε μηνῶν μισθὸς μέλλῃ εἶναι στρατευσαίμην ἂν ἄνευ Ξενοφῶντος .
perseus-eng2	Well, so far as I am concerned, I shall undertake no campaign without Xenophon even if there is going to be five months’ pay.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.5.10

perseus-eng2	And he, comprehending the rascality of Heracleides, in wanting to make him an object of suspicion to the other generals, brought with him when he came all the generals and the captains.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.5.12

perseus-eng2	When all of them had been prevailed upon, they continued the march with Seuthes, and, keeping the  Pontus  upon the right through the country of the millet-eating Thracians, as they are called, arrived at Salmydessus.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.5.12
glaux1.0-sentence	3525

perseus-eng2	And the Thracians who dwell on this coast have boundary stones set up and each group of them plunder the ships that are wrecked within their own limits;

cts:urn:0032-006:7.5.14

perseus-grc2	ἐνταῦθα ηὑρίσκοντο πολλαὶ μὲν κλῖναι , πολλὰ δὲ κιβώτια , πολλαὶ δὲ βίβλοι γεγραμμέναι , καὶ τ- ἄλλα πολλὰ ὅσα ἐν ξυλίνοις τεύχεσι ναύκληροι ἄγουσιν .

cts:urn:0032-006:7.5.16

perseus-eng2	and not only did the soldiers entertain very hard feelings toward Xenophon, but Seuthes no longer felt kindly toward him, and whenever Xenophon came and wanted to have a meeting with him, it would straightway be found that he had engagements in abundance.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.6.1

perseus-eng2	At this time, when nearly two months had already passed, Charminus the Laconian and Polynicus arrived on a mission from Thibron: they said that the Lacedaemonians had resolved to undertake a campaign against Tissaphernes, that Thibron had set sail to wage the war, and that he wanted this army; also that he said the pay would be a daric per month for every man, twice as much for the captains, and four times as much for the generals.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.6.2

perseus-eng2	When the Lacedaemonians arrived, Heracleides learned on the instant that they had come to get the army, and told Seuthes that a most fortunate thing had happened:

cts:urn:0032-006:7.6.2
glaux1.0-sentence	3538

perseus-eng2	The Lacedaemonians want the army, and you no longer want it;

cts:urn:0032-006:7.6.2
glaux1.0-sentence	3539
perseus-grc2	ἀποδιδοὺς δὲ τὸ στράτευμα χαριῇ αὐτοῖς , σὲ δὲ οὐκέτι ἀπαιτήσουσι τὸν μισθόν , ἀλλ’ ἀπαλλάξονται ἐκ τῆς χώρας .
perseus-eng2	by giving up the army you will be doing them a favour, while, on your side, the troops will not go on demanding their pay from you, but will soon be quitting the country.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.6.3

cts:urn:0032-006:7.6.3

perseus-eng2	and when they told him that they had come after the army, he replied that he would deliver it up and that he desired to be their friend and ally;

cts:urn:0032-006:7.6.4

perseus-eng2	When the Lacedaemonians asked what sort of a man Xenophon was, he replied that he was not a bad fellow on the whole, but he was a friend of the soldiers.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.6.4
glaux1.0-sentence	3548
perseus-grc2	καὶ ὁ Ἡρακλείδης , πάνυ μὲν οὖν , ἔφη .
perseus-eng2	"Exactly that," said Heracleides.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.6.5
glaux1.0-sentence	3549
perseus-grc2	ἆρ’ οὖν , ἔφασαν , μὴ καὶ ἡμῖν ἐναντιώσεται τῆς ἀπαγωγῆς ;
perseus-eng2	Well," said they, "he won’t go so far, will he, as to oppose us in the matter of taking away the army?

cts:urn:0032-006:7.6.5
glaux1.0-sentence	3550
perseus-grc2	ἀλλ’ ἢν ὑμεῖς , ἔφη ὁ Ἡρακλείδης , συλλέξαντες αὐτοὺς ὑπόσχησθε τὸν μισθόν , ὀλίγον ἐκείνῳ προσχόντες ἀποδραμοῦνται σὺν ὑμῖν .
perseus-eng2	Why," said Heracleides, "if you gather the men together and promise them their pay, they will hurry after you, paying scant heed to him.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.6.6
glaux1.0-sentence	3551
perseus-grc2	πῶς οὖν ἄν , ἔφασαν , ἡμῖν συλλεγεῖεν ;
perseus-eng2	How, then," they said, "could we get them together?

cts:urn:0032-006:7.6.6
glaux1.0-sentence	3552
perseus-grc2	αὔριον ὑμᾶς , ἔφη ὁ Ἡρακλείδης , πρῲ ἄξομεν πρὸς αὐτούς ·
perseus-eng2	To-morrow morning," Heracleides replied, "we will take you to them;

cts:urn:0032-006:7.6.6
glaux1.0-sentence	3553
perseus-grc2	καὶ οἶδα , ἔφη , ὅτι ἐπειδὰν ὑμᾶς ἴδωσιν , ἄσμενοι συνδραμοῦνται .
perseus-eng2	and I know," he continued, "that as soon as they catch sight of you, they will hurry together with all eagerness.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.6.6
glaux1.0-sentence	3554
perseus-grc2	αὕτη μὲν ἡ ἡμέρα οὕτως ἔληξεν .
perseus-eng2	So ended this day.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.6.7
glaux1.0-sentence	3555
perseus-grc2	τῇ δ’ ὑστεραίᾳ ἄγουσιν ἐπὶ τὸ στράτευμα τοὺς Λάκωνας Σεύθης τε καὶ Ἡρακλείδης , καὶ συλλέγεται ἡ στρατιά .
perseus-eng2	The next day Seuthes and Heracleides conducted the Laconians to the army, and the troops gathered together.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.6.7
glaux1.0-sentence	3556
perseus-grc2	τὼ δὲ Λάκωνε ἐλεγέτην ὅτι Λακεδαιμονίοις δοκεῖ πολεμεῖν Τισσαφέρνει τῷ ὑμᾶς ἀδικήσαντι ·
perseus-eng2	And the two Laconians said: "The Lacedaemonians have resolved to make war upon Tissaphernes, the man who wronged you;"

cts:urn:0032-006:7.6.7
glaux1.0-sentence	3557
perseus-grc2	ἢν οὖν ἴητε σὺν ἡμῖν , τόν τε ἐχθρὸν τιμωρήσεσθε καὶ δαρεικὸν ἕκαστος οἴσει τοῦ μηνὸς ὑμῶν , λοχαγὸς δὲ τὸ διπλοῦν , στρατηγὸς δὲ τὸ τετραπλοῦν .
perseus-eng2	so if you will come with us, you will punish your enemy and, besides, each one of you will receive a daric a month, each captain twofold, and each general fourfold.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.6.8
glaux1.0-sentence	3558
perseus-grc2	καὶ οἱ στρατιῶται ἄσμενοί τε ἤκουσαν καὶ εὐθὺς ἀνίσταταί τις τῶν Ἀρκάδων τοῦ Ξενοφῶντος κατηγορήσων .
perseus-eng2	The soldiers were delighted to hear these words, and straightway one of the Arcadians got up to accuse Xenophon.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.6.8
glaux1.0-sentence	3559
perseus-grc2	παρῆν δὲ καὶ Σεύθης βουλόμενος εἰδέναι τί πραχθήσεται , καὶ ἐν ἐπηκόῳ εἱστήκει ἔχων ἑρμηνέα ·
perseus-eng2	Now Seuthes also was present, for he wanted to know what would be done, and was standing within hearing distance along with an interpreter,

cts:urn:0032-006:7.6.9
glaux1.0-sentence	3560
perseus-grc2	ξυνίει δὲ καὶ αὐτὸς Ἑλληνιστὶ τὰ πλεῖστα .
perseus-eng2	although he could really understand for himself most of what was said in Greek.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.6.9
glaux1.0-sentence	3561
perseus-grc2	ἔνθα δὴ λέγει ὁ Ἀρκάς ·
perseus-eng2	Thereupon this Arcadian said:

cts:urn:0032-006:7.6.9
glaux1.0-sentence	3562
perseus-grc2	ἀλλ’ ἡμεῖς μέν , ὦ Λακεδαιμόνιοι , καὶ πάλαι ἂν ἦμεν παρ’ ὑμῖν , εἰ μὴ Ξενοφῶν ἡμᾶς δεῦρο πείσας ἀπήγαγεν , ἔνθα δὴ ἡμεῖς μὲν τὸν δεινὸν χειμῶνα στρατευόμενοι καὶ νύκτα καὶ ἡμέραν οὐδὲν πεπαύμεθα ·
perseus-eng2	For our part, Lacedaemonians, we should have been with you a long time ago if Xenophon had not talked us over and led us off to this region, where we have never ceased campaigning, by night or day, through an awful winter.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.6.9
glaux1.0-sentence	3563
perseus-grc2	ὁ δὲ τοὺς ἡμετέρους πόνους ἔχει ·
perseus-eng2	He gets the fruits of our toils;

cts:urn:0032-006:7.6.9
glaux1.0-sentence	3564
perseus-grc2	καὶ Σεύθης ἐκεῖνον μὲν ἰδίᾳ πεπλούτικεν , ἡμᾶς δὲ ἀποστερεῖ τὸν μισθόν ·
perseus-eng2	for Seuthes has enriched him personally while he defrauds us of our pay;

cts:urn:0032-006:7.6.10
glaux1.0-sentence	3565
perseus-grc2	ὥστε ὅ γε πρῶτος λέγων ἐγὼ μὲν εἰ τοῦτον ἴδοιμι καταλευσθέντα καὶ δόντα δίκην ὧν ἡμᾶς περιεῖλκε , καὶ τὸν μισθὸν ἄν μοι δοκῶ ἔχειν καὶ οὐδὲν ἐπὶ τοῖς πεπονημένοις ἄχθεσθαι .
perseus-eng2	so for myself, if I could see this fellow stoned to death as punishment for having dragged us about as he has done, I should consider that I had my pay and should feel no anger over the toils I have endured.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.6.10
glaux1.0-sentence	3566
perseus-grc2	μετὰ τοῦτον ἄλλος ἀνέστη ὁμοίως καὶ ἄλλος .
perseus-eng2	After this speaker another arose and talked in the same way, and then another.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.6.10
glaux1.0-sentence	3567
perseus-grc2	ἐκ δὲ τούτου Ξενοφῶν ἔλεξεν ὧδε .
perseus-eng2	After that Xenophon spoke as follows:

cts:urn:0032-006:7.6.11
glaux1.0-sentence	3568
perseus-grc2	ἀλλὰ πάντα μὲν ἄρα ἄνθρωπον ὄντα προσδοκᾶν δεῖ , ὁπότε γε καὶ ἐγὼ νῦν ὑφ’ ὑμῶν αἰτίας ἔχω ἐν ᾧ πλείστην προθυμίαν ἐμαυτῷ γε δοκῶ συνειδέναι περὶ ὑμᾶς παρεσχημένος .
perseus-eng2	Well, it is true, after all, that a human being must expect anything and everything, seeing that I now find myself blamed by you in a matter where I am conscious—at least, in my own opinion—of having shown the utmost zeal in your behalf.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.6.11
glaux1.0-sentence	3569
perseus-grc2	ἀπετραπόμην μέν γε ἤδη οἴκαδε ὡρμημένος , οὐ μὰ τὸν Δία οὔτοι πυνθανόμενος ὑμᾶς εὖ πράττειν , ἀλλὰ μᾶλλον ἀκούων ἐν ἀπόροις εἶναι ὡς ὠφελήσων εἴ τι δυναίμην .
perseus-eng2	I turned back after I had already set out for home, not—Heaven knows it was not—because I learned that you were prospering, but rather because I heard that you were in difficulties; and I turned back to help you in any way I could.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.6.12
glaux1.0-sentence	3570
perseus-grc2	ἐπεὶ δὲ ἦλθον , Σεύθου τουτουὶ πολλοὺς ἀγγέλους πρὸς ἐμὲ πέμποντος καὶ πολλὰ ὑπισχνουμένου μοι , εἰ πείσαιμι ὑμᾶς πρὸς αὐτὸν ἐλθεῖν , τοῦτο μὲν οὐκ ἐπεχείρησα ποιεῖν , ὡς αὐτοὶ ὑμεῖς ἐπίστασθε .
perseus-eng2	When I had arrived, although Seuthes here sent many messengers to me and made me many promises if only I would persuade you to come to him, I did not try to do that, as you know for yourselves.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.6.12
glaux1.0-sentence	3571
perseus-grc2	ἦγον δὲ ὅθεν ᾠόμην τάχιστ’ ἂν ὑμᾶς εἰς τὴν Ἀσίαν διαβῆναι .
perseus-eng2	Instead, I led you to a place from which I thought you could most speedily cross over to  Asia ;

cts:urn:0032-006:7.6.12
glaux1.0-sentence	3572
perseus-grc2	ταῦτα γὰρ καὶ βέλτιστα ἐνόμιζον ὑμῖν εἶναι καὶ ὑμᾶς ᾔδειν βουλομένους .
perseus-eng2	for I believed that this course was the best one for you and I knew it was the one you desired.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.6.13
glaux1.0-sentence	3573
perseus-grc2	ἐπεὶ δ’ Ἀρίσταρχος ἐλθὼν σὺν τριήρεσιν ἐκώλυε διαπλεῖν ἡμᾶς , ἐκ τούτου , ὅπερ εἰκὸς δήπου ἦν , συνέλεξα ὑμᾶς , ὅπως βουλευσαίμεθα ὅ τι χρὴ ποιεῖν .
perseus-eng2	But when Aristarchus came with his triremes and prevented our sailing across, at that moment—and surely it was exactly the proper step—I gathered you together so that we might consider what we should better do.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.6.14
glaux1.0-sentence	3574
perseus-grc2	οὐκοῦν ὑμεῖς ἀκούοντες μὲν Ἀριστάρχου ἐπιτάττοντος ὑμῖν εἰς Χερρόνησον πορεύεσθαι , ἀκούοντες δὲ Σεύθου πείθοντος ἑαυτῷ συστρατεύεσθαι , πάντες μὲν ἐλέγετε σὺν Σεύθῃ ἰέναι , πάντες δ’ ἐψηφίσασθε ταῦτα .
perseus-eng2	So you with your own ears heard Aristarchus direct you to march to the  Chersonese  and you heard Seuthes urge you to take the field with him, and then every man of you spoke in favour of going with Seuthes and every man of you voted to do so.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.6.14
glaux1.0-sentence	3575
perseus-grc2	τί οὖν ἐγὼ ἐνταῦθα ἠδίκησα ἀγαγὼν ὑμᾶς ἔνθα πᾶσιν ὑμῖν ἐδόκει ;
perseus-eng2	What wrong, therefore, did I do in that matter, when I led you to the place where you had all decided to go?

cts:urn:0032-006:7.6.15
glaux1.0-sentence	3576
perseus-grc2	ἐπεί γε μὴν ψεύδεσθαι ἤρξατο Σεύθης περὶ τοῦ μισθοῦ , εἰ μὲν ἐπαινῶ αὐτόν , δικαίως ἄν με καὶ αἰτιῷσθε καὶ μισοῖτε ·
perseus-eng2	I come now to the time when Seuthes began to play false with you in the matter of your pay: if I am his supporter in that, it would be just for you to blame me and hate me;

cts:urn:0032-006:7.6.15
glaux1.0-sentence	3577
perseus-grc2	εἰ δὲ πρόσθεν αὐτῷ πάντων μάλιστα φίλος ὢν νῦν πάντων διαφορώτατός εἰμι , πῶς ἂν ἔτι δικαίως ὑμᾶς αἱρούμενος ἀντὶ Σεύθου ὑφ’ ὑμῶν αἰτίαν ἔχοιμι περὶ ὧν πρὸς τοῦτον διαφέρομαι ;
perseus-eng2	but if the truth is that I, who before that was the most friendly to him of us all, am now most of all at variance with him, how can it be just in this case that, when I sided with you rather than with Seuthes, I should be blamed by you about the things in which I am at variance with him?

cts:urn:0032-006:7.6.16
glaux1.0-sentence	3578
perseus-grc2	ἀλλ’ εἴποιτ’ ἂν ὅτι ἔξεστι καὶ τὰ ὑμέτερα ἔχοντα παρὰ Σεύθου τεχνάζειν .
perseus-eng2	But it is possible, you might say, that I really have received from Seuthes the money that belongs to you, and am only tricking you.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.6.16
glaux1.0-sentence	3579
perseus-grc2	οὐκοῦν δῆλον τοῦτό γέ ἐστιν , εἴπερ ἐμοὶ ἐτέλει τι Σεύθης , οὐχ οὕτως ἐτέλει δήπου ὡς ὧν τε ἐμοὶ δοίη στέροιτο καὶ ἄλλα ὑμῖν ἀποτείσειεν , ἀλλ’ οἶμαι , εἰ ἐδίδου , ἐπὶ τούτῳ ἂν ἐδίδου ὅπως ἐμοὶ δοὺς μεῖον μὴ ἀποδοίη ὑμῖν τὸ πλέον .
perseus-eng2	Then this at least is clear: if Seuthes was in fact paying anything to me, he surely was not paying it with the understanding that he was both to lose whatever he gave me and at the same time was to pay other sums to you, but rather, I presume, if he was giving me anything, he was giving it with this understanding, that by giving a smaller sum to me he was to escape paying over the larger to you.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.6.17
glaux1.0-sentence	3580
perseus-grc2	εἰ τοίνυν οὕτως ἔχειν οἴεσθε , ἔξεστιν ὑμῖν αὐτίκα μάλα ματαίαν ταύτην τὴν πρᾶξιν ἀμφοτέροις ἡμῖν ποιῆσαι , ἐὰν πράττητε αὐτὸν τὰ χρήματα .
perseus-eng2	Now if you imagine that this is the case, it is within your power upon the instant to make this transaction a vain one for us both by exacting your money from him.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.6.17
glaux1.0-sentence	3581
perseus-grc2	δῆλον γὰρ ὅτι Σεύθης , εἰ ἔχω τι παρ’ αὐτοῦ , ἀπαιτήσει με , καὶ ἀπαιτήσει μέντοι δικαίως , ἐὰν μὴ βεβαιῶ τὴν πρᾶξιν αὐτῷ ἐφ’ ᾗ ἐδωροδόκουν .
perseus-eng2	For it is clear that, if I have received anything from Seuthes, he will demand it back from me, and, moreover, he will demand it back with justice if I am failing to fulfil to him the undertaking for which I was accepting his gifts.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.6.18
glaux1.0-sentence	3582
perseus-grc2	ἀλλὰ πολλοῦ μοι δοκῶ δεῖν τὰ ὑμέτερα ἔχειν ·
perseus-eng2	But it is far from being true, in my opinion, that I have received what belongs to you;

cts:urn:0032-006:7.6.18
glaux1.0-sentence	3583
perseus-grc2	ὀμνύω γὰρ ὑμῖν θεοὺς ἅπαντας καὶ πάσας μηδ’ ἃ ἐμοὶ ἰδίᾳ ὑπέσχετο Σεύθης ἔχειν ·
perseus-eng2	for I swear to you by all the gods and goddesses that I have not even received what Seuthes promised to me for my own services;

cts:urn:0032-006:7.6.18
glaux1.0-sentence	3584
perseus-grc2	πάρεστι δὲ καὶ αὐτὸς καὶ ἀκούων σύνοιδέ μοι εἰ ἐπιορκῶ ·
perseus-eng2	he is present here himself, and as he listens he knows as well as I do whether I am swearing falsely;

cts:urn:0032-006:7.6.19
glaux1.0-sentence	3585
perseus-grc2	ἵνα δὲ μᾶλλον θαυμάσητε , συνεπόμνυμι μηδὲ ἃ οἱ ἄλλοι στρατηγοὶ ἔλαβον εἰληφέναι , μὴ τοίνυν μηδὲ ὅσα τῶν λοχαγῶν ἔνιοι .
perseus-eng2	furthermore, to make your wonder the greater, I swear besides that I have not even received what the other generals have received—nay, not even so much as some of the captains.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.6.20
glaux1.0-sentence	3586
perseus-grc2	καὶ τί δὴ ταῦτ’ ἐποίουν ;
perseus-eng2	And why, then, did I follow this course?

cts:urn:0032-006:7.6.20
glaux1.0-sentence	3587
perseus-grc2	ᾤμην , ἄνδρες , ὅσω , μᾶλλον συμφέροιμι τούτῳ τὴν τότε πενίαν , τοσούτῳ μᾶλλον αὐτὸν φίλον ποιήσεσθαι , ὁπότε δυνασθείη .
perseus-eng2	I supposed, soldiers, that the more I helped this man to bear the poverty in which he then was, the more I should make him my friend when he should have gained power.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.6.20

perseus-grc2	ἐγὼ δὲ ἅμα τε αὐτὸν ὁρῶ εὖ πράττοντα καὶ γιγνώσκω δὴ αὐτοῦ τὴν γνώμην .
perseus-eng2	But in fact I no sooner see him enjoying prosperity than I recognize his true character.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.6.21

perseus-eng2	One might say, "Are you not ashamed of being so stupidly deceived?"

cts:urn:0032-006:7.6.21
glaux1.0-sentence	3590
perseus-grc2	ναὶ μὰ Δία ᾐσχυνόμην μ- μέντἀν , εἰ ὑπὸ πολεμίου γε ὄντος ἐξηπατήθην ·
perseus-eng2	I certainly should be ashamed, by Zeus, if I had been deceived by one who was an enemy;

cts:urn:0032-006:7.6.21
glaux1.0-sentence	3591
perseus-grc2	φίλῳ δὲ ὄντι ἐξαπατᾶν αἴσχιόν μοι δοκεῖ εἶναι ἢ ἐξαπατᾶσθαι .
perseus-eng2	but for one who is a friend, to deceive seems to me more shameful than to be deceived.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.6.22

perseus-eng2	For if there is such a thing as precaution toward friends, I know that we took every precaution not to afford this man a just pretext for not paying us what he had promised;

cts:urn:0032-006:7.6.22
glaux1.0-sentence	3593
perseus-grc2	οὔτε γὰρ ἠδικήσαμεν τοῦτον οὐδὲν οὔτε κατεβλακεύσαμεν τὰ τούτου οὐδὲ μὴν κατεδειλιάσαμεν οὐδὲν ἐφ’ ὅ τι ἡμᾶς οὗτος παρεκάλεσεν .
perseus-eng2	for we neither did this man any wrong, nor did we mismanage his affairs, nor yet did we shrink like cowards from any service to which he summoned us.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.6.23
glaux1.0-sentence	3594
perseus-grc2	ἀλλά , φαίητε ἄν , ἔδει τὰ ἐνέχυρα τότε λαβεῖν , ὡς μηδ’ εἰ ἐβούλετο ἐδύνατο ἐξαπατᾶν .
perseus-eng2	But, you might say, sureties ought to have been taken at the time, so that he could not have deceived us even if he had wanted to do so.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.6.23
glaux1.0-sentence	3595
perseus-grc2	πρὸς ταῦτα δὴ ἀκούσατε ἃ ἐγὼ οὐκ ἄν ποτε εἶπον τούτου ἐναντίον , εἰ μή μοι παντάπασιν ἀγνώμονες ἐδοκεῖτε εἶναι ἢ λίαν εἰς ἐμὲ ἀχάριστοι .
perseus-eng2	In reply to that, listen to words which I never should have spoken in this man’s presence if you had not seemed to me utterly senseless—or at least exceedingly thankless toward me.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.6.24
glaux1.0-sentence	3596
perseus-grc2	ἀναμνήσθητε γὰρ ἐν ποίοις τισὶ πράγμασιν ὄντες ἐτυγχάνετε , ἐξ ὧν ὑμᾶς ἐγὼ ἀνήγαγον πρὸς Σεύθην .
perseus-eng2	Recollect in what sort of troubles you then found yourselves, troubles out of which I delivered you when I brought you to Seuthes.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.6.24
glaux1.0-sentence	3597
perseus-grc2	οὐκ εἰς μὲν Πέρινθον προσῇτε πόλιν , Ἀρίσταρχος δ’ ὑμᾶς ὁ Λακεδαιμόνιος οὐκ εἴα εἰσιέναι ἀποκλείσας τὰς πύλας ;
perseus-eng2	Did you not go to Perinthus, and did not Aristarchus the Lacedaemonian forbid your entering and shut the gates against you?

cts:urn:0032-006:7.6.24
glaux1.0-sentence	3598
perseus-grc2	ὑπαίθριοι δ’ ἔξω ἐστρατοπεδεύετε , μέσος δὲ χειμὼν ἦν , ἀγορᾷ δὲ ἐχρῆσθε σπάνια μὲν ὁρῶντες τὰ ὤνια , σπάνια δ’ ἔχοντες ὅτων ὠνήσεσθε , ἀνάγκη δὲ ἦν μένειν ἐπὶ Θρᾴκης ·
perseus-eng2	So you encamped outside, under the sky, though it was midwinter, and you got your provisions by purchase at a market, though scanty were the supplies you saw offered for sale and scanty the means you had with which to buy; yet you were compelled to remain upon the Thracian coast,

cts:urn:0032-006:7.6.25
glaux1.0-sentence	3599
perseus-grc2	τριήρεις γὰρ ἐφορμοῦσαι ἐκώλυον διαπλεῖν ·
perseus-eng2	for over against you lay triremes that prevented your crossing to  Asia ;

cts:urn:0032-006:7.6.25
glaux1.0-sentence	3600
perseus-grc2	εἰ δὲ μένοι τις , ἐν πολεμίᾳ εἶναι , ἔνθα πολλοὶ μὲν ἱππεῖς ἦσαν ἐναντίοι , πολλοὶ δὲ πελτασταί , ἡμῖν δὲ ὁπλιτικὸν μὲν ἦν ᾧ ἁθρόοι μὲν ἰόντες ἐπὶ τὰς κώμας ἴσως ἂν ἐδυνάμεθα σῖτον λαμβάνειν οὐδέν τι ἄφθονον , ὅτῳ δὲ διώκοντες ἂν ἢ ἀνδράποδα ἢ πρόβατα κατελαμβάνομεν οὐκ ἦν ἡμῖν ·
perseus-eng2	and remaining there, you were of necessity in a hostile country, where there were many horsemen opposed to you and many peltasts; as for ourselves, we had a force of hoplites to be sure, with which, in case we went in a body against the villages, we might perhaps have been able to obtain food, though by no means an abundant supply, but any force with which we could have pursued and captured either slaves or cattle we had not;

cts:urn:0032-006:7.6.26
glaux1.0-sentence	3601
perseus-grc2	οὔτε γὰρ ἱππικὸν οὔτε πελταστικὸν ἔτι ἐγὼ συνεστηκὸς κατέλαβον παρ’ ὑμῖν .
perseus-eng2	for I had found no division either of cavalry or of peltasts in existence any longer among you.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.6.27
glaux1.0-sentence	3602
perseus-grc2	εἰ οὖν ἐν τοιαύτῃ ἀνάγκῃ ὄντων ὑμῶν μηδ’ ὁντιναοῦν μισθὸν προσαιτήσας Σεύθην σύμμαχον ὑμῖν προσέλαβον , ἔχοντα καὶ ἱππέας καὶ πελταστὰς ὧν ὑμεῖς προσεδεῖσθε , ἦ κακῶς ἂν ἐδόκουν ὑμῖν βεβουλεῦσθαι πρὸ ὑμῶν ;
perseus-eng2	Now when you were in such straits, if I had obtained for you, without demanding into the bargain any pay whatsoever, simply an alliance with Seuthes, who possessed both the cavalry and the peltasts that you were in need of, would you have thought that I had carried through a bad plan on your behalf?

cts:urn:0032-006:7.6.28
glaux1.0-sentence	3603
perseus-grc2	τούτων γὰρ δήπου κοινωνήσαντες καὶ σῖτον ἀφθονώτερον ἐν ταῖς κώμαις ηὑρίσκετε διὰ τὸ ἀναγκάζεσθαι τοὺς Θρᾷκας κατὰ σπουδὴν μᾶλλον φεύγειν , καὶ προβάτων καὶ ἀνδραπόδων μᾶλλον μετέσχετε .
perseus-eng2	For you remember, I imagine, that when you had joined forces with these troops, you not only found food in greater abundance in the villages, for the reason that the Thracians were compelled to flee in greater haste, but you also got a larger share of cattle and captives.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.6.29
glaux1.0-sentence	3604
perseus-grc2	καὶ πολέμιον οὐκέτι οὐδένα ἑωρῶμεν ἐπειδὴ τὸ ἱππικὸν ἡμῖν προσεγένετο ·
perseus-eng2	In fact, we never saw the face of an enemy again after the cavalry had joined us.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.6.29
glaux1.0-sentence	3605
perseus-grc2	τέως δὲ θαρραλέως ἡμῖν ἐφείποντο οἱ πολέμιοι καὶ ἱππικῷ καὶ πελταστικῷ κωλύοντες μηδαμῇ κατ’ ὀλίγους ἀποσκεδαννυμένους τὰ ἐπιτήδεια ἀφθονώτερα ἡμᾶς πορίζεσθαι .
perseus-eng2	Up to that time the enemy had been following boldly at our heels with horsemen and peltasts and had prevented us from scattering in any direction in small parties and thus securing a greater abundance of provisions.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.6.30
glaux1.0-sentence	3606
perseus-grc2	εἰ δὲ δὴ ὁ συμπαρέχων ὑμῖν ταύτην τὴν ἀσφάλειαν μὴ πάνυ πολὺν μισθὸν προσετέλει τῆς ἀσφαλείας , τοῦτο δὴ τὸ σχέτλιον πάθημα καὶ διὰ τοῦτο οὐδαμῇ οἴεσθε χρῆναι ζῶντα ἐμὲ ἀνεῖναι ;
perseus-eng2	And if, then, the man who aided in providing you this security did not give you, besides, very generous pay for your security, is that such a dreadful misfortune? and do you think that on that account you cannot possibly let me go alive?

cts:urn:0032-006:7.6.31
glaux1.0-sentence	3607
perseus-grc2	νῦν δὲ δὴ πῶς ἀπέρχεσθε ;
perseus-eng2	As matters stand now, what is your situation in departing from here?

cts:urn:0032-006:7.6.31
glaux1.0-sentence	3608
perseus-grc2	οὐ διαχειμάσαντες μὲν ἐν ἀφθόνοις τοῖς ἐπιτηδείοις , περιττὸν δ’ ἔχοντες τοῦτο εἴ τι ἐλάβετε παρὰ Σεύθου ;
perseus-eng2	Have you not passed the winter amid an abundance of provisions, and, whatever you have received from Seuthes, is it not really so much clear gain?

cts:urn:0032-006:7.6.31
glaux1.0-sentence	3609
perseus-grc2	τὰ γὰρ τῶν πολεμίων ἐδαπανᾶτε .
perseus-eng2	For it was the enemy’s possessions that you have been consuming.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.6.31
glaux1.0-sentence	3610

perseus-eng2	And while enjoying such fortune, you have not had to see any of your number slain nor have you lost any men alive.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.6.32

perseus-eng2	And if any glorious deed was earlier performed by you against the barbarians in  Asia , have you not at the same time kept that secure and likewise gained other glory besides in the present, by vanquishing, in addition, the Thracians in  Europe  against whom you took the field?

cts:urn:0032-006:7.6.32
glaux1.0-sentence	3612
perseus-grc2	ἐγὼ μὲν ὑμᾶς φημι δικαίως ἂν ὧν ἐμοὶ χαλεπαίνετε τούτων τοῖς θεοῖς χάριν εἰδέναι ὡς ἀγαθῶν .
perseus-eng2	For my part, I assert that for the very acts on account of which you now feel angry toward me, you should, in all justice, feel grateful to the gods, counting them as blessings.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.6.33

perseus-eng2	So much, then, for your situation.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.6.33

perseus-eng2	And now, in the name of the gods, come, and consider how the case stands with me.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.6.33
glaux1.0-sentence	3615

perseus-eng2	At the time when I first set out to return home, I possessed, as I departed, abundant praise in your eyes, and I also possessed, through you, fair fame in the eyes of the Greeks at large.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.6.34

perseus-eng2	Now, on the other hand, I am going away traduced by you before the Lacedaemonians and hated on your account by Seuthes, the man through whom I hoped to secure, by rendering him good service with your help, a fair place of refuge for myself and my children, in case children should ever be born to me.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.6.35
glaux1.0-sentence	3619
perseus-grc2	ὑμεῖς δ’ , ὑπὲρ ὧν ἐγὼ ἀπήχθημαί τε πλεῖστα καὶ ταῦτα πολὺ κρείττοσιν ἐμαυτοῦ , πραγματευόμενός τε οὐδὲ νῦν πω πέπαυμαι ὅ τι δύναμαι ἀγαθὸν ὑμῖν , τοιαύτην ἔχετε γνώμην περὶ ἐμοῦ .
perseus-eng2	And you, for whose sake I have incurred most hatred, and the hatred of men far stronger than I am, for whose sake I have not even to this moment ceased striving to accomplish whatever good I may, hold such an opinion of me as this!

cts:urn:0032-006:7.6.36
glaux1.0-sentence	3620

cts:urn:0032-006:7.6.36
glaux1.0-sentence	3621
perseus-grc2	ἢν δὲ ποιήσητε ἃ λέγετε , ἴστε ὅτι ἄνδρα κατακεκονότες ἔσεσθε πολλὰ μὲν δὴ πρὸ ὑμῶν ἀγρυπνήσαντα , πολλὰ δὲ σὺν ὑμῖν πονήσαντα καὶ κινδυνεύσαντα καὶ ἐν τῷ μέρει καὶ παρὰ τὸ μέρος , θεῶν δ’ ἵλεων ὄντων καὶ τρόπαια βαρβάρων πολλὰ δὴ σὺν ὑμῖν στησάμενον , ὅπως δέ γε μηδενὶ τῶν Ἑλλήνων πολέμιοι γένησθε , πᾶν ὅσον ἐγὼ ἐδυνάμην πρὸς ὑμᾶς διατεινάμενον .
perseus-eng2	and if you do what you are proposing, be sure that you will have slain a man who has passed many sleepless nights for your sake, who has endured many toils and dangers with you, both in his turn and out of his turn, who has also, by the graciousness of the gods, set up with you many trophies of victory over the barbarians, and who, in order to prevent your becoming enemies to any one among the Greeks, has exerted himself to the very utmost of his power in opposition to you.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.6.37
glaux1.0-sentence	3622
perseus-grc2	καὶ γὰρ οὖν νῦν ὑμῖν ἔξεστιν ἀνεπιλήπτως πορεύεσθαι ὅπῃ ἂν ἕλησθε καὶ κατὰ γῆν καὶ κατὰ θάλατταν .
perseus-eng2	In fact, you are now free to journey in security whithersoever you may choose, whether by land or by sea.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.6.37
glaux1.0-sentence	3623

perseus-eng2	And you, at the moment when such abundant freedom reveals itself to you, when you are sailing to the very place where you have long been eager to go and the mightiest are suing for your aid, when pay is within sight and the Lacedaemonians, who are deemed the most powerful leaders, have come to lead you—do you, I say, think that now is the proper time to put me to death with all speed?

cts:urn:0032-006:7.6.38

perseus-eng2	It was not so, surely, in the days when we were in straits, O you who remember better than all other men; nay, then you called me "father," and you promised to keep me for ever in memory as a benefactor!

perseus-eng2	Yes, and I believe, men of  Lacedaemon , that you ought to assume leadership over us in this enterprise first of all, in exacting our pay from Seuthes whether he will or no, and that you should not take us away till that is done.

perseus-eng2	Look you, fellow soldiers, I see Heracleides also present here, the man who took in charge the property which we had won by our toil, and then sold it, and did not pay over the proceeds either to Seuthes or to us, but stole the money, and is keeping it for himself.

perseus-eng2	He likewise said, making a great secret of it, that he had heard from Polynicus that if Xenophon should fall into the hands of the Lacedaemonians, he would certainly be put to death by Thibron.

perseus-eng2	And he, hearing these reports, took two victims and proceeded to offer sacrifice to Zeus the King, to learn whether it was better and more profitable for him to remain with Seuthes on the conditions that Seuthes proposed, or to depart with the army.

perseus-eng2	Then Medosades said:

cts:urn:0032-006:7.7.3
glaux1.0-sentence	3655
perseus-grc2	ἀδικεῖτε , ὦ Ξενοφῶν , τὰς ἡμετέρας κώμας πορθοῦντες .
perseus-eng2	You Greeks are committing a wrong, Xenophon, in plundering our villages.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.7.3
glaux1.0-sentence	3656
perseus-grc2	προλέγομεν οὖν ὑμῖν , ἐγώ τε ὑπὲρ Σεύθου καὶ ὅδε ἁνὴρ παρὰ Μηδόκου ἥκων τοῦ ἄνω βασιλέως , ἀπιέναι ἐκ τῆς χώρας ·
perseus-eng2	Therefore we give you public warning, I on behalf of Seuthes, and this man who has come from Medocus, who is king in the interior, to depart from the country;

cts:urn:0032-006:7.7.3
glaux1.0-sentence	3657
perseus-grc2	εἰ δὲ μή , οὐκ ἐπιτρέψομεν ὑμῖν , ἀλλ’ ἐὰν ποιῆτε κακῶς τὴν ἡμετέραν χώραν , ὡς πολεμίους ἀλεξόμεθα .
perseus-eng2	and if you fail to depart, we shall not leave you a free hand, but in case you continue to do harm to our territory, we shall defend ourselves against you as against enemies.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.7.4
glaux1.0-sentence	3658
perseus-grc2	ὁ δὲ Ξενοφῶν ἀκούσας ταῦτα εἶπεν ·
perseus-eng2	Upon hearing these words Xenophon said:

cts:urn:0032-006:7.7.4
glaux1.0-sentence	3659
perseus-grc2	ἀλλὰ σοὶ μὲν τοιαῦτα λέγοντι καὶ ἀποκρίνασθαι χαλεπόν ·
perseus-eng2	As for you, when you say such things as these it is painful even to give you an answer;

cts:urn:0032-006:7.7.4
glaux1.0-sentence	3660
perseus-grc2	τούτου δ’ ἕνεκα τοῦ νεανίσκου λέξω , ἵν’ εἰδῇ οἷοί τε ὑμεῖς ἐστε καὶ οἷοι ἡμεῖς .
perseus-eng2	yet for the sake of this young man I will speak, that he may know what sort of people you are and what we are.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.7.5
glaux1.0-sentence	3661
perseus-grc2	ἡμεῖς μὲν γάρ , ἔφη , πρὶν ὑμῖν φίλοι γενέσθαι ἐπορευόμεθα διὰ ταύτης τῆς χώρας ὅποι ἐβουλόμεθα , ἣν μὲν ἐθέλοιμεν πορθοῦντες , ἣν δὲ θέλοιμεν καίοντες , καὶ σὺ ὁπότε πρὸς ἡμᾶς ἔλθοις πρεσβεύων , ηὐλίζου τότε παρ’ ἡμῖν οὐδένα φοβούμενος τῶν πολεμίων ·
perseus-eng2	For we," he went on, "before we became friends of yours, marched whithersoever we chose through this country, plundering where we wished and burning where we wished; and whenever you came to us as envoy, you used then to bivouac with us without fear of any enemy;

cts:urn:0032-006:7.7.6
glaux1.0-sentence	3662
perseus-grc2	ὑμεῖς δὲ οὐκ ᾖτε εἰς τήνδε τὴν χώραν , ἢ εἴ ποτε ἔλθοιτε , ὡς ἐν κρειττόνων χώρᾳ ηὐλίζεσθε ἐγκεχαλινωμένοις τοῖς ἵπποις .
perseus-eng2	your people, on the other hand, never came into this country, or if at any time you did come, you would bivouac as in the land of men stronger than yourselves, keeping your horses all bridled.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.7.7
glaux1.0-sentence	3663
perseus-grc2	ἐπεὶ δὲ ἡμῖν φίλοι ἐγένεσθε καὶ δι’ ἡμᾶς σὺν θεοῖς ἔχετε τήνδε τὴν χώραν , νῦν δὴ ἐξελαύνετε ἡμᾶς ἐκ τῆσδε τῆς χώρας ἣν παρ’ ἡμῶν , ἐχόντων κατὰ κράτος , παρελάβετε ·
perseus-eng2	But after you had once become friends of ours and now through us, with the aid of the gods, enjoy possession of this land, you seek to drive us forth, out of this very land that you received from us, who held it by right of strength;

cts:urn:0032-006:7.7.7
glaux1.0-sentence	3664
perseus-grc2	ὡς γὰρ αὐτὸς οἶσθα , οἱ πολέμιοι οὐχ ἱκανοὶ ἦσαν ἡμᾶς ἐξελαύνειν .
perseus-eng2	for as you know yourself, the enemy were not able to drive us out.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.7.8
glaux1.0-sentence	3665
perseus-grc2	καὶ οὐχ ὅπως δῶρα δοὺς καὶ εὖ ποιήσας ἀνθ’ ὧν εὖ ἔπαθες ἀξιοῖς ἡμᾶς ἀποπέμψασθαι , ἀλλ’ ἀποπορευομένους ἡμᾶς οὐδ’ ἐναυλισθῆναι ὅσον δύνασαι ἐπιτρέπεις .
perseus-eng2	And yet, so far from deeming it proper to speed us on our way after bestowing gifts upon us and doing us kindnesses in return for the benefits you have received at our hands, you will not, so far as you have the power to prevent it, allow us at the moment of our departure even to bivouac in the country.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.7.9
glaux1.0-sentence	3666
perseus-grc2	καὶ ταῦτα λέγων οὔτε θεοὺς αἰσχύνῃ οὔτε τόνδε τὸν ἄνδρα , ὃς νῦν μέν σε ὁρᾷ πλουτοῦντα , πρὶν δὲ ἡμῖν φίλον γενέσθαι ἀπὸ λῃστείας τὸν βίον ἔχοντα , ὡς αὐτὸς ἔφησθα .
perseus-eng2	And in uttering these words you are not ashamed either before the gods or before this Odrysian, who now sees you possessed of riches, whereas before you became our friend you got your living, as you said yourself, from pillaging.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.7.10
glaux1.0-sentence	3667
perseus-grc2	ἀτὰρ τί καὶ πρὸς ἐμὲ λέγεις ταῦτα ;
perseus-eng2	But really, why do you," he added, "address these words to me?

cts:urn:0032-006:7.7.10
glaux1.0-sentence	3668
perseus-grc2	ἔφη ·
perseus-eng2	For I am no longer in command, but rather the Lacedaemonians;

cts:urn:0032-006:7.7.10
glaux1.0-sentence	3669
perseus-grc2	οὐ γὰρ ἔγωγ’ ἔτι ἄρχω , ἀλλὰ Λακεδαιμόνιοι , οἷς ὑμεῖς παρεδώκατε τὸ στράτευμα ἀπαγαγεῖν οὐδὲν ἐμὲ παρακαλέσαντες , ὦ θαυμαστότατοι , ὅπως ὥσπερ ἀπηχθανόμην αὐτοῖς ὅτε πρὸς ὑμᾶς ἦγον , οὕτω καὶ χαρισαίμην νῦν ἀποδιδούς .
perseus-eng2	and it was to them that you yourselves delivered over the army to be led away, and that, you most ill-mannered of men, without so much as inviting me to be present, so that even as I had incurred their hatred at the time when I led the army to you, so I might now win their favour by giving it back.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.7.11
glaux1.0-sentence	3670
perseus-grc2	ἐπεὶ ταῦτα ἤκουσεν ὁ Ὀδρύσης , εἶπεν ·
perseus-eng2	When the Odrysian heard this, he said:

cts:urn:0032-006:7.7.11
glaux1.0-sentence	3671
perseus-grc2	ἐγὼ μέν , ὦ Μηδόσαδες , κατὰ τῆς γῆς καταδύομαι ὑπὸ τῆς αἰσχύνης ἀκούων ταῦτα .
perseus-eng2	As for me, Medosades, I sink beneath the earth for shame at this which I hear.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.7.11
glaux1.0-sentence	3672
perseus-grc2	καὶ εἰ μὲν πρόσθεν ἠπιστάμην , οὐδ’ ἂν συνηκολούθησά σοι ·
perseus-eng2	If I had understood the matter before, I should not even have accompanied you;

cts:urn:0032-006:7.7.11
glaux1.0-sentence	3673
perseus-grc2	καὶ νῦν ἄπειμι .
perseus-eng2	and now I am going back.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.7.11
glaux1.0-sentence	3674
perseus-grc2	οὐδὲ γὰρ ἂν Μήδοκός με ὁ βασιλεὺς ἐπαινοίη , εἰ ἐξελαύνοιμι τοὺς εὐεργέτας .
perseus-eng2	For Medocus, the king, would never commend me if I should drive forth his benefactors.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.7.12
glaux1.0-sentence	3675
perseus-grc2	ταῦτ’ εἰπὼν ἀναβὰς ἐπὶ τὸν ἵππον ἀπήλαυνε καὶ σὺν αὐτῷ οἱ ἄλλοι ἱππεῖς πλὴν τεττάρων ἢ πέντε .
perseus-eng2	With these words he mounted his horse and rode away, and with him went the horsemen also, except four or five.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.7.12
glaux1.0-sentence	3676
perseus-grc2	ὁ δὲ Μηδοσάδης ( ἐλύπει γὰρ αὐτὸν ἡ χώρα πορθουμένη ) , ἐκέλευε τὸν Ξενοφῶντα καλέσαι τὼ Λακεδαιμονίω .
perseus-eng2	But Medosades, still distressed by the plundering of the country, urged Xenophon to summon the two Lacedaemonians.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.7.13
glaux1.0-sentence	3677
perseus-grc2	καὶ ὃς λαβὼν τοὺς ἐπιτηδειοτάτους προσῆλθε τῷ Χαρμίνῳ καὶ Πολυνίκῳ καὶ ἔλεγεν ὅτι καλεῖ αὐτοὺς Μηδοσάδης προερῶν ἅπερ αὐτῷ , ἀπιέναι ἐκ τῆς χώρας .
perseus-eng2	And Xenophon, taking with him the best men he had, went to Charminus and Polynicus and said that Medosades was summoning them in order to give them the same warning as he had already given him,—to depart from the country.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.7.14
glaux1.0-sentence	3678
perseus-grc2	οἴομαι ἂν οὖν , ἔφη , ὑμᾶς ἀπολαβεῖν τῇ στρατιᾷ τὸν ὀφειλόμενον μισθόν , εἰ εἴποιτε ὅτι δεδέηται ὑμῶν ἡ στρατιὰ συναναπρᾶξαι τὸν μισθὸν ἢ παρ’ ἑκόντος Σεύθου ἢ παρ’ ἄκοντος Σεύθου , καὶ ὅτι τούτων τυχόντες προθύμως ἂν συνέπεσθαι ὑμῖν φασι ·
perseus-eng2	I should think, therefore," he continued, "that you might recover for the army the pay that is due if you should say that the army has requested you to aid them in exacting their pay from Seuthes whether he will or no, and that the troops say that they would follow you eagerly in case they should obtain it;

cts:urn:0032-006:7.7.14
glaux1.0-sentence	3679
perseus-grc2	καὶ ὅτι δίκαια ὑμῖν δοκοῦσι λέγειν ·
perseus-eng2	also, that their words seem to you just.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.7.14
glaux1.0-sentence	3680
perseus-grc2	καὶ ὅτι ὑπέσχεσθε αὐτοῖς τότε ἀπιέναι ὅταν τὰ δίκαια ἔχωσιν οἱ στρατιῶται .
perseus-eng2	and that you promised them not to depart until the soldiers should obtain their rights.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.7.15
glaux1.0-sentence	3681
perseus-grc2	ἀκούσαντες οἱ Λάκωνες ταῦτα ἔφασαν ἐρεῖν καὶ ἄλλα ὁποῖα ἂν δύνωνται κράτιστα ·
perseus-eng2	When they had heard him, the Laconians replied that they would make such statements, adding others as forceful as they could make them;

cts:urn:0032-006:7.7.15
glaux1.0-sentence	3682
perseus-grc2	καὶ εὐθὺς ἐπορεύοντο ἔχοντες πάντας τοὺς ἐπικαιρίους .

cts:urn:0032-006:7.7.15

perseus-eng2	If you have anything to say to us, Medosades, say it; if not, we have something to say to you.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.7.16

perseus-eng2	I say, and Seuthes also says the same, that we ask that those who have become friends of ours should not suffer harm at your hands;

cts:urn:0032-006:7.7.16

perseus-eng2	for whatever harm you may do to them, you are then and there doing to us;

cts:urn:0032-006:7.7.16

perseus-eng2	for they are ours.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.7.17

perseus-eng2	As for ourselves, then," said the Laconians, "we shall depart whenever the men who obtained these possessions for you, have received their pay;

cts:urn:0032-006:7.7.17
glaux1.0-sentence	3690
perseus-grc2	εἰ δὲ μή , ἐρχόμεθα μὲν καὶ νῦν βοηθήσοντες τούτοις καὶ τιμωρησόμενοι ἄνδρας οἳ τούτους παρὰ τοὺς ὅρκους ἠδίκησαν .
perseus-eng2	failing that, we intend here and now to lend them our assistance and to punish the men who, in violation of their oaths, have done them wrong.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.7.17
glaux1.0-sentence	3691
perseus-grc2	ἢν δὲ δὴ καὶ ὑμεῖς τοιοῦτοι ἦτε , ἐνθένδε ἀρξόμεθα τὰ δίκαια λαμβάνειν .
perseus-eng2	And if you belong to that number, it is with you that we shall begin in obtaining their rights.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.7.18
glaux1.0-sentence	3692
perseus-grc2	ὁ δὲ Ξενοφῶν εἶπεν ·
perseus-eng2	Then Xenophon said:

cts:urn:0032-006:7.7.18

perseus-grc2	ἐθέλοιτε ἂν τούτοις , ὦ Μηδόσαδες , ἐπιτρέψαι , ἐπειδὴ φίλους ἔφατε εἶναι ὑμῖν , ἐν ὧν τῇ χώρᾳ ἐσμέν , ὁπότερ’ ἂν ψηφίσωνται , εἴθ’ ὑμᾶς προσῆκεν ἐκ τῆς χώρας ἀπιέναι εἴθ’ ἡμᾶς ;
perseus-eng2	Would you be willing, Medosades, to leave the question to these people (for you were saying that they are your friends) in whose country we are, to vote, one way or the other, whether it is proper for you or ourselves to depart from their country?

cts:urn:0032-006:7.7.19
glaux1.0-sentence	3694
