perseus-eng2	Medosades said no to that;

cts:urn:0032-006:7.7.19
glaux1.0-sentence	3695
perseus-grc2	ἐκέλευε δὲ μάλιστα μὲν αὐτὼ τὼ Λάκωνε ἐλθεῖν παρὰ Σεύθην περὶ τοῦ μισθοῦ , καὶ οἴεσθαι ἂν Σεύθην πεῖσαι ·
perseus-eng2	but he urged, as his preference, that the two Laconians should go to Seuthes themselves about the pay, and said that he thought they might persuade Seuthes;

cts:urn:0032-006:7.7.19
glaux1.0-sentence	3696
perseus-grc2	εἰ δὲ μή , Ξενοφῶντα σὺν αὐτῷ πέμπειν , καὶ συμπράξειν ὑπισχνεῖτο .
perseus-eng2	or if they would not consent to go, he asked them to send Xenophon along with himself, and promised to support him.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.7.19
glaux1.0-sentence	3697
perseus-grc2	ἐδεῖτο δὲ τὰς κώμας μὴ καίειν .
perseus-eng2	And he begged them not to burn the villages.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.7.20
glaux1.0-sentence	3698
perseus-grc2	ἐντεῦθεν πέμπουσι Ξενοφῶντα καὶ σὺν αὐτῷ οἳ ἐδόκουν ἐπιτηδειότατοι εἶναι .
perseus-eng2	Thereupon they sent Xenophon, and with him the men who seemed to be fittest.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.7.20
glaux1.0-sentence	3699
perseus-grc2	ὁ δὲ ἐλθὼν λέγει πρὸς Σεύθην ·
perseus-eng2	When he had come, he said to Seuthes:

cts:urn:0032-006:7.7.20
glaux1.0-sentence	3700
perseus-grc2	οὐδὲν ἀπαιτήσων , ὦ Σεύθη , πάρειμι , ἀλλὰ διδάξων , ἢν δύνωμαι , ὡς οὐ δικαίως μοι ἠχθέσθης ὅτι ὑπὲρ τῶν στρατιωτῶν ἀπῄτουν σε προθύμως ἃ ὑπέσχου αὐτοῖς ·
perseus-eng2	I am here, Seuthes, not to present any demand, but to show you, if I can, that you were wrong in getting angry with me because in the name of the soldiers I zealously demanded from you what you had promised them;

cts:urn:0032-006:7.7.21
glaux1.0-sentence	3701
perseus-grc2	σοὶ γὰρ ἔγωγε οὐχ ἧττον ἐνόμιζον σύμφορον εἶναι ἀποδοῦναι ἢ ἐκείνοις ἀπολαβεῖν .
perseus-eng2	for I believed that it was no less to your advantage to pay them than it was to theirs to get their pay.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.7.22
glaux1.0-sentence	3702
perseus-grc2	πρῶτον μὲν γὰρ οἶδα μετὰ τοὺς θεοὺς εἰς τὸ φανερόν σε τούτους καταστήσαντας , ἐπεί γε βασιλέα σε ἐποίησαν πολλῆς χώρας καὶ πολλῶν ἀνθρώπων ·
perseus-eng2	For, in the first place, I know that next to the gods it was these men who set you in a conspicuous position, since they made you king over a large territory and many people;

cts:urn:0032-006:7.7.22
glaux1.0-sentence	3703
perseus-grc2	ὥστε οὐχ οἷόν τέ σοι λανθάνειν οὔτε ἤν τι καλὸν οὔτε ἤν τι αἰσχρὸν ποιήσῃς .
perseus-eng2	hence it is not possible for you to escape notice, whether you perform an honourable deed or a base one.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.7.23
glaux1.0-sentence	3704
perseus-grc2	τοιούτῳ δὲ ὄντι ἀνδρὶ μέγα μέν μοι ἐδόκει εἶναι μὴ δοκεῖν ἀχαρίστως ἀποπέμψασθαι ἄνδρας εὐεργέτας , μέγα δὲ εὖ ἀκούειν ὑπὸ ἑξακισχιλίων ἀνθρώπων , τὸ δὲ μέγιστον μηδαμῶς ἄπιστον σαυτὸν καταστῆσαι ὅ τι λέγοις .
perseus-eng2	Now it seemed to me an important thing that a man in such a place should not be thought to have dismissed benefactors without gratitude, an important thing also to be well spoken of by six thousand men, but most important of all that you should by no means set yourself down as untrustworthy in whatever you say.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.7.24
glaux1.0-sentence	3705
perseus-grc2	ὁρῶ γὰρ τῶν μὲν ἀπίστων ματαίους καὶ ἀδυνάτους καὶ ἀτίμους τοὺς λόγους πλανωμένους ·
perseus-eng2	For I see that the words of untrustworthy men wander here and there without result, without power, and without honour;

cts:urn:0032-006:7.7.24
glaux1.0-sentence	3706
perseus-grc2	οἳ δ’ ἂν φανεροὶ ὦσιν ἀλήθειαν ἀσκοῦντες , τούτων οἱ λόγοι , ἤν τι δέωνται , οὐδὲν μεῖον δύνανται ἁνύσασθαι ἢ ἄλλων ἡ βία ·
perseus-eng2	but if men are seen to practise truth, their words, if they desire anything, have power to accomplish no less than force in the hands of other men;

cts:urn:0032-006:7.7.24
glaux1.0-sentence	3707
perseus-grc2	ἤν τέ τινας σωφρονίζειν βούλωνται , γιγνώσκω τὰς τούτων ἀπειλὰς οὐχ ἧττον σωφρονιζούσας ἢ ἄλλων τὸ ἤδη κολάζειν ·
perseus-eng2	and if they wish to bring one to reason, I perceive that their threats can do this no less than present chastisement applied by others;

cts:urn:0032-006:7.7.24
glaux1.0-sentence	3708
perseus-grc2	ἤν τέ τῴ τι ὑπισχνῶνται οἱ τοιοῦτοι ἄνδρες , οὐδὲν μεῖον διαπράττονται ἢ ἄλλοι παραχρῆμα διδόντες ·
perseus-eng2	and if such men make a promise to any one, they accomplish no less than others do by an immediate gift.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.7.25
glaux1.0-sentence	3709
perseus-grc2	ἀναμνήσθητι δὲ καὶ σὺ τί προτελέσας ἡμῖν συμμάχους ἡμᾶς ἔλαβες .
perseus-eng2	Recall for yourself what amount you paid to us in advance in order to obtain us as allies.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.7.25
glaux1.0-sentence	3710
perseus-grc2	οἶσθ’ ὅτι οὐδέν ·
perseus-eng2	You know that it was nothing;

cts:urn:0032-006:7.7.25
glaux1.0-sentence	3711
perseus-grc2	ἀλλὰ πιστευθεὶς ἀληθεύσειν ἃ ἔλεγες ἐπῆρας τοσούτους ἀνθρώπους συστρατεύεσθαί τε καὶ κατεργάσασθαί σοι ἀρχὴν οὐ τριάκοντα μόνον ἀξίαν ταλάντων , ὅσα οἴονται δεῖν οὗτοι νῦν ἀπολαβεῖν , ἀλλὰ πολλαπλασίων .
perseus-eng2	but because you were trusted to carry out truthfully whatever you said, you induced that great body of men to take the field with you and to gain for you a realm worth not merely thirty talents, the sum which these men think they ought now to recover, but many times as much.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.7.26
glaux1.0-sentence	3712
perseus-grc2	οὐκοῦν τοῦτο μὲν πρῶτον τὸ πιστεύεσθαι , τὸ καὶ τὴν βασιλείαν σοι κατεργασάμενον , τούτων τῶν χρημάτων πιπράσκεται .
perseus-eng2	First of all, then, this trust, the very thing which gained your kingdom for you, is being sold for this sum.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.7.27
glaux1.0-sentence	3713
perseus-grc2	ἴθι δὴ ἀναμνήσθητι πῶς μέγα ἡγοῦ τότε καταπρᾶξαι ἃ νῦν καταστρεψάμενος ἔχεις .
perseus-eng2	Come, now, recall how great a thing you then deemed it to achieve the conquests which you now have achieved.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.7.27
glaux1.0-sentence	3714
perseus-grc2	ἐγὼ μὲν εὖ οἶδ’ ὅτι ηὔξω ἂν τὰ νῦν πεπραγμένα μᾶλλόν σοι καταπραχθῆναι ἢ πολλαπλάσια τούτων τῶν χρημάτων γενέσθαι .
perseus-eng2	For my part, I am sure you would have prayed that the deeds now done might be accomplished for you rather than that many times that amount of money might fall to your lot.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.7.28
glaux1.0-sentence	3715
perseus-grc2	ἐμοὶ τοίνυν μεῖζον βλάβος καὶ αἴσχιον δοκεῖ εἶναι τὸ ταῦτα νῦν μὴ κατασχεῖν ἢ τότε μὴ λαβεῖν , ὅσῳπερ χαλεπώτερον ἐκ πλουσίου πένητα γενέσθαι ἢ ἀρχὴν μὴ πλουτῆσαι , καὶ ὅσῳ λυπηρότερον ἐκ βασιλέως ἰδιώτην φανῆναι ἢ ἀρχὴν μὴ βασιλεῦσαι .
perseus-eng2	Now I count it greater hurt and shame not to hold these possessions firmly now than not to have gained them then, by so much as it is a harder fate to become poor after being rich than not to become rich at all, and by so much as it is more painful to be found a subject after being a king than not to become king at all.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.7.29
glaux1.0-sentence	3716
perseus-grc2	οὐκοῦν ἐπίστασαι μὲν ὅτι οἱ νῦν σοι ὑπήκοοι γενόμενοι οὐ φιλίᾳ τῇ σῇ ἐπείσθησαν ὑπὸ σοῦ ἄρχεσθαι ἀλλ’ ἀνάγκῃ , καὶ ὅτι ἐπιχειροῖεν ἂν πάλιν ἐλεύθεροι γίγνεσθαι , εἰ μή τις αὐτοὺς φόβος κατέχοι .
perseus-eng2	You understand, then, that those who have now become your subjects were not persuaded to live under your rule out of affection for you, but by stress of necessity, and that unless some fear should restrain them, they would endeavour to become free again.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.7.30
glaux1.0-sentence	3717
perseus-grc2	ποτέρως οὖν οἴει μᾶλλον ἂν φοβεῖσθαί τε αὐτοὺς καὶ σωφρονεῖν τὰ πρὸς σέ , εἰ ὁρῷέν σοι τοὺς στρατιώτας οὕτω διακειμένους ὡς νῦν τε μένοντας ἄν , εἰ σὺ κελεύοις , αὖθίς τ’ ἂν ταχὺ ἐλθόντας , εἰ δέοι , ἄλλους τε τούτων περὶ σοῦ ἀκούοντας πολλὰ ἀγαθὰ ταχὺ ἄν σοι ὁπότε βούλοιο παραγενέσθαι , ἢ εἰ καταδοξάσειαν μήτ’ ἂν ἄλλους σοι ἐλθεῖν δι’ ἀπιστίαν ἐκ τῶν νῦν γεγενημένων τούτους τε αὐτοῖς εὐνουστέρους εἶναι ἢ σοί ;
perseus-eng2	In which of these two cases, therefore do you think they would feel greater fear and be more moderate in their relations with you: if they should see the soldiers cherishing such feelings toward you that they would stay with you now if you so bade them and would quickly come back to you again if you needed them, and should see also that others, hearing many good things about you from these troops, would quickly present themselves to take service with you whenever you wished it—or if they should form the unkind opinion that no other soldiers would come to you, in consequence of a distrust resulting from what has now happened, and that these whom you have are more friendly to them than to you?

cts:urn:0032-006:7.7.31
glaux1.0-sentence	3718
perseus-grc2	ἀλλὰ μὴν οὐδὲ πλήθει γε ἡμῶν λειφθέντες ὑπεῖξάν σοι , ἀλλὰ προστατῶν ἀπορίᾳ .
perseus-eng2	Again, it was by no means because they fell short of us in numbers that they yielded to you, but because they lacked leaders.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.7.31
glaux1.0-sentence	3719
perseus-grc2	οὐκοῦν νῦν καὶ τοῦτο κίνδυνος μὴ λάβωσι προστάτας αὑτῶν τινας τούτων οἳ νομίζουσιν ὑπὸ σοῦ ἀδικεῖσθαι , ἢ καὶ τούτων κρείττονας τοὺς Λακεδαιμονίους , ἐὰν μὲν οἱ στρατιῶται ὑπισχνῶνται προθυμότερον αὐτοῖς συστρατεύσεσθαι , ἂν τὰ παρὰ σοῦ νῦν ἀναπράξωσιν , οἱ δὲ Λακεδαιμόνιοι διὰ τὸ δεῖσθαι τῆς στρατιᾶς συναινέσωσιν αὐτοῖς ταῦτα .
perseus-eng2	Hence there is now danger on this count also, the danger that they may find leaders in some of these soldiers who regard themselves as wronged by you, or else in men who are even stronger than these are,—I mean the Lacedaemonians,—in case the soldiers promise to render them more zealous service if they now exact what is due from you, and in case the Lacedaemonians, on account of their needing the army, grant them this request.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.7.32
glaux1.0-sentence	3720
perseus-grc2	ὅτι γε μὴν οἱ νῦν ὑπὸ σοὶ Θρᾷκες γενόμενοι πολὺ ἂν προθυμότερον ἴοιεν ἐπί σε ἢ σύν σοι οὐκ ἄδηλον ·
perseus-eng2	Again, that the Thracians who have now fallen under your sway would far more eagerly go against you than with you, is quite certain;

cts:urn:0032-006:7.7.32
glaux1.0-sentence	3721
perseus-grc2	σοῦ μὲν γὰρ κρατοῦντος δουλεία ὑπάρχει αὐτοῖς , κρατουμένου δέ σου ἐλευθερία .
perseus-eng2	for when you are conqueror their lot is slavery, and when you are conquered it is freedom.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.7.33
glaux1.0-sentence	3722
perseus-grc2	εἰ δὲ καὶ τῆς χώρας προνοεῖσθαι ἤδη τι δεῖ ὡς σῆς οὔσης , ποτέρως ἂν οἴει ἀπαθῆ κακῶν μᾶλλον αὐτὴν εἶναι , εἰ οὗτοι οἱ στρατιῶται ἀπολαβόντες ἃ ἐγκαλοῦσιν εἰρήνην καταλιπόντες οἴχοιντο , ἢ εἰ οὗτοί τε μένοιεν ὡς ἐν πολεμίᾳ σύ τε ἄλλους πειρῷο πλέονας τούτων ἔχων ἀντιστρατοπεδεύεσθαι δεομένους τῶν ἐπιτηδείων ;
perseus-eng2	And if you need henceforth to take some thought for the sake of this land also, seeing that it is yours, in which case do you suppose it would be freer from ills: if these soldiers should recover what they claim and go away leaving a state of peace behind them, or if they should remain as in a hostile country and you should undertake to maintain an opposing camp with other troops, that would have to be more numerous than these and would need provisions?

cts:urn:0032-006:7.7.34
glaux1.0-sentence	3723
perseus-grc2	ἀργύριον δὲ ποτέρως ἂν πλέον ἀναλωθείη , εἰ τούτοις τὸ ὀφειλόμενον ἀποδοθείη , ἢ εἰ ταῦτά τε ὀφείλοιντο ἄλλους τε κρείττονας δέοι σε μισθοῦσθαι ;
perseus-eng2	And in which case would more money be spent, if what is owing to these men should be paid over to them, or if this sum should be left owing and you should have to hire other troops stronger than they are?

cts:urn:0032-006:7.7.35
glaux1.0-sentence	3724
perseus-grc2	ἀλλὰ γὰρ Ἡρακλείδῃ , ὡς πρὸς ἐμὲ ἐδήλου , πάμπολυ δοκεῖ τοῦτο τὸ ἀργύριον εἶναι .
perseus-eng2	Yes, but Heracleides thinks, as he used to explain to me, that this sum of money is a very large one.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.7.35
glaux1.0-sentence	3725
perseus-grc2	ἦ μὴν πολύ γέ ἐστιν ἔλαττον νῦν σοι καὶ λαβεῖν τοῦτο καὶ ἀποδοῦναι ἢ πρὶν ἡμᾶς ἐλθεῖν πρὸς σὲ δέκατον τούτου μέρος .
perseus-eng2	Upon my word it is a far smaller thing now for you to receive or to pay this sum than it would have been before we came to you to receive or to pay a tenth part of it.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.7.36
glaux1.0-sentence	3726
perseus-grc2	οὐ γὰρ ἀριθμός ἐστιν ὁ ὁρίζων τὸ πολὺ καὶ τὸ ὀλίγον , ἀλλ’ ἡ δύναμις τοῦ τε ἀποδιδόντος καὶ λαμβάνοντος .
perseus-eng2	For it is not number that determines what is much and what is little, but the capacity of the man who pays and of him who receives.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.7.36
glaux1.0-sentence	3727
perseus-grc2	σοὶ δὲ νῦν ἡ κατ’ ἐνιαυτὸν πρόσοδος πλείων ἔσται ἢ ἔμπροσθεν τὰ παρόντα πάντα ἃ ἐκέκτησο .
perseus-eng2	And as for yourself, your yearly income is going to be greater now than all the property you possessed amounted to before.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.7.37
glaux1.0-sentence	3728
perseus-grc2	ἐγὼ μέν , ὦ Σεύθη , ταῦτα ὡς φίλου ὄντος σου προυνοούμην , ὅπως σύ τε ἄξιος δοκοίης εἶναι ὧν οἱ θεοί σοι ἔδωκαν ἀγαθῶν ἐγώ τε μὴ διαφθαρείην ἐν τῇ στρατιᾷ .
perseus-eng2	For my part, Seuthes, it was out of regard for you as a friend that I urged this course, in order that you might be deemed worthy of the good things which the gods have given to you and that I might not lose credit with the army.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.7.38
glaux1.0-sentence	3729
perseus-grc2	εὖ γὰρ ἴσθι ὅτι νῦν ἐγὼ οὔτ’ ἂν ἐχθρὸν βουλόμενος κακῶς ποιῆσαι δυνηθείην σὺν ταύτῃ τῇ στρατιᾷ οὔτ’ ἂν εἴ σοι πάλιν βουλοίμην βοηθῆσαι , ἱκανὸς ἂν γενοίμην .
perseus-eng2	For be well assured that at present if I should wish to inflict harm upon a foe, I could not do it with this army, and if I should wish to come to your assistance again, I should not find myself able to do that;

cts:urn:0032-006:7.7.38
glaux1.0-sentence	3730
perseus-grc2	οὕτω γὰρ πρός με ἡ στρατιὰ διάκειται .
perseus-eng2	such is the feeling of the army toward me.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.7.39
glaux1.0-sentence	3731
perseus-grc2	καίτοι αὐτόν σε μάρτυρα σὺν θεοῖς εἰδόσι ποιοῦμαι ὅτι οὔτε ἔχω παρὰ σοῦ ἐπὶ τοῖς στρατιώταις οὐδὲν οὔτε ᾔτησα πώποτε εἰς τὸ ἴδιον τὰ ἐκείνων οὔτε ἃ ὑπέσχου μοι ἀπῄτησα ·
perseus-eng2	And yet I make your own self my witness, along with the gods, who know, that I have neither received anything from you that was intended for the soldiers, nor have ever asked what was theirs for my private use, nor demanded from you what you had promised me;

cts:urn:0032-006:7.7.40
glaux1.0-sentence	3732
perseus-grc2	ὄμνυμι δέ σοι μηδὲ ἀποδιδόντος δέξασθαι ἄν , εἰ μὴ καὶ οἱ στρατιῶται ἔμελλον τὰ ἑαυτῶν συναπολαμβάνειν .
perseus-eng2	and I swear to you that even if you had offered to pay what was due to me, I should not have accepted it unless the soldiers also were at the same time to recover what was due to them.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.7.40
glaux1.0-sentence	3733
perseus-grc2	αἰσχρὸν γὰρ ἦν τὰ μὲν ἐμὰ διαπεπρᾶχθαι , τὰ δ’ ἐκείνων περιιδεῖν κακῶς ἔχοντα ἄλλως τε καὶ τιμώμενον ὑπ’ ἐκείνων .
perseus-eng2	For it would have been disgraceful to get my own affairs arranged and leave theirs in an evil state, especially since I was honoured by them.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.7.41
glaux1.0-sentence	3734
perseus-grc2	καίτοι Ἡρακλείδῃ γε λῆρος πάντα δοκεῖ εἶναι πρὸς τὸ ἀργύριον ἔχειν ἐκ παντὸς τρόπου ·
perseus-eng2	And yet Heracleides thinks that everything is but nonsense in comparison with possessing money, by hook or by crook;

cts:urn:0032-006:7.7.41
glaux1.0-sentence	3735
perseus-grc2	ἐγὼ δέ , ὦ Σεύθη , οὐδὲν νομίζω ἀνδρὶ ἄλλως τε καὶ ἄρχοντι κάλλιον εἶναι κτῆμα οὐδὲ λαμπρότερον ἀρετῆς καὶ δικαιοσύνης καὶ γενναιότητος .
perseus-eng2	but I believe, Seuthes, that no possession is more honourable for a man, especially a commander, or more splendid than valour and justice and generosity.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.7.42
glaux1.0-sentence	3736
perseus-grc2	ὁ γὰρ ταῦτα ἔχων πλουτεῖ μὲν ὄντων φίλων πολλῶν , πλουτεῖ δὲ ἄλλων βουλομένων γενέσθαι , καὶ εὖ μὲν πράττων ἔχει τοὺς συνησθησομένους , ἐὰν δέ τι σφαλῇ , οὐ σπανίζει τῶν βοηθησόντων .
perseus-eng2	For he who possesses these things is rich because many are his friends, and rich because still others desire to become his friends; if he prospers he has those who will rejoice with him, and if he meets with a mischance he does not lack those who will come to his aid.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.7.43
glaux1.0-sentence	3737
perseus-grc2	ἀλλὰ γὰρ εἰ μήτε ἐκ τῶν ἔργων κατέμαθες ὅτι σοι ἐκ τῆς ψυχῆς φίλος ἦν , μήτε ἐκ τῶν ἐμῶν λόγων δύνασαι τοῦτο γνῶναι , ἀλλὰ τοὺς τῶν στρατιωτῶν λόγους πάντας κατανόησον ·
perseus-eng2	But if you neither learned from my deeds that I was your friend from the bottom of my heart nor are able to perceive this from my words, at least give a thought to what the soldiers say with one accord;

cts:urn:0032-006:7.7.43
glaux1.0-sentence	3738
perseus-grc2	παρῆσθα γὰρ καὶ ἤκουες ἃ ἔλεγον οἱ ψέγειν ἐμὲ βουλόμενοι .
perseus-eng2	for you were present and heard what those who wished to censure me said.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.7.44
glaux1.0-sentence	3739
perseus-grc2	κατηγόρουν γάρ μου πρὸς Λακεδαιμονίους ὡς σὲ περὶ πλείονος ποιοίμην ἢ Λακεδαιμονίους , αὐτοὶ δ’ ἐνεκάλουν ἐμοὶ ὡς μᾶλλον μέλει μοι ὅπως τὰ σὰ καλῶς ἔχοι ἢ ὅπως τὰ ἑαυτῶν ·
perseus-eng2	They accused me before the Lacedaemonians of regarding you more highly than I did the Lacedaemonians, while on their own account they charged me with being more concerned that your affairs should be well than that their own should be;

cts:urn:0032-006:7.7.44
glaux1.0-sentence	3740
perseus-grc2	ἔφασαν δέ με καὶ δῶρα ἔχειν παρὰ σοῦ .
perseus-eng2	and they also said that I had received gifts from you.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.7.45
glaux1.0-sentence	3741
perseus-grc2	καίτοι τὰ δῶρα ταῦτα πότερον οἴει αὐτοὺς κακόνοιάν τινα ἐνιδόντας μοι πρὸς σὲ αἰτιᾶσθαί με ἔχειν παρὰ σοῦ ἢ προθυμίαν πολλὴν περὶ σὲ κατανοήσαντας ;
perseus-eng2	And yet, touching these gifts, do you imagine it was because they had observed in me some ill-will toward you that they charged me with having received them from you, or because they perceived in me abundant good-will for you?

cts:urn:0032-006:7.7.46
glaux1.0-sentence	3742
perseus-grc2	ἐγὼ μὲν οἶμαι πάντας ἀνθρώπους νομίζειν εὔνοιαν δεῖν ἀποδείκνυσθαι τούτῳ παρ’ οὗ ἂν δῶρά τις λαμβάνῃ .
perseus-eng2	For my part, I presume that everybody believes he ought to show good-will to the man from whom he receives gifts.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.7.46
glaux1.0-sentence	3743
perseus-grc2	σὺ δὲ πρὶν μὲν ὑπηρετῆσαί τί σοι ἐμὲ ἐδέξω ἡδέως καὶ ὄμμασι καὶ φωνῇ καὶ ξενίοις καὶ ὅσα ἔσοιτο ὑπισχνούμενος οὐκ ἐνεπίμπλασο ·
perseus-eng2	You, however, before I had rendered you any service, welcomed me with a pleasure which you showed by your eyes, your voice, and your hospitality, and you could not make promises enough about all that should be done for me;

cts:urn:0032-006:7.7.46
glaux1.0-sentence	3744
perseus-grc2	ἐπεὶ δὲ κατέπραξας ἃ ἐβούλου καὶ γεγένησαι ὅσον ἐγὼ ἐδυνάμην μέγιστος , νῦν οὕτω με ἄτιμον ὄντα ἐν τοῖς στρατιώταις τολμᾷς περιορᾶν ;
perseus-eng2	yet now that you have accomplished what you desired and have become as great as I could possibly make you, have you now the heart to allow me to be held in such dishonour among the soldiers?

cts:urn:0032-006:7.7.47
glaux1.0-sentence	3745
perseus-grc2	ἀλλὰ μὴν ὅτι σοι δόξει ἀποδοῦναι πιστεύω καὶ τὸν χρόνον διδάξειν σε καὶ αὐτόν γέ σε οὐχὶ ἀνέξεσθαι τοὺς σοὶ προεμένους εὐεργεσίαν ὁρῶντά σοι ἐγκαλοῦντας .
perseus-eng2	But truly I have confidence, not only that time will teach you that you must resolve to pay what is due, but also that you will not yourself endure to see those men who have freely given you good service, accusing you.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.7.47
glaux1.0-sentence	3746
perseus-grc2	δέομαι οὖν σου , ὅταν ἀποδιδῷς , προθυμεῖσθαι ἐμὲ παρὰ τοῖς στρατιώταις τοιοῦτον ποιῆσαι οἷόνπερ καὶ παρέλαβες .
perseus-eng2	I ask you, therefore, when you render payment, to use all zeal to make me just such a man in the eyes of the soldiers as I was when you made me your friend.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.7.48
glaux1.0-sentence	3747
perseus-grc2	ἀκούσας ταῦτα ὁ Σεύθης κατηράσατο τῷ αἰτίῳ τοῦ μὴ πάλαι ἀποδεδόσθαι τὸν μισθόν ·
perseus-eng2	Upon hearing these words Seuthes cursed the man who was to blame for the fact that the soldiers’ wages had not been paid long ago;

cts:urn:0032-006:7.7.48
glaux1.0-sentence	3748
perseus-grc2	καὶ πάντες Ἡρακλείδην τοῦτον ὑπώπτευσαν εἶναι ·
perseus-eng2	and everybody suspected that Heracleides was that man;

cts:urn:0032-006:7.7.48
glaux1.0-sentence	3749
perseus-grc2	ἐγὼ γάρ , ἔφη , οὔτε διενοήθην πώποτε ἀποστερῆσαι ἀποδώσω τε .
perseus-eng2	for I," said Seuthes, "never intended to defraud them, and I will pay over the money.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.7.49
glaux1.0-sentence	3750
perseus-grc2	ἐντεῦθεν πάλιν εἶπεν ὁ Ξενοφῶν ·
perseus-eng2	Thereupon Xenophon said again:

cts:urn:0032-006:7.7.49
glaux1.0-sentence	3751
perseus-grc2	ἐπεὶ τοίνυν διανοῇ ἀποδιδόναι , νῦν ἐγώ σου δέομαι δι’ ἐμοῦ ἀποδοῦναι , καὶ μὴ περιιδεῖν με διὰ σὲ ἀνομοίως ἔχοντα ἐν τῇ στρατιᾷ νῦν τε καὶ ὅτε πρὸς σὲ ἀφικόμεθα .
perseus-eng2	Then since you intend to make payment, I now request you to do it through me, and not to allow me to have, on your account, a different standing with the army now from what I had at the time when we came to you.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.7.50
glaux1.0-sentence	3752
perseus-grc2	ὁ δ’ εἶπεν ·
perseus-eng2	And Seuthes replied:

cts:urn:0032-006:7.7.50
glaux1.0-sentence	3753
perseus-grc2	ἀλλ’ οὔτ’ ἐν τοῖς στρατιώταις ἔσει δι’ ἐμὲ ἀτιμότερος ἄν τε μένῃς παρ’ ἐμοὶ χιλίους μόνους ὁπλίτας ἔχων , ἐγώ σοι τά τε χωρία ἀποδώσω καὶ τ- ἄλλα ἃ ὑπεσχόμην .
perseus-eng2	But you will not be less honoured among the soldiers on my account if you will stay with me, keeping only a thousand hoplites, and, besides, I will give over the fortresses to you and the other things that I promised.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.7.51
glaux1.0-sentence	3754
perseus-grc2	ὁ δὲ πάλιν εἶπε ·
perseus-eng2	And Xenophon answered:

cts:urn:0032-006:7.7.51
glaux1.0-sentence	3755
perseus-grc2	ταῦτα μὲν ἔχειν οὕτως οὐχ οἷόν τε ·
perseus-eng2	This plan is not a possible one;

cts:urn:0032-006:7.7.51
glaux1.0-sentence	3756
perseus-grc2	ἀπόπεμπε δὲ ἡμᾶς .
perseus-eng2	so dismiss us.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.7.51
glaux1.0-sentence	3757
perseus-grc2	καὶ μήν , ἔφη ὁ Σεύθης , καὶ ἀσφαλέστερόν γέ σοι οἶδα ὂν παρ’ ἐμοὶ μένειν ἢ ἀπιέναι .
perseus-eng2	Yet really," said Seuthes, "I know that it is also safer for you to stay with me than to go away.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.7.52
glaux1.0-sentence	3758
perseus-grc2	ὁ δὲ πάλιν εἶπεν ·
perseus-eng2	And Xenophon replied:

cts:urn:0032-006:7.7.52
glaux1.0-sentence	3759
perseus-grc2	ἀλλὰ τὴν μὲν σὴν πρόνοιαν ἐπαινῶ ·
perseus-eng2	Well, I thank you for your solicitude;

cts:urn:0032-006:7.7.52
glaux1.0-sentence	3760
perseus-grc2	ἐμοὶ δὲ μένειν οὐχ οἷόν τε ·
perseus-eng2	it is not possible, however, for me to stay;

cts:urn:0032-006:7.7.52
glaux1.0-sentence	3761
perseus-grc2	ὅπου δ’ ἂν ἐγὼ ἐντιμότερος ὦ , νόμιζε καὶ σοὶ τοῦτο ἀγαθὸν ἔσεσθαι .
perseus-eng2	but wherever I may enjoy greater honour, be sure that it will be a good thing for you as well as myself.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.7.53
glaux1.0-sentence	3762
perseus-grc2	ἐντεῦθεν λέγει Σεύθης ·
perseus-eng2	Thereupon Seuthes said:

perseus-eng2	As for ready money, I have only a little, and that I give you, a talent.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.7.53

cts:urn:0032-006:7.7.53

perseus-eng2	In fact, on that very day Bion and Nausicleides arrived with money to give to the army and were entertained by Xenophon, and they redeemed his horse, which he had sold at  Lampsacus  for fifty daries,—for they suspected that he had sold it for want of money, since they heard he was fond of the horse,—gave it back to him, and would not accept from him the price of it.

perseus-eng2	When they reached the place, about midnight, the slaves that were round about the tower and most of the animals ran away, the Greeks leaving them unheeded in order to capture Asidates himself and his belongings.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.8.13
glaux1.0-sentence	3808

perseus-eng2	And when they found themselves unable to take the tower by storm (for it was high and large, and furnished with battlements and a considerable force of warlike defenders), they attempted to dig through the tower-wall.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.8.15

perseus-eng2	Then, as the result of their shouting and lighting of beacon fires, there came to their assistance Itamenes with his own force, and from Comania Assyrian hoplites and Hyrcanian horsemen—these also being mercenaries in the service of the King—to the number of eighty, as well as about eight hundred peltasts, and more from Parthenium, and more from  Apollonia  and from the near-by places, including horsemen.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.8.16
glaux1.0-sentence	3815

perseus-eng2	so seizing all the cattle and sheep there were, as well as slaves, they got them inside of a hollow square and proceeded to drive them along with them, not because they were any longer giving thought to the matter of booty, but out of fear that the retreat might become a rout if they should go off and leave their booty behind, and that the enemy might become bolder and the soldiers more disheartened;

cts:urn:0032-006:7.8.16
glaux1.0-sentence	3816
perseus-grc2	νῦν δὲ ἀπῇσαν ὡς περὶ τῶν χρημάτων μαχούμενοι .
perseus-eng2	while as it was, they were withdrawing like men ready to fight for their possessions.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.8.17

perseus-eng2	But as soon as Gongylus saw that the Greeks were few and those who were attacking them many, he sallied forth himself, in spite of his mother, at the head of his own force, desiring to take part in the action;

cts:urn:0032-006:7.8.17

perseus-eng2	and Procles also came to the rescue, from Halisarna and Teuthrania, the descendant of Damaratus.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.8.18
glaux1.0-sentence	3819
perseus-grc2	οἱ δὲ περὶ Ξενοφῶντα ἐπεὶ πάνυ ἤδη ἐπιέζοντο ὑπὸ τῶν τοξευμάτων καὶ σφενδονῶν , πορευόμενοι κύκλῳ , ὅπως τὰ ὅπλα ἔχοιεν πρὸ τῶν τοξευμάτων , μόλις διαβαίνουσι τὸν Κάρκασον ποταμόν , τετρωμένοι ἐγγὺς οἱ ἡμίσεις .
perseus-eng2	And Xenophon and his men, by this time sorely distressed by the arrows and sling-stones, and marching in a curved line in order to keep their shields facing the arrows, succeeded with difficulty in crossing the Carcasus river, almost half of their number wounded.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.8.19
glaux1.0-sentence	3820
perseus-grc2	ἐνταῦθα δὲ Ἀγασίας ὁ Στυμφάλιος λοχαγὸς τιτρώσκεται , τὸν πάντα χρόνον μαχόμενος πρὸς τοὺς πολεμίους .
perseus-eng2	It was here that Agasias, the Stymphalian captain, was wounded, though he continued to fight all the time against the enemy.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.8.19
glaux1.0-sentence	3821
perseus-grc2	καὶ διασῴζονται ἀνδράποδα ὡς διακόσια ἔχοντες καὶ πρόβατα ὅσον θύματα .
perseus-eng2	So they came out of it in safety, with about two hundred slaves and sheep enough for sacrificial victims.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.8.20
glaux1.0-sentence	3822
perseus-grc2	τῇ δὲ ὑστεραίᾳ θυσάμενος ὁ Ξενοφῶν ἐξάγει νύκτωρ πᾶν τὸ στράτευμα , ὅπως ὅτι μακροτάτην ἔλθοι τῆς Λυδίας , εἰς τὸ μὴ διὰ τὸ ἐγγὺς εἶναι φοβεῖσθαι , ἀλλ’ ἀφυλακτεῖν .
perseus-eng2	The next day Xenophon offered sacrifice, and then by night led forth the entire army with the intention of making as long a march as possible through  Lydia , to the end that Asidates might not be fearful on account of their nearness, but be off his guard.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.8.21
glaux1.0-sentence	3823
perseus-grc2	ὁ δὲ Ἀσιδάτης ἀκούσας ὅτι πάλιν ἐπ’ αὐτὸν τεθυμένος εἴη ὁ Ξενοφῶν καὶ παντὶ τῷ στρατεύματι ἥξοι , ἐξαυλίζεται εἰς κώμας ὑπὸ τὸ Παρθένιον πόλισμα ἐχούσας .
perseus-eng2	Asidates, however, hearing that Xenophon had sacrificed again with a view to attacking him and that he was to come with the entire army, left his tower and encamped in villages that lay below the town of Parthenium.

cts:urn:0032-006:7.8.22
glaux1.0-sentence	3824
perseus-grc2	ἐνταῦθα οἱ περὶ Ξενοφῶντα συντυγχάνουσιν αὐτῷ καὶ λαμβάνουσιν αὐτὸν καὶ γυναῖκα καὶ παῖδας καὶ τοὺς ἵππους καὶ πάντα τὰ ὄντα ·
perseus-eng2	There Xenophon and his men fell in with him, and they captured him, his wife and children, his horses, and all that he had;

cts:urn:0032-006:7.8.22
glaux1.0-sentence	3825
perseus-grc2	καὶ οὕτω τὰ πρότερα ἱερὰ ἀπέβη .
perseus-eng2	and thus the omens of the earlier sacrifice proved true.

perseus-eng2	And there Xenophon paid his greeting to the god;

cts:urn:0032-006:7.8.23

perseus-eng2	for the Laconians, the captains, the other generals, and the soldiers joined in arranging matters so that he got the pick of horses and teams of oxen and all the rest;

perseus-eng2	the result was, that he was now able even to do a kindness to another.

perseus-eng2	Meanwhile Thibron arrived and took over the army, and uniting it with the rest of his Greek forces, proceeded to wage war upon Tissaphernes and Pharnabazus.

perseus-eng2	The length of the entire journey, upward and downward, was two hundred and fifteen stages, one thousand, one hundred and fifty parasangs, or thirty-four thousand, two hundred and fifty-five stadia;
